1.6A.5.2: PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING AUTHORITY:
   A.   Council Contract Approval Required:
      1.   All agreements for purchases and all contracts which impose a
financial obligation on the City must first be authorized by the City Council
except as provided by this section 5.2.
      2.   The City Manager may sign on behalf of the City any contract
authorized by the City Council, except where otherwise directed by the City
Council.
   B.   Exceptions: Unless otherwise prohibited for Home Rule municipalities or
by other law, the City Manager (or the City Manager’s designee, which authority
must be in writing for transactions of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000)
or more) may contract for or otherwise procure any supplies, material, rights,
equipment or services for the City (and may execute any associated documents)
and may enter into legal settlements, without prior City Council approval,
provided that the following terms are met:
      1.   Authority Not To Exceed $50,000: No transactions authorized under
this section may exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in total value
(except in case of emergency as described in this section below).
      2.   Transactions Must Be Within Budget Limits: In the reasonable opinion
of the City Manager, the funds for any transaction under this section must be
reasonably available from the funds already approved by the City Council in its
annual budget ordinance.
      3.   Emergency: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in
case of accident or other circumstances creating an emergency necessitating any
expenditure in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), the City Manager
may, without the prior consent of the Council, award contracts and make
purchases for the purpose of repairing damages caused by an accident or meeting
the public emergency, but shall promptly notify the City Council of such
emergency and the necessity of such action, together with a description of such
expenditures. In the case of emergency action under this provision, the
requirement that any action be dependent on the existence of previously
budgeted and available funds shall not apply.
      4.   Limited Authority To Amend Existing Agreements: notwithstanding any
other provision of this section, regarding contracts, agreements or purchases
previously authorized by the City Council or previously approved by the City
Manager (or the City Manager’s designee), the City Manager (or the City
Manager’s designee) may approve and execute amendments or changes to any such
authorized contracts, agreements or purchases provided that:
         a.   Any such amendment shall not increase the total contract,
agreement, or purchase price in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) or more or the time of completion by a total of one hundred eighty
(180) days or more. Any amounts more than this must be submitted to the City
Council and must comply with the requirements of 720 ILCS 5/33E-9 regarding
change orders. A series of change orders in excess of twenty-five thousand
dollars ($25,000.00) must also be submitted to the City Council and must comply
with 720 ILCS 5/33E-9.
         b.   No such amendments shall violate any provisions of Illinois law
governing public contracts as contained in the Illinois Criminal Code at 720
ILCS 5/Art. 33E.
      5.   City-Owned Real Estate And Property: Notwithstanding any other
provisions of this section, unless otherwise directed by the City Council, the
City Manger shall have the authority to enter into and to amend agreements for
the use of all or part of any City-owned real estate or property provided:
         a.   That such agreement is for a period of twelve (12) months or
less;
         b.   That the City Manager finds that the agreement is on terms and
conditions that are reasonable under the circumstances, advance the public
interest of the City, and are not in violation of any state law or covenant
governing the real estate or property; and
         c.   That, prior to executing any such agreement, the City Manager
first shall report to the City Council about the potential agreement and shall
provide a reasonable opportunity for any Council member to object and to
request that the agreement first be considered by the City Council.
      6.   Employee Benefit Agreements. Notwithstanding any other provisions of
this Section, because of the short turn-around time-frames associated with the
provision and operation of the City’s health and life insurance agreements and
other employee benefit-related agreements, the City Manager (or the Manager’s
designee) is authorized to approve the annual renewal of those agreements and
any changes made to such agreements throughout a plan-year, regardless of total
value, provided that:
         a.   Such agreements are consistent with reasonable budgetary
practices and budgetary expectations of the City; and
         b.   That a summary of the overall annual agreements or plan documents
are reported to the City Council within fourteen (14) days of their acceptance
by the City Manager (or the Manager’s designee).
      7.   Duty To Report: Unless previously reported to the Council, the City
Manager (or the City Manager’s designee) shall regularly report to the Council
any action taken under the authority of this section. Except as otherwise
required, a report of a payment made under this section may be contained in the
regular warrant reports provided to the Council, which shall satisfy this
reporting requirement.
   C.   Duties Regarding Comparative Pricing And Competitive Bidding:
      1.   If, in the judgement of the City Manager (or the City Manager’s
designee), it is appropriate under the circumstances, the City shall obtain
reasonable comparative prices for any transactions made under this section that
area in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
      2.   The City Council, pursuant to its home rule authority, waives the
statutory requirements of 65 ILCS 5/8-9-1, including those related to public
bidding for public improvements in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) when, in the opinion of the City Manager (or the City Manager’s
designee), alternative means of obtaining reasonable pricing are appropriate:
      3.   When the administration proposes contracts to the City Council for
public works projects in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) that
have not been obtained through competitive bidding, they shall provide the
basis for such recommendation in any communication to the City Council that
accompanies the request for approval of such contracts.
      4.   The City Manager (or the City Manager’s designee) is authorized to
reject any and all bids solicited by a sealed bid process, when, in the opinion
of the City Manager, such a rejection is appropriate, provided that the City
Manager (or the City Manager’s designee) reports such a rejection to the City
Council.
      5.   The City Council pursuant to its home rule authority, waives the
statutory requirements of 50 ILCS 510/0.01 et. seq. (the Local Government
Professional Services Selection Act), as may be amended, in the selection of
professional services covered by that Act.
(Ord. 19-O-86, 11-5-2019; amd. Ord. 20-O-36, 5-20-2020; Ord. 20-O-47, 6-17-
2020; Ord. 23-O-32, 6-6-2023; Ord. 25-O-26, 4-15-2025)
1.6A.5.3: DISPOSAL OF SURPLUS PERSONAL PROPERTY:
   A.   Personal property less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in value.
Whenever the City owns any personal property which is determined by the City
Manager (or designee) to be no longer necessary or useful to, or for the best
interest of the City and having an original value ofless than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00), the City Manager (or designee), at their discretion, may
authorize the disposal of said property, in accordance with the following
conditions and procedures without any additional action by the City Council:
      1.   The City Manager (or designee) shall make a written determination
that the property is no longer needed by the City and shall set forth reasons
therefore.
      2.   The City Manager (or designee) may direct the disposal of such
property in the manner that best supports City finances and/or operations. This
may include but not be limited to, soliciting proposals for the purchase of
such property, selling it at public auction (including through online
websites), scrapping the property, donating the property, or authorizing a
trade of the property for the purchase of other property.
      3.   Disposal or sale of the property hereunder shall not be made to an
officer or employee of the City or to a person related by blood or marriage to
an officer or employee of the City, including any items sold through sealed bid
or at public auction.
      4.   The City Manager shall ensure that a written report of all such
actions shall be presented to the City Council on at least a semi-annual basis
for any individual item with an original or current value over five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
   B.   Personal property between one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in value. Whenever the City owns any personal
property which is determined by the City Manager (or designee) to be no longer
necessary or useful to, or for the best interest of the City, and the City
Manager reasonably determines that said property originally had a value of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to fifty thousand ($50,000.00), the City Manager
(or designee) may authorize the disposal of such personal property in
accordance with the following conditions and procedures:
      1.   The City Manager ( or designee) shall make a written determination
that the property is no longer needed by the City and shall set forth the
reasons therefore.
      2.   The City Manager (or designee) may direct the disposal of such
property in the manner that best supports City finances and/or operations. This
may include but not be limited to, soliciting proposals for the purchase of
such property, selling it at public auction (including through online
websites), scrapping the property, donating the property, or authorizing a
trade of it for the purchase of other property.
      3.   In the event the City Manager (or designee) concludes that it is in
the best interests of the City operations to scrap or donate any property with
an original value of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00), the City Manager may only authorize such action following
reasonable notice to the City Council of such intent and the reason therefore
and must provide the opportunity for any member of the Council to object to
such action. In the event of such an objection, the City Manager shall submit
the scrap or donation proposal to the City Council for a vote before such
action can be undertaken.
      4.   Disposal or sale of the property hereunder shall not be made to an
officer or employee of the City or to a person related by blood or marriage to
an officer or employee of the City, including any items sold through sealed bid
or at public auction.
      5.   The City Manager shall ensure that a written report of all such
actions shall be presented to the City Council on at least a semi-annual basis.
   C.   Personal property over fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in value or
items having title. Whenever the City owns:
      1.   Any personal property which is determined by the City Manager (or
designee) to be no longer necessary or useful to, or for the best interest of
the City, and the City Manager reasonably determines that said property either
originally had a value of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more or has an
estimated resale value of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more; or
      2.   An item of personal property having a title (i.e., vehicle), then
such item may only be disposed in accordance with City Council action.
      3.   Disposal or sale of the property hereunder shall not be made to an
officer or employee of the City or to a person related by blood or marriage to
an officer or employee of the City, including any items sold through sealed bid
or at public auction.
   D.   Disposal of surplus real property. The provisions of this Chapter do
not apply to the disposal of surplus city-owned real estate, which is subject
to the provisions of
Chapter 9 of this Title 1.
(Ord. 24-O-33, 5-21-2024; amd. Ord. 25-O-05, 2-4-2025)
1.6A.5.4: PAYMENT AUTHORITY:
   A.   All payments of City funds for expenses and liabilities of the City
must first be approved by the City Council except as provided in this Section
1.6A.5.4 .
   B.   Administrative Payment Authority: The following, time-sensitive
payments may be authorized administratively by the City Manager (or by the City
Manager’s designee), absent prior Council consideration, provided that (i) in
the City Manager’s opinion, such payments are reasonably within the budgeted
amounts already approved by the Council in its annual budget ordinance; and
(ii) such budgeted funds are available; and (iii) all such payments are
included in the next reasonably possible warrant list (or similar report)
presented to the City Council for the City Council’s information (with the
exception of Health and Life Insurance Fund Expenditures pursuant to subsection
7 below).
      1.   Time Sensitive Payments Less Than $7,500: Payments that do not
exceed seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) for expenses that, in
the opinion of the City Manager, or his designee, cannot reasonably be delayed
until the next meeting of the City Council, which have been authorized and
budgeted. No expenses in excess of seven thousand five hundred dollars
($7,500.00) may be split into separate payments in order to fall within the
seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) cap amount. For instance, an
invoice for fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for a single project cannot
be split into two seven thousand five hundred dollar ($7,500.00) invoices.
      2.   Payment For Utility Services: Payments for utility service such as
electric or natural gas that in the opinion of the City Manager or his designee
cannot reasonably be delayed until the next meeting of the City Council.
      3.   Payments To 1099 Contractors Employed As Recreational Or Pool
Instructors: Payments that do not exceed seven thousand five hundred dollars
($7,500.00) each to 1099 contractors employed as recreational or pool
instructors, which have been authorized and budgeted.
      4.   Third Party Event Sponsor Payments: Payment to a third party of
money received by the City on behalf of that third party, such as a producer’s
share of ticket sale funds collected by the Opera House.
      5.   Previously Authorized Payments: Payments previously authorized by
the City Council such as bond payments.
      6.   Authorized Payroll And Associated Expenses: Payroll and associated
expenses for positions previously approved by the City Council, as well as any
final payouts to departing City employees, if paid in a manner consistent with
City policy.
      7.   Health And Life Insurance Fund: Payment from the Health and Life
Insurance Fund, provided that any insurance administrator retained by the City
has recommended such payment. (Ord. 19-O-86, 11-5-2019)
1.6A.5.5: APPROPRIATION AND LEVIES:
   A.   The City Manager shall cause to be prepared each year the annual
appropriation ordinance or annual budget within the time required by law.
   B.   The City Manager shall cause to be prepared the annual tax levy
ordinance for passage and file a certified copy of it with the County Clerk
within the time required by law. (1963 Code, § 4.07; amd. 1986 Code)
   C.   The City Manager shall keep current accounts of the amounts
appropriated and budgeted and the amounts spent out of each budget account,
showing the unexpended balances at all times. (1963 Code, § 4.07) (Ord. 19-O-
86, 11-5-2019)
1.6A.5.6:   ACCOUNTS:
The City Manager shall keep current accounts showing at all times the fiscal
condition of the City, including the current and anticipated revenue of all
municipal funds and accounts; and shall supervise collection of all money due
the City. (1963 Code, § 4.08) (Ord. 19-O-86, 11-5-2019)
1.6A.6: REPORTS AND DOCUMENTS:
   A.   Reports And Publications: The city manager shall supervise the
publication of all notices, ordinances or other documents required by law to be
published, and shall prepare or cause to be prepared all reports which the city
or any city official is required by law to prepare. (1963 Code, §4.10)
   B.   Records And Certificates:
      1.   The city manager shall prepare and have custody of all municipal
records required by law to be kept by the city but not required to be kept by a
specific officer. Where the law makes it the duty of a specific officer to keep
or maintain records, the city manager shall make available to such officer all
necessary clerical assistance for the preparation of such records and shall
make available a place for the custody of such records. The city manager shall
make available to the city clerk stenographic or clerical assistance necessary
for the preparation of the journal of city council proceedings, the record of
ordinances and all other documents which by law the city clerk is required to
keep. He shall perform similar service for the city treasurer in the
maintenance of bond registers, and all other records or documents which by law
the city treasurer is required to keep or prepare.
      2.   Where the law requires or provides for certification of any records
or documents by any officer of the city, the city manager shall cause such
records or documents to be properly prepared and presented to such officer for
his signature. (1963 Code, §4.12)
   C.   Maps And Plats: The city manager shall cause to be kept a complete set
of maps and plats showing the location of all city utilities and other
municipal properties, all streets and other public places, and all lots or
parcels of land subdivided according to law. (1963 Code, §4.13)
ARTICLE B. CITY CLERK
SECTION:
1.6B.1: Appointment And Term
1.6B.2: Oath
1.6B.3: Bond
1.6B.4: Compensation
1.6B.5: Duties
1.6B.1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
   A.   The city clerk shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council for a four (4) year term and shall serve until his/
her successor is appointed and qualified as provided by law.
   B.   The term of the city clerk shall commence at the first regular or
special meeting of the city council in the month of May following the election
of the mayor. (Ord. 2581, 8-15-1995)
1.6B.2: OATH:
The city clerk shall take the oath as required by the Illinois Compiled
Statutes. (1986 Code)
1.6B.3: BOND:
Upon entering the duties of his/her office, the city clerk shall execute a bond
in the amount and with such sureties as may be required by the council
conditioned upon the faithful performance of his/her duties 1 . (1986 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1.6.3 of this chapter.
1.6B.4: COMPENSATION:
The salary of the city clerk shall be as determined by the city council from
time to time. (Ord. 01-0-13, 5-1-2001)
1.6B.5: DUTIES:
   A.   Records: The city clerk shall keep all papers belonging to the
municipality the custody and control of which are not given to other officers.
The clerk shall attend all meetings of the city council and keep a full record
of their proceedings in the journal. The record of those proceedings shall be
made available for public inspection within ten (10) days after being approved
or accepted by the city council as the official minutes of their proceedings.
   B.   Seal And Attest Documents: The city clerk shall seal and attest all
ordinances and resolutions of the city council, contracts of the city and all
licenses, permits and all other such documents that require this formality.
   C.   Corporate Seal: The city clerk shall be the custodian of the city's
seal and shall affix its impression on documents whenever required.
   D.   Warrants: The city clerk shall, upon the allowance of any account or
claim by the city council, sign a warrant therefor upon the city treasury
payable to the order of the claimant, which warrant, when signed by the mayor
and the city clerk, shall be paid by the city treasurer. He shall keep in a
suitable book an accurate list of all warrants drawn on the treasury, stating
the date, number and account thereof and the name of the person in whose favor
drawn.
   E.   (Rep. by Ord. 2581, 8-15-1995)
   F.   Record Of Ordinances: All ordinances passed by the city council shall
be deposited in the office of the city clerk and shall be duly recorded by the
clerk in the record book of ordinances and appropriately indexed by title or
subject.
The city clerk shall file and carefully preserve the originals of all
ordinances deposited in his office. He may correct errors in numbering of any
section of any ordinances, and insert the proper numbers and correct clerical
mistakes. The clerk shall make at the foot of the record of each ordinance
recorded a memorandum of the date of its passage and the date of its
publication, when required to be published, which record, memorandum or
certified copy thereof shall be deemed official evidence of the passage and
legal publication of such ordinances for all purposes whatsoever.
   G.   Records On File: The city clerk shall maintain on file three (3) copies
of all codes, regulations or public records adopted either in this code or
otherwise by the city council by reference and there kept available for public
use, inspection and examination.
   H.   Additional Duties: In addition to the duties herein provided, the city
clerk shall perform such other duties and functions required by law or
ordinance or otherwise assigned by the mayor and city council.
   I.   Deputy Clerks:
      1.   It is hereby authorized that the positions of chief deputy clerk and
deputy clerk are hereby established. No person shall be eligible to be
appointed chief deputy clerk who is not, at the time of his or her appointment,
a member of the administrative staff of the city.
      2.   The salary of the chief deputy clerk and deputy clerk shall be as
determined by the city manager and included in the annual budget. (1986 Code;
amd. Ord. 2581, 8-15-1995; Ord. 05-0-77, 8-16-2005; Ord. 22-O-36, 6-21-2022)
ARTICLE C. CITY TREASURER
SECTION
1.6C.1: Appointment
1.6C.2: Bond Requirements
1.6C.3: General Duties
1.6C.4: Deposit Of Funds
1.6C.1: APPOINTMENT:
The City Treasurer shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the approval of the
City Council. (Ord. 822, 5-20-69)
1.6C.2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
The Treasurer shall give bond in an amount that is three (3) times the latest
Federal census population or any subsequent census figure used for Motor Fuel
Tax purposes, provided; however, that pursuant to Section
1.6.3 of this Municipal Code, this obligation may be fulfilled without
providing bond through the City's regular insurance provider coverage, if the
provider indicates reasonable insurance coverage is in place to fulfill this
equivalent coverage of the bond obligation. (1963 Code, §6.02; amd. Ord. 1639,
2-3-81; amd. Ord. 19-O-86, 11-5-2019)
1.6C.3: GENERAL DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The City Treasurer shall perform such duties as may be
prescribed by law or by ordinance. The Treasurer shall receive all money paid
into the City, either directly from the person paying it or from the hands of
such other officer as may receive it, and the Treasurer shall pay out money
only as authorized by the City Code regarding Payment Authority at Section
1.6A.5.3.
   B.   Accounts: The City Treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may
be required by the City Council. The City Treasurer is authorized by the City
Council to set up and transfer funds each fiscal year in a manner consistent
with the budget approved by the City Council. (1963 Code, §6.05)
   C.   Reports: The City Treasurer shall make monthly reports to the Council
showing the state of the finances of the City, and the amounts received and
spent during the month, which reports shall be filed, and he shall make an
annual report with the total amount of all receipts and expenditures of the
City and his transactions as City Treasurer during the preceding fiscal year.
(1963 Code, §6.06; amd. 1986 Code)
   D.   Register of Warrants: The City Treasurer shall keep a register of all
warrants, bonds or orders filed with him or paid by him, and all vouchers, as
required by law. (1963 Code, §6.07)(Ord. 1342, 2-1-77; amd. Ord. 19-O-86, 11-5-
2019)
1.6C.4: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
The City Treasurer shall be custodian of all City funds, and he shall keep the
City money separate and distinct from his own and shall not intermingle his own
money with it or make private or personal use of the City funds. Funds shall be
deposited in such depositories as may be designated by the Council from time to
time as provided by law. (Ord. 788A, 9-17-68; amd. 1986 Code)
CHAPTER 7
MUNICIPAL DEPARTMENTS
ARTICLE A. DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE
SECTION:
1.7A.1: Department Established
1.7A.2: Director of Finance
1.7A.3: Functions of the Director
1.7A.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the Department of Finance for the City consisting of
the Director of Finance and such other employees as may be provided for by the
Council. (1963 Code, §7.01)
1.7A.2: DIRECTOR OF FINANCE:
There is established the position of Director of Finance, who shall be
appointed by the City Manager, as provided by law. The Director of Finance
shall have control over all employees assigned to this Department, subject to
the supervision of the City Manager. (1963 Code, §7.02)
1.7A.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR:
The Director of Finance shall:
   A.   Prepare and keep all financial records of the City.
   B.   Keep a current account of the amounts appropriated and budgeted each
year and the sums spent out of each budget account showing the unexpended
balance for each item.
   C.   Prepare each year the annual appropriation and tax levy ordinance in
time for enactment and filing as required by law, subject to the supervision of
the City Manager.
   D.   Keep accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of the City,
including the current and anticipated revenues and expenses of all Municipal
funds and accounts.
   E.   Prepare and keep for the City Treasurer all registers and other records
required by law to be kept by the City Treasurer, and prepare for signature and
publication the annual City Treasurer's report and any other report required by
law. (1963 Code, §7.03; amd. Ord. 788A, 9-17-68; Ord. 821, 5-20-69; 1986 Code)
   F.   Pay all bills of the City in the following manner:
      1.   The Director of Finance shall prepare, no less than monthly, a
warrant for the payment of all sums due from the City, listing each item and
the account out of which it is payable (with the exception of authorized health
and life insurance fund payments).
      2.   Following authorization by the City Council (or by the City Manager
in the limited instances authorized by Section
1.6A.5), the City Treasurer shall make the payments identified on such warrant
list.
   G.   Receive and Collect Fees: The Director of Finance shall receive and
collect all license fees, permit fees, charges for Municipal utility services
rendered by the City, sums due the City on any contract, and all other sums due
the City are required to be paid to him by ordinances of the City.
The Director shall keep the City Manager informed as to all sums due in taxes,
accumulations in the motor fuel tax account to the credit of the City, and all
other revenues to which the City is entitled.
ARTICLE B. BUDGET DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1.7B.1: Department Established
1.7B.2: Budget Officer
1.7B.3: Functions of the Officer
1.7B.4: Compilation and Contents of Budget
1.7B.5: Capital Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund
1.7B.6: Revision of Annual Budget
1.7B.7: Funds for Contingency Purposes
1.7B.8: Public Inspection, Notice of Hearing
1.7B.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the Budget Department for the City. It shall consist of
the Budget Officer, and such administrative assistants and other employees as
may be provided for by the City Council in the annual appropriation and budget
ordinances of the City. (Ord. 1784, 2-1-83)
1.7B.2: BUDGET OFFICER:
There is hereby established a position of Budget Officer, who shall be
appointed by the City Manager, as provided by law. The Budget Officer shall
have control over all employees assigned to this Department, subject to the
supervision of the City Manager. In the event of a vacancy in the office of
Budget Officer, the City Manager shall serve as ex-officio head of the
Department until the position is filled by separate appointment.
1.7B.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE OFFICER:
The Budget Officer shall have the following duties:
   A.   Encourage and establish the use of efficient planning, budgeting,
auditing, reporting and other fiscal management procedures in all City
departments, commissions and boards.
   B.   Compile an annual budget which shall contain estimates of revenues
available to the City for the fiscal year, together with recommended
expenditures for the City in all departments, commissions and boards. Such
estimates shall be presented in the manner provided by the Illinois Compiled
Statutes.
   C.   Examine all books and records of the City departments, commissions and
boards, which relate to monies received or paid out, or any amounts owed by or
to the City or any department, board or commission thereof.
   D.   To obtain such additional information from the City or any department,
board or commission of the City, as may be helpful in the preparation of the
budget. Such information shall be supplied in the form required by the Budget
Officer.
   E.   To establish such procedures as are necessary to insure compliance with
the budget by the City and all departments, boards and commissions of the City.
1.7B.4: COMPILATION AND CONTENTS OF BUDGET:
The Municipal Budget Officer shall compile a budget, such budget to contain
estimates of revenues available to the Municipality for the fiscal year for
which the budget is drafted together with recommended expenditures for the
Municipality and all the Municipality's departments, boards and commissions.
The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the
two (2) years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is
prepared. Each budget shall show the specific funds from which each anticipated
expenditure shall be made.
1.7B.5: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT, REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT FUND:
In the preparation by the Municipal Budget Officer of the annual budget, an
amount not to exceed one-half of one percent (.5%) of equalized assessed value
of properties subject to taxation by the Municipality may be accumulated in a
separate fund for the purpose or purposes of specific capital improvements,
repairs and/or replacements of specific types of Municipal equipment, or other
tangible property, both real and personal, to be designated as the "Capital
Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund". Expenditures from the Capital
Improvement, Repair or Replacement Fund shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in
which the capital improvement, repair or replacement will occur. Upon the
completion or abandonment of any object for which the Capital Improvement,
Repair or Replacement Fund, or should any surplus monies remain after the
completion or abandonment of any object for which the Capital Improvement,
Repair or Replacement Fund was inaugurated, then such funds no longer necessary
for capital improvements, repairs or the replacement shall be transferred to
the General Corporate Fund of the Municipality on the first day of the fiscal
year following such abandonment, completion or discovery of surplus funds.
1.7B.6: REVISION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
The following guidelines shall apply to changes or corrections to the City's
approved Budget:
   A.   The City Manager has authority to approve changes to line-items within
all funds, except the General Fund, provided the total revised expenditures do
not exceed the total fund's budget amount for that fund.
   B.   For the General Fund, the City Manager may approve line-item changes on
a department level basis only, provided the total revised expenditures do not
exceed the total budget amount for that department.
   C.   All other budget changes must be approved by a majority vote of the
City Council. No budget increases shall be authorized unless funds are
available for such a revision. (Ord. 20-O-62, 8-19-2020)
1.7B.7: FUNDS FOR CONTINGENCY PURPOSES:
The annual budget for the City may contain money set aside for contingency
purposes not to exceed ten percent (10%) of the total budget, less the amount
set aside for contingency purposes, which monies may be expended for
contingencies upon a majority vote of the City Council.
1.7B.8: PUBLIC INSPECTION, NOTICE OF HEARING:
The City Council shall make the tentative annual budget available for public
inspection by placing a suitable number of copies on file at the City Hall at
least ten (10) days prior to the passage of the annual budget. Not less than
one week after the tentative budget is placed on file and prior to final action
on the budget, the City Council shall hold at least one public hearing or
hearings on the tentative budget, after which hearing or hearings the tentative
budget may be further revised or passed without any further inspection, notice
or hearing. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper
having a general circulation in the City at least one week prior to the time of
the hearing. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE C. LEGAL DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1.7C.1: Department Established
1.7C.2: Corporation Counsel
1.7C.3: Functions Of The Corporation Counsel, General Duties
1.7C.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the legal department of the city, consisting of the
corporation counsel and such other assistants as may be provided by the
council. (1963 Code, §16.01)
1.7C.2: CORPORATION COUNSEL:
There is hereby established the position of corporation counsel who shall be
appointed by the city manager, as provided by law. (1963 Code, §16.02)
1.7C.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE CORPORATION COUNSEL, GENERAL DUTIES:
The corporation counsel shall have the following duties:
   A.   Provide legal advice to the city council, city manager, department
heads, the plan commission, the zoning board of appeals, the liquor commission,
and all other boards as the city manager may direct. (1963 Code, §16.03; amd.
1986 Code; Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
   B.   Represent the city in all matters brought in the name of the city or
against the city in all courts of competent jurisdiction, administrative boards
as established by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, or other hearings as may be
directed by the city manager. (The aforementioned duty is subject to an
exception for those causes of action in which the city is a party defendant
under insurance coverage of the city, in which case, the city's insurance
carrier shall have the right to select legal counsel to appear and represent
the city in said cause of action.) (1963 Code, §16.03; amd. 1986 Code)
ARTICLE D. PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1.7D.1: Department Established
1.7D.2: Director Of Public Works
1.7D.3: Functions Of The Director Of Public Works
1.7D.4: City Engineer
1.7D.5: Functions Of The City Engineer
1.7D.6: Development Engineer
1.7D.7: Functions Of The Development Engineer
1.7D.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the public works department for the city. It shall
consist of the director of public works and all other employees with such
titles as may be appointed by the city manager provided for in the annual
appropriation and city budget ordinance. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.2: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
There is hereby established a position of director of public works, who shall
be appointed by the city manager, as provided by law. The director of public
works shall have control over all employees assigned to this department,
subject to the supervision of the city manager. Qualified persons not
possessing a professional engineering license may hold the position of director
of public works. In the event of a vacancy in the office of the director of
public works, the city manager shall serve as the ex officio head of the
department until the position is filled by separate appointment. (Ord. 04-0-16,
2-3-2004)
1.7D.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS:
The director of public works shall have charge over:
   A.   All public property of the city, including, but not limited to, all
streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, municipal buildings and all other
properties not specifically assigned to some other department.
   B.   The maintenance and operation of the city's water and sanitary sewer
conveyance systems; all streets and sidewalks and the drainage thereof; all
vehicles, equipment, and buildings with the exception of those items
specifically placed under another department.
   C.   All construction, repair or extension of any pavement, any sewer or
water mains, and any appurtenances thereto, and all other construction, repair
or maintenance work conducted by the city.
   D.   All motor vehicles, trucks and other equipment of the city, and all
buildings or places in which the same are housed or kept with the exception of
those items and buildings specifically placed under another department.
   E.   The referral of the making of all surveys, maps, plans and
investigations regarding city facilities to engineers determined by the city
manager.
   F.   The coordination of the functions and duties of the various review
processes within the department.
   G.   The maintenance and operation of the city's water treatment facilities,
sanitary sewage treatment facilities, water supply wells, storage tanks, lift
stations and related appurtenances.
   H.   The maintenance and operation of the city's paratransit division
including vehicle maintenance, preparation of ridership information,
preparation of monthly operating reports, and preparation of reports and
records as may be required by the regional transportation authority.
   I.   The maintenance and operation of the city's park system, exclusive of
facility scheduling and recreation programs.
   J.   Shall serve as the pollution control officer for the city, with the
following additional duties:
      1.   Provide information to all departments of the city relating to
pollution control and environmental regulations and requirements.
      2.   Provide environmental evaluations and audits of all city property
and disposal practices.
      3.   Provide environmental audits for the purchase of any real estate by
the city.
      4.   Establish and administer programs for the management and
documentation of disposal of waste materials from city facilities.
      5.   Develop and implement necessary programs of corrective action on all
city property.
      6.   Develop and promote community programs for improvement of waste
disposal facilities and practices. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.4: CITY ENGINEER:
There is hereby established the position of city engineer who shall be
appointed by the city manager, as is provided by law. When the director of
public works is a licensed engineer, he/she shall be the director of public
works/city engineer. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.5: FUNCTIONS OF THE CITY ENGINEER:
The city engineer shall have the following duties:
   A.   Charge of and supervision over the making of all surveys, plans, maps
and investigations regarding city facilities as may be referred to him/her by
either the director of public works or the city manager.
   B.   The city engineer shall exercise approval authority over engineering
plans for all public improvements conducted for the city and shall make all
inspections needed for that purpose. The city engineer shall exercise final
approval authority for the acceptance of public improvements by the city,
constructed as part of a development project.
   C.   The review and approval of all engineering plans and development plans
for the construction of private and public improvements to be completed as part
of a planned development, subdivision of land or other private development
project.
   D.   Administer and enforce city regulations and policies for the
construction of private and public improvements to be completed as part of a
development project.
   E.   The city engineer shall issue all permits established by ordinances of
the city or the city manager which are required to be issued by the city
engineer.
   F.   Shall direct all the engineering services required of the city as well
as such other duties as may be prescribed by any ordinance of the city or
directed by the city manager. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.6: DEVELOPMENT ENGINEER:
There is hereby created the position of development engineer, who shall be
appointed by the city manager, as provided by law, and who shall report to the
director of public works. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7D.7: FUNCTIONS OF THE DEVELOPMENT ENGINEER:
The development engineer shall have the following duties:
   A.   Provide reports and recommendations to the director for the review of
all engineering plans and development plans for the construction of private and
public improvements to be completed as part of a planned development,
subdivision of land or other private development project.
   B.   To administer and enforce city regulations and policies for the
construction of private and public improvements to be completed as part of a
development project.
   C.   Provide reports and recommendations to the director pertaining to
subdivision standards, typical details, detailed specifications, and
engineering information for development guidelines.
   D.   Review and approve letter of credit information pertaining to public
and private development project, administer and manage letter of credit
guarantees, review and approve applications for the reduction of letters of
credit.
   E.   Coordinate review of detailed engineering information with consultants
who have been retained by the city.
   F.   Assist residents with general information regarding storm water
drainage, lot grading, and similar issues.
   G.   Perform other duties as may be prescribed by any ordinance of the city
or as directed by the director or the city manager. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
ARTICLE E. DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
SECTION:
1.7E.1: Department Established
1.7E.2: Director Of Community Development
1.7E.3: Functions Of The Director Of Community Development
1.7E.4: Building Inspector
1.7E.5: Functions Of The Building Inspector
1.7E.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the department of community development for the city.
It shall consist of the director of the department and all such other employees
as may be appointed by the city manager and provided for in the annual
appropriation and city budget ordinance. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7E.2: DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT:
There is hereby created the position of director of community development, who
shall be appointed by the city manager, as provided by law. The director of
community development shall have control over all employees assigned to this
department, subject to the supervision of the city manager, and shall serve as
building and zoning officer for the city. In the event of a vacancy in the
office of director of community development the city manager shall serve as ex
officio head of the department until the position is filled by separate
appointment. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7E.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT:
The director of community development shall have the following duties:
   A.   The interpretation and administration of the zoning ordinance,
subdivision ordinance, building code, comprehensive plan and all other laws and
regulations pertaining to the planning, development, alteration, and use of
land and structures.
   B.   Maintaining and revising the comprehensive plan and corresponding
documents and studies for the city and its extraterritorial planning
jurisdiction.
   C.   Maintaining and revising the city's zoning map.
   D.   Assisting the corresponding boards and commissions in the review and
approval of requests pertaining to the functional areas within the department,
including, but not limited to, all planned developments, rezonings, amendments
to the text of the zoning ordinance, all subdivisions of land, and variations
from or amendments to corresponding codes and ordinances.
   E.   The coordination of the functions and duties of the various review
processes within the department. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7E.4: BUILDING INSPECTOR:
There is hereby created the position of building inspector, who shall be
appointed by the city manager, as provided by law, and who shall report to the
director of community development. (Ord. 04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
1.7E.5: FUNCTIONS OF THE BUILDING INSPECTOR:
The building inspector shall have the following duties:
   A.   Enforce all laws and ordinances of the city pertaining to construction,
repair, or alteration of buildings or structures, and shall make or cause to be
made all inspections needed for that purpose.
   B.   Issue or cause to be issued all proper permits for such work after
payment of required fees to the director of finance.
   C.   Serve as enforcement officer for the building, electrical, and plumbing
codes and for the zoning ordinances.
   D.   Serve as the enforcement officer of ordinances of the city relating to
the construction and alteration of private improvements, including signs,
swimming pools, parking areas, sidewalks, air conditioner systems, and private
utility services, as well as for ordinances relating to the moving and/or
demolition of buildings and the removal of refuse and/or junk.
   E.   Perform such duties as may be prescribed by any ordinance of the city,
or directed by the director of community development or the city manager. (Ord.
04-0-16, 2-3-2004)
ARTICLE F. FIRE DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 2438, 10-5-1993)
ARTICLE G. POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1.7G.1: Department Established
1.7G.2: Chief Of Police
1.7G.3: Functions Of Chief Of Police
1.7G.4: Regulations For Civilian Employees
1.7G.5: Regulations For Sworn Officers
1.7G.6: Duties Of Supervisory Personnel, Sworn And Civilian
1.7G.7: Arrest Procedures
1.7G.8: Obstructing Justice
1.7G.9: Special And Auxiliary Police
1.7G.10: Deputy Chief
1.7G.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created a Police Department for the City which shall consist of
the Chief of Police, supervisory personnel and such sworn officers, special
police and civilian employees as provided for by the Council in the Personnel
Plan and annual budget of the City. All sworn officers, including the Chief of
Police, shall be subject to the rules established by the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners of the City, the personnel policies of the City, and any
rules and regulations adopted by ordinances of the City, orders of the Chief of
Police or his designated representative, or orders of the City Manager. (1986
Code)
1.7G.2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
There is hereby established the position of Chief of Police who shall be
appointed by the City Manager as provided by law. The Chief of Police shall
have control over all employees assigned to the Department subject to the rules
established by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners and the supervision
of the City Manager. In the event of a vacancy in the office of Chief of
Police, the City Manager shall designate a qualified replacement. (1986 Code)
1.7G.3: FUNCTIONS OF CHIEF OF POLICE:
The Chief of Police shall have the following duties:
   A.   The Chief of Police shall be the chief executive officer of the Police
Department of the City. He shall seek the enforcement of all laws of the State
and the City, as well as the enforcement of all orders, rules and regulations
of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. He should devote his whole time
to the duties of his position.
   B.   The Chief of Police shall be in charge of and exercise control over all
sworn officers and civilian employees of the Police Department, subject to the
authority of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners and the City Manager.
   C.   He shall have charge and custody of all property of the Police
Department including, but not limited to, alarm systems and other communication
systems used or required for the operation of the Police Department.
   D.   He shall have the charge and custody of all evidence relating to
pending cases, and all lost, abandoned or stolen property recovered by the
City.
   E.   He shall be the keeper of the City jail and custodian of all persons
confined therein.
   F.   He shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all arrests made in
conformity with the best possible police records system. He shall also keep
records of all traffic violations or accidents and other accidents resulting in
loss, damage or injury to persons or property and shall supervise the operation
of traffic-control devices.
   G.   He shall give notice to the City Manager of all damage to City property
coming to the attention of the Police Department together with the complete
report relating thereto.
   H.   He shall notify the City Manager and the City Attorney of the violation
of City ordinances and of the filing of all complaints for warrants relating to
the violations of City ordinances insofar as the knowledge of the filing of
such complaints is had by the Police Department.
   I.   He shall ensure the preservation of peace and order at elections and
provide adequate police protection at every public assembly in the City.
   J.   He shall make an annual report to the City Manager showing the work
carried on by the Department during the preceding year in such detail as may be
required by the City Manager, together with suggestions and recommendations for
the improvement of police service.
   K.   The Chief of Police may, subject to the approval of the City Manager,
establish reasonable rules and regulations relating to routine work of the
Department consistent with the ordinances of the City and the rules and
regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. Wilful failure on
the part of any sworn or civilian employee of the Police Department to comply
with such rules and regulations shall be deemed to be a disobedience of lawful
orders of the Chief of Police.
   L.   The Chief of Police shall assign sworn officers and civilian employees
of the Police Department to such responsibilities within the Department as he
shall determine. To implement the foregoing, the Chief may designate an
administrative assistant to the Chief, designate a number of sworn officers to
work in civilian clothes under the title of detective, and to make such other
internal assignments as he may deem necessary and appropriate. No internal
appointment as either administrative assistant to the Chief, or detective or
other internal assignment shall be deemed a promotion, and no sworn officer
receiving such an assignment shall be entitled to any automatic increase in
salary. (1986 Code)
1.7G.4: REGULATIONS FOR CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES:
   A.   All civilian employees of the Police Department shall perform such
duties as may be assigned to them by the Chief of Police or by the City
Manager.
   B.   It shall be the duty of all such civilian employees to adhere to such
rules and regulations as may from time to time be established by the Chief of
Police with the approval of the City Manager. (1986 Code)
1.7G.5: REGULATIONS FOR SWORN OFFICERS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of every sworn officer of the Police Department to
conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner at all times and to avoid
the use of unnecessary force.
   B.   Each and every sworn officer of the Police Department shall devote his
whole time and attention to the business of the Department; and every sworn
officer is expressly prohibited from following any other calling, being in any
other business, or holding any other lucrative position unless approval is
first obtained from the Chief of Police and although certain hours are
allocated in respect to sworn officers for the performance of duties on
ordinary occasions, they must, nevertheless, be prepared at all times to act
immediately on notice that their services are required.
   C.   Every sworn officer shall wear a suitable badge and uniform. The badge
shall be furnished by the City and shall be the indicia of authority of all
sworn officers. The badge shall remain the property of the City and be
surrendered to the Chief of Police, together with other property of the City
which may be in his/her possession, upon his/her death, discharge or
resignation.
   D.   No sworn officer shall make a false official report or make a false
statement or gossip about a sworn officer or civilian employee of the
Department or the business of the Department to the discredit or detriment of
any such sworn officer or civilian employee of the Department. No sworn officer
shall, upon the street, in any business house, or other place, to any sworn
officer or civilian employee of the Department, or to any citizen, make any
remark in regard to or about any other sworn officer or civilian employee of
the Department, which may bring the Department or sworn officer or civilian
employee disrepute, or subject it or him to any ridicule.
   E.   Any matters which any sworn officer feels should be brought to the
attention of the Department shall be communicated directly to the Chief or the
person acting in his stead.
   F.   No sworn officer shall drink intoxicating liquor while on duty. No
sworn officer shall smoke while on duty unless otherwise provided for by the
rules and regulations of the Chief of Police.
   G.   No sworn officer shall loiter in any store or other place of business
while on duty. No sworn officer of the Department, while on duty, shall enter
any place where intoxicating liquor is sold, unless in the immediate discharge
of duty. No sworn officer shall attend theatrical or other public performances
in uniform unless detailed for such duty.
   H.   No sworn officer shall receive or accept any fee, reward or gift of any
kind from any person arrested, or from any friend in his/her behalf, while in
custody, or after his/her discharge.
   I.   No sworn officer shall communicate to others, without permission from
the Chief of Police, any information or orders which have been issued to any
person who is not a sworn officer of the Department, the City Manager or the
City Attorney's department. (1986 Code)
   J.   No sworn officer shall reside outside the corporate limits of McHenry
County, Illinois. (Ord. 2059, 8-4-1987)
1.7G.6: DUTIES OF SUPERVISORY PERSONNEL, SWORN AND CIVILIAN:
In addition to the regulations for sworn officers or civilian employees,
supervisory personnel shall perform such leadership and administrative duties
and functions as may be assigned by the Chief of Police or by the City Manager.
(1986 Code)
1.7G.7: ARREST PROCEDURES:
Every sworn officer of the Police Department is a conservator of the peace with
the power to make arrests. A sworn officer shall arrest without warrant any
person detected or seen by him/her in the commission of a felony, misdemeanor
or violation of a City ordinance, and any person whom he has reason to believe
is guilty of a felony, or who is escaping from lawful arrest or confinement.
Sworn officers of the Police Department shall have power to serve civil and
criminal warrants, writs and processes as are provided by law. No such process
shall be served by any sworn officer of the Department other than the Chief of
Police without an order from the Chief or his designated representative. (1986
Code)
1.7G.8: OBSTRUCTING JUSTICE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or assist in the escape of any
person lawfully in the custody of the Police Department or any sworn officer of
the Police Department, or to obstruct or hinder any sworn officer of the Police
Department in the performance of his/her duties or to give or make a false
official report.
No sworn officer of the Department shall recommend counsel to any prisoner in
securing counsel. No sworn officer of the Department shall retain in his/her
possession any property of the Police Department after the demand for the
surrender of such property has been made upon his/her by the Chief of Police.
No sworn officer of the Police Department found guilty of any felony or aid in
escape, extortion, oppression or lawful wrong or injustice, or conspiring with
any person against the ordinances of the City and the laws of the State shall
be retained as a sworn officer of the Department. (1986 Code)
1.7G.9: SPECIAL AND AUXILIARY POLICE:
   A.   Special Police: Special police may be appointed by the Chief of Police
upon the approval of the City Manager for such time or times as may be deemed
necessary.
   B.   Auxiliary Police: The Chief of Police, upon the approval of the City
Manager, may appoint not more than twenty one (21) auxiliary police. (1986
Code)
1.7G.10: DEPUTY CHIEF:
The position of Deputy Chief is hereby established for the Police Department of
the City. The Deputy Chief, who shall be appointed by the Chief of Police,
shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of the Chief of Police. Up to
two (2) persons may be appointed to the position of Deputy Chief. The
appointment shall be from the rank of sworn, full-time officers of the City,
but must have at least five (5) years of full-time service as a police officer
in the Police Department. The Deputy Chief shall serve at the discretion of the
Chief of Police and, if removed from the position, shall revert to the rank
held immediately prior to appointment to the Deputy Chief position. (Ord. 99-0-
55, 10-5-1999)
ARTICLE H. PARATRANSIT DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 2315, 11-19-1991)
ARTICLE I. AMBULANCE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1.7I.1: Department Established
1.7I.2: Ambulance Chief and Members
1.7I.3: Functions
1.7I.4: Records
1.7I.5: Use of Equipment
1.7I.6: Compensation
1.7I.7: Charges
1.7I.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created an Ambulance Department of the City, consisting of an
Ambulance Chief and such other members as may be provided for by the City
Council. (Ord. 1821, 12-20-83)
1.7I.2: AMBULANCE CHIEF AND MEMBERS:
   A.   The Ambulance Chief shall be appointed by the City Manager. At the
scene of any emergency, the Ambulance Chief and assistants shall rank in the
order named and the officer of the highest rank at any emergency shall take
command at the scene of such emergency. In the event of an emergency call at
the scene of a fire, the Ambulance Chief and his/her assistants shall take
preliminary orders and directions from the Fire Chief and assistants at the
scene of any fire.
   B.   The Ambulance Department shall consist of as many members as may be
determined from time to time by the City Council. The Ambulance Department may
have such organization approved by the Council and may hold meetings and engage
in social activities with the approval of the City Council. No member shall be
elected, appointed to or accepted into the Ambulance Department without the
approval of the City Council. No person shall be eligible to appointment within
the Ambulance Department who has not met the minimum requirements of the
Illinois Department of Public Health.
1.7I.3: FUNCTIONS:
The Ambulance Department shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To provide emergency medical services to emergency patients for
analytic, resuscitative, stabilizing or preventative purposes, preceding and
during transportation to hospitals.
   B.   To respond to any calls for emergency medical services for the pre-
hospital treatment or transportation of a person or persons in a condition or
situation needing immediate medical attention or in a situation where such need
is declared by emergency medical personnel or public safety official.
   C.   To operate a general ambulance service for the transportation of the
sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless from or to
hospitals, nursing homes or health systems agencies.
1.7I.4: RECORDS:
The Ambulance Chief shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all meetings and
the attendance of members, a record of all emergency calls and the attendance
of members at such calls and a record of all activities of the Department. Each
April, the Ambulance Chief shall file with the City Manager a full report of
said records and attendance and emergency calls.
The Ambulance Chief shall make such Department records as are necessary
available for the review or audit of the City Council or the City Manager, when
requested.
The Ambulance Chief shall be responsible for the preliminary preparation of the
Department annual budget.
1.7I.5: USE OF EQUIPMENT:
   A.   No person shall use any ambulance, equipment or other apparatus
belonging to the City for any private purpose other than the rendition of
emergency medical services or care, or remove the same or any part thereof from
its location on the property of the City.
   B.   No person shall wilfully or negligently break, deface, or in any manner
injure any ambulance, equipment or other apparatus belonging to the City or
remove any part of such ambulance apparatus or equipment or in any manner
interfere with the same when being used by a proper person or authority.
1.7I.6: COMPENSATION:
Each member of the Ambulance Department shall be paid in accordance with the
schedule established by the City Council.
1.7I.7: CHARGES:
The City Council may establish fees and charges for the provision of ambulance
services. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE J. PERFORMING ARTS DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1.7J.1: Department Established
1.7J.2: Director Of The Woodstock Opera House
1.7J.3: Functions Of The Director Of The Woodstock Opera House
1.7J.4: Opera House Surcharge
1.7J.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the performing arts department for the city. It shall
consist of the director of the Woodstock Opera House and all other employees as
may be appointed by the city manager as provided by the city council. (1986
Code)
1.7J.2: DIRECTOR OF THE WOODSTOCK OPERA HOUSE:
There is hereby established a position of director of the Woodstock Opera
House, who shall be appointed by the city manager, as provided by law. The
director of the opera house shall have control over all employees assigned to
this department, subject to the supervision of the city manager. In the event
of a vacancy in the position of director of the Woodstock Opera House, the city
manager shall serve as ex officio head of the department until the position is
filled by separate appointment. (1986 Code)
1.7J.3: FUNCTIONS OF THE DIRECTOR OF THE WOODSTOCK OPERA HOUSE:
The director of the Woodstock Opera House shall have the following duties:
   A.   The direction, execution and evaluation of all phases of opera house
programming.
   B.   The overseeing of the Woodstock municipal band program and the
programming of the bandstand and the springhouse in the park in the square.
   C.   The ongoing maintenance of and development of recommendations for the
long term restoration of the Woodstock Opera House.
   D.   Assisting the various boards and commissions which have direct input in
the operations of the opera house including, but not limited to, the
establishment of policy and fundraising procedures and activities.
   E.   Keeping or causing to be kept a record of all activities of the
department including the financial and attendance records. He shall make an
annual report to the city manager regarding the work carried on by the
department during the preceding year, together with suggestions and
recommendations for future improvements. (1986 Code)
1.7J.4: OPERA HOUSE SURCHARGE:
   A.   A surcharge is hereby established for the sale of any ticket to a
performance, program, etc., at the Woodstock Opera House. For purposes of this
section, the purchase of a series ticket shall be considered one ticket.
   B.   A surcharge of three dollars ($3.00) shall be applied to each ticket
sale. The surcharge shall be applicable to all productions, except youth
programs, beginning on or after May 1, 2006. Youth programs shall be exempt
from the surcharge.
   C.   All surcharge proceeds shall be deposited in the debt service fund and
utilized for the repayment of the series 2001B alternative revenue bonds, which
were issued to construct the opera house annex. (Ord. 06-0-15, 2-21-2006, eff.
5-1-2006)
ARTICLE K. DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT
SECTION:
1.7K.1: Department Established
1.7K.2: Director Of Business Development
1.7K.3: Functions Of Director Of Business Development
1.7K.1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created the Department of Business Development for the City. It
shall consist of the Director of the Department and all such other employees as
may be appointed by the City Manager and provided for in the annual
appropriation and City Budget Ordinance. (Ord. 2643, 9-3-1996)
1.7K.2: DIRECTOR OF BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT:
There is hereby created the position of Director of Business Development, who
shall be appointed by the City Manager, as provided by law. The Director of
Business Development shall have control over all employees assigned to this
Department, subject to the supervision of the City Manager. In the event of a
vacancy in the Office of Director of Business Development the City Manager
shall serve as ex-officio head of the Department until the position is filled
by separate appointment. (Ord. 2643, 9-3-1996)
1.7K.3: FUNCTIONS OF DIRECTOR OF BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT:
The Director of Business Development shall have the following duties:
   A.   To coordinate the Business Retention and Expansion Program as directed
by the City Manager, to include development of appropriate systems for
information flow, analysis and response, and to prepare periodic reports.
   B.   Provide follow-up assistance to prospective employers to encourage the
attraction of investment to Woodstock with the assistance of the City Manager.
   C.   Design and implement activities to stimulate entrepreneurial
development, business development and redevelopment.
   D.   Assist existing and prospective employers in identifying and obtaining
public and private financial assistance for business expansion/location in
Woodstock.
   E.   Develop and maintain information clearinghouse and files, including:
demographic and socioeconomic indicators, labor force information, available
commercial and industrial site/buildings, locational and market data, updates
of fact sheets and individual community profiles.
   F.   Provide written, telephone and in-person response and follow- up to
inquiries from potential and existing business prospects and the general public
of the Woodstock economy and business climate. Market cold calls to prospective
businesses.
   G.   Conduct specific research on development issues and topics as directed
by the City Manager.
   H.   Represent the City at business development-related functions and
meetings; deliver presentations and other public relations efforts to promote
the City.
   I.   Serve as lead staff person to the Woodstock Economic Development
Corporation.
   J.   Other duties as prescribed by ordinance or as directed by the City
Manager. (Ord. 2643, 9-3-1996)
ARTICLE L. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION
SECTION:
1.7L.1: Adoption Of State Statutes
1.7L.2: Department Established
1.7L.3: Hearing Officer Powers, Duties And Qualifications
1.7L.4: Code Administrator Duties
1.7L.5: Instituting Code Hearing Provisions
1.7L.6: Subpoenas And Defaults
1.7L.7: Continuances And Representation At Code Hearings
1.7L.8: Hearing Evidence
1.7L.9: Eviction And Rights Of The Defendant
1.7L.10: Defenses To Code Violations
1.7L.11: Findings, Decision And Order
1.7L.12: Administrative Review Law
1.7L.13: Judgment On Findings, Decision And Order
1.7L.14: Sanctions Applicable To The Owner And Property
1.7L.15: Administrative Adjudication Concerning Automated Traffic Law
Violations
1.7L.16: Vehicle Impoundment
1.7L.1: ADOPTION OF STATE STATUTES:
The following statutes, as from time to time amended, are adopted in their
entirety and any person charged with the violation of a municipal ordinance may
be prosecuted under and in accordance with the provisions herein: a) 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., administrative adjudications; b)
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., building code violations; c)
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, administrative adjudication of
violations of traffic regulations concerning the standing, parking or
conditions of vehicles and automated traffic law violations; d) 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.6, which authorizes the City to create and implement
an automated traffic law enforcement system; and e) 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-208.7, administrative fees and procedures for impounding vehicles
for specified violations. The adoption of these statutes shall not preclude the
City from using other methods to enforce City ordinances. (Ord. 12-O-02, 1-17-
2012; amd. Ord. 20-O-57, 8- 4-2020)
1.7L.2: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
   A.   A code hearing department is hereby established for the city as a
separate and independent agency in the municipal government. The purpose of the
code hearing department is to expedite the prosecution and correction of code
violations in the manner set forth herein. The provisions set forth in this
article may be used in the adjudication of any violations of a city ordinance
except for any offense under the Illinois vehicle code 1  or this code or
similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of
vehicles, and except for any reportable offenses under section 5/6-204 of the
Illinois vehicle code.
   B.   The code hearing department shall be comprised of the following
individuals appointed by the city manager:
      1.   A hearing officer who may also be referred to as an administrative
law judge;
      2.   The chief of police or designee;
      3.   The deputy city manager or designee;
      4.   A code administrator; and
      5.   Any person or persons deemed necessary for the efficient
administration of the code hearing department.
   C.   In no event may the hearing officer be an employee of the city. (Ord.
09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS.
1.7L.3: HEARING OFFICER POWERS, DUTIES AND QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   The powers and duties of the hearing officer include:
      1.   Hearing testimony and accepting evidence that is relevant to the
existence of the code violation;
      2.   Issuing subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony at the hearing, upon the request of the parties or their
representatives;
      3.   Preserving and authenticating the record of the hearing and all
exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
      4.   Issuing a determination, based on the evidence presented at the
hearing, of whether a code violation exists. The determination shall be in
writing and shall include a written finding of fact, decision, and order
including the fine, penalty, or action with which the defendant must comply;
and
      5.   Imposing penalties consistent with applicable code provisions and
assessing costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation, except,
however, that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to (i)
impose a penalty of incarceration, or (ii) impose a fine in excess of $50,000,
or at the option of the City, such other amount not to exceed the maximum
amount established by the Mandatory Arbitration System as prescribed by the
Rules of the Illinois Supreme Court from time to time for the 22nd Judicial
Circuit, McHenry County. The maximum monetary fine under this item (5), shall
be exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance with
the City's ordinances and shall not be applicable to cases to enforce the
collection of any tax imposed and collected by the City.
   B.   Every hearing officer shall be an attorney licensed to practice law in
the State of Illinois for at least three years and have successfully completed
a formal training program which includes the following:
      1.   Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings
which they will conduct;
      2.   Orientation to each subject area of the code violations that they
will adjudicate;
      3.   Observation of administrative hearings; and
      4.   Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence
and issuing final orders. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009; amd. Ord. 20-
O-57, 8-4-2020)
1.7L.4: CODE ADMINISTRATOR DUTIES:
The code administrator may be a city employee or an independent contractor or
agency contracted by the city to perform such duties as enumerated herein. The
code administrator is authorized, empowered and directed to:
   A.   Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of all
code violations, as may be permitted by law and directed by ordinance;
   B.   Adopt, distribute, and process all notices as may be required herein;
   C.   Operate and maintain a computerized program for the system of
administrative adjudication;
   D.   Keep accurate records of adjudication appearances and activities;
   E.   Collect monies paid as fines and/or penalties after a final
determination of liability; and
   F.   Other duties as may be necessary to efficiently administer this
article. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.5: INSTITUTING CODE HEARING PROVISIONS:
   A.   When a police officer, building inspector, code enforcement officer or
other individual authorized to issue a code violation finds that a code
violation exists, that individual shall note the violation on a multiple copy
violation notice, report and hearing notice that indicates:
      1.   The name and address of the defendant;
      2.   The type and nature of the violation including a reference to the
appropriate section of the code and potential penalties that may result;
      3.   The date and time the violation was observed;
      4.   The names of witnesses to the violation;
      5.   In the event of a building code violation, the address of the
structure or premises where the violation is observed;
      6.   The means by which the defendant may waive the right to a hearing
and pay the applicable fine for the violation;
      7.   The time and date and location of the hearing; and
      8.   Penalties which may occur if the defendant fails to appear.
   B.   For the purpose of a code violation relating to real property, the
property owner shall be prima facie responsible for a violation that occurs on
such property and subject to the penalty therefor. For violations relating to
motor vehicles, the owner or operator of said vehicle shall be prima facie
responsible for a violation that occurs.
   C.   The violation notice, report, and hearing notice shall be forwarded to
the code hearing department and a docket number shall be assigned and stamped
on all copies thereto and a hearing date shall be noted on the form. Hearings
shall be scheduled with reasonable promptness, provided that for hearings
scheduled in all non-emergency situations, if requested by the defendant, the
defendant shall have at least fifteen (15) days after service of process to
prepare for a hearing. For purposes of this subsection (C), "non-emergency
situation" means any situation that does not reasonably constitute a threat to
the public interest, safety, or welfare. If service is provided by mail, the
fifteen (15)-day period shall begin to run on the day that the notice is
deposited in the mail.
   D.   A copy of the violation notice, report, and hearing notice shall be (1)
maintained in the files of the code hearing department and shall become part of
the record of the hearing, (2) provided to the individual representing the
City, and (3) served to the Defendant. The Defendant shall be served with
process in a manner reasonably calculated to give them actual notice,
including, as appropriate, personal service of process upon a party or its
employees or agents; service by mail at a party's address; or notice that is
posted upon the property where the violation is found when the party is the
owner or manager of the property.
   Service of a building code violation shall comply with 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-4,
as amended from time to time.
   Service of a vehicular parking, standing, or compliance violation notice
shall comply with 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3(b)(3) as amended from time to time. (Ord.
09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009; amd. Ord. 20-O-57, 8-4-2020)
1.7L.6: SUBPOENAS AND DEFAULTS:
At any time prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer assigned to the case
may, at the request of either party, direct witnesses to appear and give
testimony at the hearing. If the defendant or the defendant's attorney fails to
appear on the specified hearing date, the hearing officer may find the
defendant in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence
relevant to the existence of a code violation. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-
1-2009)
1.7L.7: CONTINUANCES AND REPRESENTATION AT CODE HEARINGS:
Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. The case for the
City may be presented by an attorney designated by the City or by any other
City employee, except that the case for the City shall not be presented by an
employee of the code hearing department. The case for the defendant may be
presented by the defendant or the defendant's attorney or any other agent or
representative of the defendant. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009; amd.
Ord. 20-O-57, 8-4-2020)
1.7L.8: HEARING EVIDENCE:
At the hearing, the hearing officer shall preside, shall hear testimony and
shall accept any evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a code
violation. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings
shall not apply to hearings authorized by this article. Evidence, including
hearsay, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by
reasonably prudent person in the conduct of their affairs. Parties may be
represented by counsel, present witnesses, and cross-examine opposing
witnesses. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009; amd. Ord. 20-O-57, 8-4-2020)
1.7L.9: EVICTION AND RIGHTS OF THE DEFENDANT:
No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or
other similar proceedings shall be threatened or instituted against an occupant
of a structure or premises solely because such occupant agrees to testify or
testifies at a code violation hearing. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.10: DEFENSES TO CODE VIOLATIONS:
   A.   It shall be a defense to a code violation charged if the owner, the
owner's attorney or any other agent or representative proves to the hearing
officer's satisfaction that:
      1.   The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants
and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the structure
or premises free of such violation, the current occupants continue to cause the
violations; or
      2.   An occupant or resident of the structure or premises has refused
entry to the owner or the owner's agent to all or part of the structure or
premises for the purpose of correcting the code violation.
   B.   It shall not constitute a defense at any proceeding that a person or
entity came into compliance with the ordinance after the date of the alleged
violation, except to the limited extent as set forth in subsection 3.5B, of the
