unified development ordinance, pursuant to which penalties shall commence after
the date specified in the notice of violation. (Ord. 17-O-25, 3-7-2017)
1.7L.11: FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a
determination based on the evidence presented at the hearing as to whether or
not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be
designated as "findings, decision and order". The findings, decision and order
shall include: a) the hearing officer's finding of facts, b) a decision as to
whether a code violation exists based on the findings of fact, and c) an order
that states the sanction or dismisses the case if a violation is not proved. A
monetary sanction for a violation under the terms of this article shall not
exceed the amount authorized by statute. If a building code violation is
proved, the order may also impose the sanctions that are provided in this code
for the violation proved. A copy of the findings, decision and order shall be
served on the defendant within five (5) days after it is issued. Service shall
be in the same manner that the violation report and summons are served in
accordance with subsection 1.7L.5D of this article. Payment of any penalty or
fine and the disposition of fine money shall be in the same manner as set forth
in this code unless otherwise provided for; however, payment of such fine or
penalty shall be made no later than ten (10) days after the determination has
been made by the hearing officer. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.12: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW LAW:
The findings, decision, and order shall be subject to review in the 22nd
judicial circuit court of McHenry County, Illinois. The provisions of the
Illinois administrative review law, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et
seq., or as hereinafter amended, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall
apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the findings,
decision and order of the hearing officer under this article. Any person filing
for judicial review under the Illinois administrative review law shall be
subject to the assessment of costs for the preparation and certification of the
record of proceeding before the hearing officer. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff.
5-1-2009)
1.7L.13: JUDGMENT ON FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
   A.   Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other
sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the
failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the administrative review
law shall be a debt due and owing the city and, as such, may be collected in
accordance with applicable law.
   B.   After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the
Illinois Administrative Review Law may be sought for a final determination of a
code violation, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the
findings, decision, and order of the hearing officer may be enforced in the
same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction,
including, but not limited to, judgments for the recovery of money, and any
other orders and injunctions that are requested by the City to enforce the
order of the hearing officer to correct a code violation.
   C.   In any case in which a defendant has failed to comply with a judgment
ordering a defendant to correct a code violation or imposing any fine or other
sanction as a result of a code violation, any expenses incurred by the city to
enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney's fees, court
costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are
fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer, shall be a
debt due and owing the city and may be collected in accordance with applicable
law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a hearing officer pursuant this
section, the city shall provide notice to the defendant that states that the
defendant shall appear at a hearing before the administrative hearing officer
to determine whether the defendant has failed to comply with the judgment. The
notice shall set the date for such a hearing, which shall not be less than
seven (7) days from the date that notice is served. If notice is served by
mail, the seven (7)-day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice
was deposited in the mail.
   D.   Upon being recorded in the manner required by article XII of the
Illinois Code of Civil Procedure or by the Uniform Commercial Code, a lien
shall be imposed on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of the
defendant in the amount of any debt due and owing the City under this section.
The lien may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a
judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction.
   E.   A hearing officer may set aside any judgment entered by default and set
a new hearing date, upon a petition filed within twenty-one (21) days after the
issuance of the order of default, if the hearing officer determines that the
petitioner's failure to appear at the hearing was for good cause or at any time
if the petitioner establishes that the city did not provide proper service of
process. This section shall not be construed to limit the hearing officer from
setting aside any judgment when the petition is uncontested or by agreement of
the parties. If any judgment is set aside pursuant to this subsection, the
hearing officer shall have authority to enter an order extinguishing any lien
which has been recorded for any debt due and owing the city as a result of the
vacated default judgment. (Ord. 15-O-58, 10-6-2015; amd. Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-
2009, eff. 5-1-2009; Ord. 20-O-57. 8-4-2020)
1.7L.14: SANCTIONS APPLICABLE TO THE OWNER AND PROPERTY:
The order to correct a code violation and the sanctions imposed by the city as
the result of a finding of a code violation shall attach to the property as
well as to the owner of the property, so that a finding of a code violation
against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property
to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of property takes
ownership of the property subject to the findings, decision and order of the
hearing officer under this article. (Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.15: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION CONCERNING AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW
VIOLATIONS:
Except as otherwise provided for, title 5, chapter 5, "Automated Traffic Law
Enforcement", of this code shall be subject to the procedures of this article.
(Ord. 09-O-16, 3-3-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
1.7L.16: VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Administrative Fee: In addition to any fees charged for the towing and
storage of an impounded vehicle, the city may impose an administrative fee not
to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) related to its administrative and
processing costs associated with the investigation, arrest and detention of an
offender, or the removal, impoundment, storage and release of the vehicle. The
administrative fee shall be waived upon verifiable proof that the vehicle was
stolen at the time the vehicle was impounded. (Ord. 12-O-02, 1-17-2012)
   B.   Violations: The administrative fee may be imposed and a motor vehicle
may be impounded upon probable cause that any of the following violations have
occurred:
      1.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and
forfeited pursuant to section 36-1 of the criminal code of 2012; or
      2.   Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an
intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of
section 11-501 of the Illinois vehicle code; or
      3.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the cannabis control act; or
      4.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois controlled
substances act; or
      5.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of section 24-1, 24-1.5, or 24-3.1
of the criminal code of 1961 or the criminal code of 2012; or
      6.   Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a
motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to section 6-303 of the Illinois
vehicle code; except that vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or
impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or
due to failure to comply with emission testing; or
      7.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or
attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined
by the cannabis control act or the Illinois controlled substances act; or
      8.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's
license, in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois vehicle code, if the
period of expiration is greater than one year; or
      9.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued
a driver's license or permit, in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois
vehicle code, or operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a
driver's license or permit due to a person's age; or
      10.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a
warrant has been issued by a circuit clerk in Illinois for failing to answer
charges that the driver violated section 6-101, 6-303, or 11-501 of the
Illinois vehicle code; or
      11.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, an offense in violation of article 16 or 16A of the criminal
code of 1961 or the criminal code of 2012; or
      12.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the
attempt to commit, any other misdemeanor or felony offense in violation of the
criminal code of 1961 or the criminal code of 2012, when so provided by this
code; or
      13.   Operation or use of a motor vehicle in violation of section 11-503
of the Illinois vehicle code:
         a.   While the vehicle is part of a funeral procession; or
         b.   In a manner that interferes with a funeral procession. (Ord. 17-
O-03, 1-17-2017)
   C.   Fees Imposed And Collection: The following shall apply to any fees
imposed for administrative and processing costs pursuant to subsection B of
this section:
      1.   All administrative fees and towing and storage charges shall be
imposed on the registered owner of the motor vehicle or the agents of that
owner. The registered owner shall be the record titleholder to a motor vehicle
as registered with the Illinois secretary of state or any other applicable
governmental agency.
      2.   The fees shall be in addition to: a) any other penalties that may be
assessed by a court of law for the underlying violations; and b) any towing or
storage fees, or both, charged by the towing company.
      3.   The fees shall be uniform for all similarly situated vehicles.
      4.   The fees shall be collected by and paid to the city.
      5.   The towing or storage fees, or both, shall be collected by and paid
to the person, firm, or entity that tows and stores the impounded vehicle.
Costs for towing and storage of a motor vehicle shall be those approved by the
chief of police for all tow companies authorized to tow for the police
department.
   D.   Administrative Hearing: A hearing shall be provided pursuant to 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3(b)(4). The vehicle shall be released to
the owner of record, lessee or a lienholder of record upon payment of all
administrative fees and towing and storage fees.
   E.   Administrative Hearing Requirements:
      1.   Administrative hearings shall be conducted by a hearing officer who
is an attorney licensed to practice law in the state for a minimum of three (3)
years and who is not an officer or employee of the city. The hearing officer
shall be designated by the city manager;
      2.   The hearing officer shall have the power to administer oaths and to
secure the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of relevant
books and papers via subpoena;
      3.   The hearing shall be recorded and the technical/formal rules of
evidence shall not apply;
      4.   Individuals appearing before the hearing officer shall have the
right to be represented by counsel at their own expense;
      5.   At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the hearing officer
shall issue a written decision either sustaining or overruling the vehicle
impoundment;
      6.   If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is sustained by the hearing
officer, the administrative fee shall be imposed in accordance with Paragraph A
of this Section. Any administrative fee previously posted to secure the release
of the vehicle shall be forfeited to the city, and any outstanding fees shall
be paid prior to release of any vehicle still impounded. The fact that the
impounded vehicle may have been released prior to a hearing without the
administrative fee having been paid or that the title or interest in the
vehicle transferred to any person, firm, or entity subsequent to the impound
shall not constitute a defense to the obligation to pay the administrative fee.
      7.   All final decisions of the administrative hearing officer shall be
subject to review under the provisions of the administrative review law; and
      8.   Unless the administrative hearing officer overturns the basis for
the vehicle impoundment, no vehicle shall be released to the owner, lessee or
lienholder of record until all administrative fees and towing and storage
charges are paid.
   F.   Notice Of Impoundment: The following provisions shall be observed
concerning notice of impoundment:
      1.   Whenever a police officer has cause to believe that a motor vehicle
is subject to impoundment, the officer shall provide for the towing of the
vehicle to a facility authorized by the municipality.
      2.   At the time the vehicle is towed, the city shall notify or make a
reasonable attempt to notify the owner, lessee, or person identifying himself
or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or any person who is found to
be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense, of the fact of
the seizure, and of the vehicle owner's or lessee's right to an administrative
hearing.
      3.   The city shall provide notice that the motor vehicle will remain
impounded pending the completion of an administrative hearing, unless the owner
or lessee of the vehicle or a lienholder posts with the city a bond equal to
the administrative fee as provided by this section and pays for all towing and
storage charges.
   G.   Notice Of Hearing: The registered owner or lessee of the vehicle and
any lienholder of record shall be provided with a notice of hearing. The notice
shall:
      1.   Be served upon the owner, lessee and any lienholder of record either
by personal service or by first class mail to the interested party's address as
registered with the secretary of state;
      2.   Be served upon interested parties within ten (10) days after a
vehicle is impounded by the city; and
      3.   Contain the date, time and location of the administrative hearing.
An initial hearing shall be scheduled and convened no later than forty five
(45) days after the date of the mailing of the notice of hearing.
   H.   Failure To Retrieve Vehicle: Vehicles not retrieved from the towing or
storage facility within thirty five (35) days after the administrative officer
issues a written decision shall be deemed abandoned and disposed of in
accordance with the provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-201 et
seq., abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicles.
   I.   Enforcement: Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any
fine, penalty or administrative fee imposed under this section which remains
unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of the deadline for seeking
review under section
 1.7L.12 of this article, may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment
entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
   J.   Applicability Of Other Laws: This section is in addition to and shall
not replace or otherwise abrogate any existing state or federal laws or any
ordinance that relates to the seizure or impoundment of motor vehicles, and any
fee provided for in this section shall be in addition to any and all penalties
that may be assessed or imposed by a court for any criminal charges. This
section shall not apply: 1) if the motor vehicle used in the violation was
stolen at the time of the violation or 2) if the motor vehicle is subject to
successful forfeiture proceedings under 725 Illinois Compiled Statutes 150/1 et
seq., as amended (drug asset forfeiture procedure act); 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/36-1 et seq., as amended (seizure and forfeiture of vessels,
vehicles and aircraft); or 3) other state or federal forfeiture laws.
   K.   Administrative Review: Any owner of record, lienholder or other person
with a legal interest in the motor vehicle, shall have the right to appeal the
decision of the hearing officer to the 22nd judicial circuit court, pursuant to
the administrative review act, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq.,
as amended. Any respondent seeking review of a final decision shall be required
to reimburse the city for the costs of preparing and certifying the record of
proceedings. Failure of the respondent to reimburse the city shall be grounds
for the dismissal of a complaint for administrative review pursuant to 735
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-109. In the event the reviewing court reverses
the findings, decision and order of the administrative law judge, the city will
reimburse the respondent for the costs for preparing and certifying the record
of proceedings. Any administrative fee posted with the city to secure the
release of a motor vehicle prior to a hearing shall be held by the city until
the hearing officer issues a decision or, if there is judicial review of the
hearing officer's decision, until a reviewing court issues a final decision.
   L.   Administrative Fee Refund: A finding of "not guilty" following a trial
in the 22nd judicial circuit court for the underlying violation wherein the
motor vehicle was impounded, shall entitle the owner of record to a full and
complete refund of any administrative fee imposed under this section. However,
the owner of record must request the refund in writing and shall include in the
request a certified disposition of "not guilty" following a trial from the 22nd
circuit court clerk. An order of dismissal or a negotiated disposition on the
underlying charge(s) shall not result in a refund of the administrative fee.
(Ord. 12-O-02, 1-17-2012; amd. Ord. 23-O-45, 9-5-2023)

MISCELLANEOUS ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS

1.8.5: Use Of Public Buildings
1.8.6: Use Of City Council Chambers
1.8.1: CORPORATE SEAL:
The corporate seal of the city is as follows:
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4dab9daa3760717eed3dfba32280dfcb48722d44/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1869.png]
(1963 Code, §20.03; amd. 1986 Code)
1.8.2: CITY DATUM:
The datum for the establishment of grades in the city is established or fixed
from time to time by the council in ordinances or public improvements or
otherwise shall refer. This plane is the city datum and is established at
seventy feet (70') below the center of a crosscut in the cornerstone in the
northeast corner of the Woodstock Opera House. The crosscut is marked "city
datum" in the stone. (1963 Code, §20.07; amd. 1986 Code)
1.8.3: ANNUAL AUDIT OF ACCOUNTS:
The city council shall, no later than six (6) months after the close of each
fiscal year, cause an audit to be made of all accounts of the city by a
competent person designated by the council and authorized to act as an auditor
under the law 1 . Copies of such audit report shall be filed with the city
clerk and with the director of the state department of revenue and in such
other places as may be required by law or designated by the council. (1963
Code, §20.10)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq.
1.8.4: REIMBURSEMENT OF CITY EXPENSES:
   A.   The mayor, city council and/or the city manager may request the city's
planning consultant, engineer, attorney, any other designated consultant,
department head, or staff to review petitions, land use plans, plats and
documents pertaining to subdivision or resubdivision, zoning or rezoning and/or
annexation of land for residential purposes either within or outside the
corporate boundary of the city. Request for review shall be made in advance of
any preliminary presentation before the plan commission to allow designated
consultants, department heads or staff to be in attendance at the presentation.
   B.   Each department head, individual or firm designated to review a
proposed project shall, within seven (7) days of the request for review,
present the city council and property owner or developer with a written
estimate of time, materials, and costs involved. Such costs shall reflect
specific areas of review and standard hourly or per diem rates charged to the
city. Where unusual circumstances involve a number of unknown tasks, a cost
ceiling and standard hourly or per diem rate may be set to allow "work in
progress" review and flexibility to cover costs incurred. All activities shall
take place after preliminary presentation of the proposed project before the
plan commission and sufficient copies of all pertinent documents, land use
plan, plats and reports shall be made available for each review, to the plan
commission and city council to inform them of the status and impact of each
project. Copies of all reviews and reports shall be made available to the
developer.
   C.   The person petitioning for rezoning and/or annexation or presenting
subdivision, resubdivision, or land use plan shall be notified that the
services of the city's department heads, staff, or the planning consultant,
engineer, attorney, or other consultants are required. Such notification shall
be given to the petitioner prior to the preliminary presentation before the
plan commission or other commission, board or the corporate authority. Should
additional review be required, subsequent notice shall be given by the
consultant or department head performing the review, to the petitioner
concerning the extent, content, and estimated cost of such review and report.
(Ord. 1406, 10-18-1977)
   D.   Petitioners for rezoning and/or annexation, or presenting a
subdivision, resubdivision, or land use plan shall, hereafter, deposit with the
city clerk, a sum of money as established from time to time by the city
council, as security for the reimbursement of review expenses. Where unusual
problems or conditions are encountered which require additional review, the
corporate authority shall notify the petitioner of such conditions. Should
additional funds be required as a deposit, such notification shall be given to
the petitioner. (Ord. 1406, 10-18-1977; amd. 1986 Code)
   E.   Planning consultants, engineers, attorneys or other consultants to the
city shall submit itemized bills for services, materials and out of pocket
costs incurred in performing tasks identified in subsections A and B of this
section to the city. Standard hourly or per diem rates, normally billed to the
city, shall be charged. The city shall be reimbursed for costs paid to its
consultants from the amount on deposit, as required in subsection D of this
section. If the amount on deposit shall, for any reason, be insufficient to
fully reimburse the city for any costs and charges so paid, the deficiency
shall be billed to and collected from the owner or developer. Should city staff
be involved in designated review tasks, such services shall be reimbursed to
the city in a similar manner, determined by multiplying the number of hours
spent on the review by the average hourly cost of the city for salary,
materials, overhead, fringe benefits and expenses.
   F.   Normal review procedures will require from thirty (30) to forty five
(45) days depending upon problems encountered. During the review period, the
petitioner may request and shall receive a statement on costs incurred for
review activities to date. As services are completed, statements shall be
presented to the city so that compensation may be made following normal
administrative practices of the corporate authority.
   G.   Funds deposited with the city clerk which are not required to reimburse
the planning consultant, engineer, attorney or other designated consultant
shall be returned to the petitioner; provided, that all services requested have
been completed and all bills have been paid in full. (Ord. 1406, 10-18-1977)
1.8.5: USE OF PUBLIC BUILDINGS:
   A.   Application for the use of any city building other than a park building
shall be in writing addressed to the city clerk. The application shall state
the name and address of the applicant, the use for which the building is
desired and the names of at least two (2) references.
   B.   The city manager, if satisfied that the applicant is of good character
and reputation and the purpose for which the building is desired is worthy,
lawful and of a civic nature, shall report the result of his investigation to
the council. In case of rental, the recommendation shall state the amount of
rental and the financial responsibility of the applicant. No lease shall be
entered into without the consent and approval of the council.
   C.   If the application is approved by the council, the city clerk shall
issue the permit, but in the case of a lease, the lease itself shall constitute
the permit. (1963 Code, §20.11)
1.8.6: USE OF CITY COUNCIL CHAMBERS:
   A.   The general management and direction of the city council chambers and
its use shall be vested in the city manager.
   B.   Application for the use of the city council chambers by any person
shall be submitted, in writing, on forms provided by the city not less than
seven (7) days prior to the date of the proposed use. The application shall be
submitted in writing over the signature of a duly authorized representative of
the group or organization and shall be submitted on the forms provided by the
city. All applications shall be submitted in duplicate. Within seventy two (72)
hours after the submission of the application in proper form, the city manager
shall endorse the original application and the copy either "approved" or
"rejected" and return a copy thereof to the applicant with any appropriate
remarks.
      1.   In the event there is a question in the mind of the city manager as
to the propriety of the use or the propriety of the person as to its
eligibility for use, the city manager shall so advise the applicant and the
question of the issuance of the application shall then be placed upon the next
available agenda of the city council for action and approval.
      2.   The city manager shall, upon submitting an application for the use
of the city council chambers to the city council, circulate copies of the
application to each member of the city council with their regular agenda lists
together with any additional remarks he may have regarding the reasons that the
application is on the council's agenda, the basis of his questions and his
general recommendations as to the disposition of the application. Copies of his
remarks shall be distributed to the applicant as well.
      3.   Upon the submission to the city council by the city manager of a
question regarding the application for use of the city council chambers, the
council shall either approve or reject the application upon the face of the
application and the manager's remarks. The council may, upon motion of any
councilman, suspend its rules and the operation of these rules and permit
debate on the issue of the application or barring the applicant. The submission
of the application to the council shall not automatically entitle any person to
debate the question before the council.
   C.   The city manager shall keep a record or calendar of the dates for the
use of the city council chambers and shall keep such dates available for public
inspection.
   D.   The permission to use the city council chambers, given by the city
manager to any person shall be secondary and subject to any and all regular,
special or adjourned meetings of the city council and any regular, adjourned or
special meetings of any of the boards, committees or commissions whose
memberships are appointed by either the mayor with the advice and consent of
the city council or by the city manager. In the event that the meeting date of
the city council or any of its boards, commissions or committees, as heretofore
described, shall fall upon the date for which permission has been given for use
of the city council chambers of any person, the setting of such date for a
meeting by the city council or any of the boards, committees or commissions of
the city shall be deemed an automatic cancellation of such permission. It shall
be the duty of the applicant for use of the city council chambers, to keep
itself advised of the availability of the city council chambers,
notwithstanding the issuance of any permit or the allowance of any application.
   E.   All applications for the use of the city council chambers shall be
accompanied by a damage deposit of fifty dollars ($50.00). The balance of the
damage deposit shall be refunded to the person after deducting any expenses
incurred by the city for cleanup, repair or restoration of the city council
chambers after such use by any person hereafter allowed to use the chambers.
(Ord. 1085, 5-7-1974)
CHAPTER 9
CITY OWNED REAL ESTATE
SECTION:
1.9.1: Sale Of City Owned Real Estate
1.9.2: Agreements For Use Of City-Owned Real Estate And Property (Rep. by Ord.
25-O-26, 4-15-2025)
1.9.1: SALE OF CITY OWNED REAL ESTATE:
   A.   The city council may, by resolution or ordinance, authorize the
conveyance of real estate if it finds the real estate is no longer necessary,
appropriate, required for the use of, profitable to, or in the best interests
of the city. At such time the city council may also specify the specific use or
purpose to which they would like to see the real estate put.
   B.   Following such resolution or ordinance, but prior to a subsequent
council vote on any offer for the real estate, the following notice shall be
provided:
      1.   Notice of the proposal to sell shall be published one time in a
daily or weekly paper published in the city, at least thirty (30) days prior to
the passage of any resolution or ordinance approving the conveyance of real
estate. Such notice shall:
         a.   Solicit bids;
         b.   Contain an accurate description of the property which may include
a common street address and need not include a full metes and bounds legal
description;
         c.   State the specific use or purpose to which the city council would
like to see the real estate put, if any;
         d.   State the date on which bids will be opened by the city
administration.
      2.   Notice of the proposal to sell shall also be mailed, by certified
mail, return receipt requested, to the owners of all property immediately
abutting the real estate proposed for sale, but not for property separated from
the real estate proposed for sale by any public right of way or other
intervening barrier between the property lines.
      3.   The city manager or his designee may provide notice to such other
third parties regarding the proposed real estate sale as, in the city manager's
discretion, would be in the best interest of the city to be invited to bid on
the real estate.
      4.   The city manager or his designee is authorized to open the bids on
the date specified in the notice and may formulate a recommendation for the
city council's consideration. This recommendation may be provided to the city
council in advance of the meeting at which the bids will be considered. In
formulating such a recommendation, if the city manager has not already done so,
the city manager or his designee may, but is not required to, obtain one or
more appraisals of the real estate or may otherwise consult with third parties
regarding the value or best use of the real estate.
   C.   Thereafter, the city council may accept the highest qualified bid or
any other bid determined to be in the best interest of the city or may reject
any and all bids by a majority vote of the members of the city council.
   D.   The city council may sell, purchase, accept or otherwise transfer real
estate from or to another unit of government in accordance with the Illinois
local government property transfer act 1  as presently exists or as may be
subsequently amended. (Ord. 17-O-21, 3-7-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 605/1 et seq.
1.9.2: AGREEMENTS FOR USE OF CITY-OWNED REAL ESTATE AND PROPERTY:
(Rep. by Ord. 25-O-26, 4-15-2025)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
2.1.1: Boards And Commissions Established
2.1.2: General Membership, Terms, Officers
2.1.3: General Meetings
2.1.4: General Powers And Duties
2.1.5: General Provisions Established
2.1.1: BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS ESTABLISHED:
To provide for citizen participation in local municipal governance and advise
the city council, who serve as the sole municipal officers and corporate
authorities, there are established within the city of Woodstock the following
named boards and commissions:
   Arts Commission
   Board of building construction
   Board of police commissioners
   Board of library trustees
   Cultural and social awareness commission
   Electrical commission
   Environmental commission
   Historic preservation commission
   Opera house advisory commission
   Parks and recreation commission
   Plan commission
   Police pension board
   Zoning board of appeals
(Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012; amd. Ord. 21-O-23, 4-6-2021; Ord. 22-O-25, 4-19-2022;
Ord. 25-O-28, 5-6-2025)
2.1.2: GENERAL MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   The members of all established boards and commissions shall be
appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.
   B.   All members, including the chair, of each established board and
commission shall be voting members of the respective board or commission.
   C.   The specific number of members for each established board and
commission shall be as prescribed by Illinois Compiled Statutes or the chapters
of this title.
   D.   The specific terms of members for each established board and commission
shall be as prescribed by Illinois Compiled Statutes or the chapters of this
title.
   E.   The terms of members of all established boards and commissions shall
expire on April 30 in the year of expiration or until such time as a successor
is appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.
   F.   The members of all established boards and commissions may succeed
themselves.
   G.   The members of all established boards and commissions shall serve
without compensation.
   H.   The members of all established boards and commissions may be revoked by
a majority vote of the city council or by the mayor with the advice and consent
of the city council.
   I.   The members of all established boards and commissions shall not be in
violation of any provisions of this code and shall not have any outstanding or
delinquent debt owed to the city. The presence of such a violation or debt may
be grounds for revocation.
   J.   All vacancies on established boards and commissions, whether created by
death, resignation, or removal, shall be filled through appointment by the
mayor with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the
unexpired portion of the vacated term.
   K.   All members of boards and commissions are subject to all of the city's
ethics rules including the gift ban act, the rules regarding prohibited
political activities and any other prohibitions relating to contracting with
the city.
   L.   Any member of an established board or commission having a personal or
professional pecuniary interest in an application before the body in public
hearing status shall recuse and disengage from any participation as a member.
   M.   The chair of each established board and commission shall be appointed
by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council unless otherwise
established by Illinois Compiled Statutes and thereby identified in the
respective chapter of this title.
   N.   The chair of each established board and commission may be revoked at
the sole discretion of the mayor unless otherwise established by Illinois
Compiled Statutes.
   O.   A vice chair shall be elected by the appointed members of each
established board and commission from among its respective membership at the
first meeting of each year, and herein defined as the first meeting after the
beginning of each fiscal year.
   P.   A secretary responsible for maintaining minutes and records of all
regular and special meetings of each established board and commission shall be
designated as prescribed in the chapters of this title. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-
2008)
2.1.3: GENERAL MEETINGS:
   A.   Each established board and commission shall hold regular meetings as
prescribed in the chapters of this title and in no case, less than once each
year.
   B.   Special meetings of each established board and commission may be called
if deemed necessary by the chair or a majority of the members of the respective
board or commission.
   C.   For the purposes of conducting business, the quorum for each
established board and commission shall be a simple majority of the board
members or commissioners currently appointed and serving.
   D.   Attendance or absence of board members or commissioners shall be
recorded in the minutes of every regular and special meeting of every
established board and commission. The absence of any appointed member from
three (3) consecutive meetings shall be cause for removal by the mayor.
   E.   Approved minutes of all regular and special meetings of each
established board and commission shall be provided to the city council in a
timely fashion.
   F.   All regular and special meetings of each established board and
commission shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open meetings act.
   G.   Except in cases of emergencies, all notices for meetings, including
those for special, nonemergency meetings, shall be provided at least forty
eight (48) hours prior to the time set for the meeting and in the manner
required by the open meetings act. It shall be the responsibility of the city
manager or designee to provide such notice. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
   H.   The public shall be permitted to comment before each board in the same
manner as provided in section
1.5.8 of this code except that for any public hearings, the public shall have
the right to participate in the hearing in the manner established by the chair
of that board. (Ord. 15-O-20, 4-7-2015)
2.1.4: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The members of the established boards and commissions in their capacity
as board members and commissioners shall not be recognized as officers of the
city. The city council serves as the sole municipal officers and corporate
authorities.
   B.   The established boards and commissions are vested with the general
powers and duties prescribed by the chapters of this title on behalf of the
city of Woodstock.
   C.   Additional powers and duties may be set forth from time to time as
provided and directed by the city council.
   D.   Additional powers and duties specified in the Illinois Compiled
Statutes/Illinois municipal code shall also apply for each board and
commission.
   E.   In conducting city business, the members of all established boards and
commissions shall comport themselves in an ethical, professional manner.
   F.   Regulations or guidelines for the conduct of meetings, hearings, or
special projects may be developed by each of the established boards and
commissions and, after approval by the city council, shall be in full force and
effect upon filing with the city clerk. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.1.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS ESTABLISHED:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to all established
boards and commissions in furtherance of the prescribed duties set forth by
Illinois Compiled Statutes or the chapters of this title.
   B.   Neither board or commission nor any member of a board or commission
shall give direction to any member of the city staff unless otherwise
established by Illinois Compiled Statutes and thereby identified in the
respective chapter of this title.
   C.   All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager or
the designated agent of the city as specifically set forth in the chapters of
this title.
   D.   Necessary assistants, consultants, or advisors may be employed at the
discretion of the city manager or as otherwise provided by the city council.
   E.   All recommendations of an established board or commission shall be
referred to the city council for consideration and implementation unless
otherwise prescribed by Illinois Compiled Statutes.
   F.   Neither board or commission nor any member of a board or commission
shall have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any
purchase or contract, that directly or indirectly results in a financial
liability or lien against the city, without the express prior approval of the
mayor and city council unless otherwise established by Illinois Compiled
Statutes and thereby identified in the respective chapter of this title.
   G.   In the event the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes/Illinois
municipal code and the provisions of this title conflict, the Illinois Compiled
Statutes/Illinois municipal code shall apply. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
CHAPTER 2
BOARD OF BUILDING CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
2.2.1: Board Established
2.2.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.2.3: Meetings
2.2.4: Powers And Duties
2.2.5: General Provisions
2.2.1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
To provide for the safety and welfare of residents through safe, quality
building construction and building code enforcement, the board of building
construction is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.2.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Board Membership: The board shall consist of four (4) members plus an
appointed chair. One member shall be appointed as the representative of the
Woodstock fire/rescue district and at least three (3) members shall reside
within the corporate boundaries of the city of Woodstock.
Voting members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of
providing cross sector representation from the building trades. Therefore,
consideration should be given to the contractor/construction, electrical and
plumbing sectors.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council.
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   C.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the board and to represent the board at city
council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice Chair: The board shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The appointed staff liaison shall serve as secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.2.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The board shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the
chair or a majority of the board.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.2.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The board shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the Woodstock
city council and shall comply with all applicable provisions of Illinois state
statutes and this code.
   B.   Specific duties of the board shall be limited to providing for the
safety and welfare of residents through safe, quality building construction and
building code enforcement in the city of Woodstock by:
      1.   Assisting the building and zoning officers of the city in
interpreting the specific ordinances for which they are responsible.
      2.   Recommending to the city council amendments to building codes and
relevant city ordinances as may, from time to time, be appropriate.
      3.   Considering applications for and the results of new materials and
methods testing. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
      4.   Preparing and disseminating educational materials regarding city
building codes and inspection procedures. The board shall not, however, have
the authority to consider appeals of orders, decisions, or determinations
regarding noncompliance with the city's building codes, the issuance of
citations for building code violations, or the adjudication of such violations.
      5.   Fostering communication between the public and city regarding
ongoing activities of the board.
      6.   Arranging and conducting any form of publicity relative to its
activities for the general purpose of increasing public understanding. (Ord.
08-0-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
2.2.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of
building construction in order to assist the board with its various duties. All
requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager for appropriate
response by the city. Neither the board nor any of its members shall give
direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the board
shall be referred to the city council for consideration and implementation by
the city.
   B.   The board shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
CHAPTER 3
BOARD OF LIBRARY TRUSTEES
SECTION:
2.3.1: Board Established
2.3.2: Membership And Terms
2.3.3: Meetings
2.3.4: Powers And Duties
2.3.5: General Provisions
2.3.6: Bond Requirements
2.3.1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
   A.   To provide and maintain a public library and associated services for
the benefit of residents, a Board of Trustees of the Woodstock Public Library
is hereby established in the City.
   B.   For purposes of reference and financial accounting within the
Municipality, the Board of Trustees of the Woodstock Public Library shall also
be known as, and shall serve as one in the same as, the Board of Library
Trustees.
   C.   The board shall have the following specific responsibilities:
      1.   To adopt and revise policies so that proper courses of action may be
taken;
      2.   To see that the library has the necessary funds for proper
administration of the library; and
      3.   To see that the public understands the goals and objectives of the
library. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.3.2: MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS:
   A.   Board Membership: The Board of Library Trustees of the Woodstock Public
Library, aka, Board of Library Trustees, shall consist of nine (9) members, all
of whom shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the City of Woodstock,
shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City
Council, and chosen with reference to their fitness for such office. No more
than one member of the City Council shall be at any one time a member of the
board.
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members shall be for three
(3) years.
   C.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the Mayor
with the advice and consent of the City Council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Officers: The officers of the board shall be a President, Vice
President, Secretary and Treasurer who shall all be elected at the first
regular meeting of the board following the annual appointment of Trustees.
   E.   President: It shall be the duty of the President to preside at all
meetings of the board, appoint all committees, act as ex officio member of all
committees, and represent the board at City Council meetings as from time to
time may be necessary.
   F.   Vice President: It shall be the duty of the Vice President to perform
the duties of the President as from time to time may be necessary in the
absence of the President.
   G.   Secretary: It shall be the duty of the Secretary to notify each member
of the board of all regular and special meetings, including the statement of
purpose of each meeting; to maintain minutes and records of regular and special
meetings; and regularly provide such records to the City Council.
   H.   Treasurer: It shall be the duty of the Treasurer to report on the
status of funds received by the library and to review their proper
disbursement. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.3.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   Meetings of the board shall be held no less than monthly on the second
Thursday of each calendar month in the library or at such time and place as the
board may determine. (Ord. 19-O-07, 1-15-2019)
   B.   Additional special meetings may be called if deemed necessary by the
President, Secretary or any two (2) members of the board, provided that notice
of the meeting is provided to all members of the board at least forty eight
(48) hours prior to the time set for the meeting. The notice of a special
meeting shall state the purpose of the meeting and no business other than that
stated in the notice shall be transacted.
   C.   The board shall cause to have posted said notice of a special meeting
at all public library facilities maintained by the board and not less than one
other public place within the City at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the
time set for the special meeting.
   D.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois Open
Meetings Act. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.3.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Board of Library Trustees of the Woodstock Public Library, aka, Board of
Library Trustees, shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own
guidance and for the government of the library as may be expedient, not
inconsistent with this chapter.
   B.   To have exclusive control of the expenditure of all monies collected
for the library and deposited to the credit of the Library Fund.
   C.   To have the exclusive control of the construction of any library
building and of the supervision, care, and custody of the grounds, rooms or
buildings constructed, leased or set apart for that purpose.
   D.   To purchase or lease real or personal property, and to construct an
appropriate building or buildings for the use of the library, using, at the
board's option, contracts providing for all or part of the consideration to be
paid through installments at stated intervals during a certain period not to
exceed twenty (20) years with interest at any lawful rate for municipal
corporations in the State of Illinois on the unpaid balance or such legally
applicable rate in effect at the time such contract is made, whichever is
higher, except that contracts which call for installment purchases of real
estate shall provide for not more than seventy five percent (75%) of the total
consideration to be repaid by installments.
   E.   To remodel or reconstruct a building erected or purchased by the board
when such building is not adapted to its purposes or needs.
   F.   To sell or otherwise dispose of real or personal property that it no
longer deems necessary or useful for library purposes and to lease to others
any real property not immediately useful but for which plans for ultimate use
have been or will be adopted but the city council shall have the first right to
purchase or lease such property.
   G.   To appoint and to fix the compensation of a qualified librarian who
shall have the authority to hire such other employees as may be necessary, to
fix their compensation, to remove such appointees, subject to the approval of
the board and in accordance to Illinois state statutes, and to retain counsel
and professional consultants as needed.
   H.   To contract with any library association, school board, or any city,
village, incorporated town, township, county or district library board in the
state for furnishing or receiving library services including, but not limited
to, contracts for such library services as participants in any library system
formed pursuant to law and as participants in interstate library compacts, and
to contract to supply library services and for the expenditure of any federal
or state funds made available to any county, municipality, township or the
state of Illinois for library purposes.
   I.   To join with the board or boards of any one or more libraries of any
city, incorporated town, village, township, county, or district in maintaining
libraries, or for the maintenance of a common library for such cities,
incorporated towns, villages, townships, county or districts upon such terms as
may be agreed upon by and between the boards.
   J.   To enter into contracts and to take title to any property acquired by
it for library purposes by the name and style of the board of library trustees
of the city of Woodstock, McHenry County, Illinois, and by that name to sue and
be sued.
   K.   To exclude from the use of the library any person who unlawfully
violates the rules prescribed by the board.
   L.   To extend the privileges and use of the library to persons residing
outside the city, incorporated town, village or township upon such terms and
conditions as the board may from time to time by its regulations prescribe and
to impose a nonresident fee for such privileges and uses comparable to the cost
to residents of such entity.
   M.   To exercise the power of eminent domain subject to the prior approval
of the city council as provided by law.
   N.   To join the public library as a member in the Illinois Library
Association and the American Library Association, nonprofit, nonpolitical
associations as designed by the federal internal revenue service, having the
purpose of library development and librarianship; to provide for the payment of
annual membership dues, fees and assessments and act by, through and in the
name of such instrumentality by providing and disseminating information and
research services, employing personnel and doing any and all other acts for the
purpose of improving library development.
   O.   To invest funds pursuant to Illinois state statutes.
   P.   To lease from any public building commission created pursuant to the
provisions of the public building commission act, any real or personal property
for library purposes for a period of time not to exceed twenty (20) years.
   Q.   To pay for the use of such leased property in accordance with the terms
of the lease and with the provisions of the public building commission act as
now or hereafter amended.
   R.   To enter into such a lease without making a previous appropriation for
the expense thereby incurred according to the limitations provided by law.
   S.   To pay all or part of the cost of maintaining and owning any property
leased from the public building commission for the term or within the period
provided by law. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.3.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of
trustees of the Woodstock public library, a.k.a., board of library trustees, in
order to assist the board with its various duties. All requests for assistance
are to be conveyed to the director of the library for appropriate response by
the city. Neither the board nor any of its members shall give direction to any
member of the city staff. Unless otherwise set forth herein or established by
Illinois state statutes, all recommendations of the board shall be referred to
the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
   B.   Except as specifically stated in this chapter, the board shall not have
the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any purchase or
contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien
against the city, without the express prior approval of the mayor and city
council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.3.6: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Pursuant to the City's home rule authority, the library shall not be required
to provide a separate surety bond or insurance coverage amounts regarding the
safe keeping and payment of library funds received (as otherwise required
pursuant to 75 ILCS 5/4-9), provided that the City Manager concludes that the
City maintains reasonable insurance coverage to protect the library against
potential financial loss as a result of a financial crime by an employee. (Ord.
19-O-60, 7-16-2019)
CHAPTER 4
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2.4.1: Board Established
2.4.2: Membership And Terms
2.4.3: Meetings
2.4.4: Powers And Duties
2.4.5: General Provisions
2.4.1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
To provide for the safety and protection of residents through the employment of
highly qualified and professional sworn officers of the police department, and
in accordance with Illinois state statutes, the board of police commissioners
is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 21-O-23,
4-6-2021)
2.4.2: MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS:
   A.   Board Membership: The board of police commissioners shall consist of
three (3) members, including an appointed chair, all of which shall reside
within the corporate boundaries of the city of Woodstock. All members,
including the chair, shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council.
   B.   Officers: As an exception to subsection
 2.1.4A of this title, the board of police commissioners shall be considered
officers of the city and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond in such amount
as from time to time may be required by the city council.
   C.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   D.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   E.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   F.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   G.   Secretary: The administrative assistant to the chief of police or
designee shall serve as secretary and maintain minutes and records of regular
and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the city council.
(Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 21-O-23, 4-6-2021)
2.4.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The board shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the
chair or a majority of the board.
   B.   Notice of a board meeting shall be given in writing to each member of
the board at least twenty four (24) hours prior to the time set for the
meeting. Additionally, notice of the meeting shall be posted in a conspicuous
place in the police department not less than twenty four (24) hours prior to
any board meeting. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
2.4.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of police commissioners shall have the following powers and duties
pertaining to sworn members of the police department:
   A.   To make and promulgate rules and regulations for the conduct of
examinations for original appointments, conduct of examinations for promotions,
and conduct of hearings on charges brought against a member of the police
department.
   B.   To conduct examinations for original appointments and promotions.
   C.   To make all original appointments to the police department and
appointments to promotions within the police department pursuant to
examinations.
   D.   To conduct hearings on charges brought against any member of the police
department.
   E.   Such other and further powers as may from time to time be authorized by
the Illinois general assembly.
   F.   Exception For Certified Police Officer Entry Candidates:
Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section regarding original
appointments made by the Board of Police Commissioners, the City Manager may
appoint any applicant to the Police Department who has at least two (2) years
previous full-time experience as a police officer (known as a Certified Police
Officer Entry Candidate), in coordination with the City's Department of Human
Resources and the Chief of Police. Such appointment shall be instead of any
other applicant listed on the eligibility list of qualified candidates for
initial entry or otherwise considered by the Board of Police Commissioners.
(Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 19-O-83, 10-15-2019; Ord. 21-O-23, 4-6-
2021)
2.4.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of police
commissioners in order to assist the board with its various duties. All
requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the chief of police for
appropriate response by the city. Neither the board nor any of its members
shall give direction to any member of the city staff. Unless otherwise set
forth herein or established by Illinois state statutes, all recommendations of
the board shall be referred to the city council for consideration and
implementation by the city.
   B.   The board shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 21-
O-23, 4-6-2021)
CHAPTER 5
CULTURAL AND SOCIAL AWARENESS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.5.1: Commission Established
2.5.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.5.3: Meetings
2.5.4: Powers And Duties
2.5.5: General Provisions
2.5.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To further the goals of eliminating prejudice and discrimination, enhancing
awareness of the benefits of a culturally diverse community, and awareness of
current social issues within a vital, growing community, a Cultural and Social
Awareness Commission is hereby established in the City. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-
2012)
2.5.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of four (4) members
plus an appointed Chair. At least three (3) members shall reside within the
corporate boundaries of the City of Woodstock. All members and the Chair shall
be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City Council.
      This advisory commission promotes mutual understanding and respect and
furthers the goals of eliminating prejudice and discrimination, enhancing
awareness of the benefits of a culturally diverse community, and awareness of
current social issues within a vital, growing community. This Commission meets
quarterly Woodstock City Hall.
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
Chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   C.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the Mayor
with the advice and consent of the City Council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The Chair shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the City Council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
Chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at City Council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a Vice Chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The City Clerk or designee shall serve as Secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the City Council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012; amd. Ord.
17-O-47, 5-16-2017; Ord. 24-O-37, 7-16-2024)
2.5.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The commission shall meet no less than quarterly in January, April,
July and October.
Additional meetings may be called if deemed necessary by the Chair or a
majority of the commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois Open
Meetings Act. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.5.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the
Woodstock City Council and shall comply with all applicable provisions of
Illinois State Statutes and this Code.
   B.   The commission shall serve to encourage and ensure equality of
opportunity for all people of Woodstock, regardless of race, color, national
origin, religion, sex, disability, age, marital status or sexual orientation
and to promote awareness of current social issues affecting the well being of
the community and its residents. Social issues may include, but shall not be
limited to, issues of underage consumption of alcohol, the abuse of alcohol and
other drugs, synthetic drugs, safe driving and good neighbor initiatives.
   C.   Specific duties of the commission shall be limited to promoting
cultural diversity education, awareness of current social issues, and
associated outreach, recognition and celebration in the City of Woodstock
through:
      1.   Preparation and dissemination of promotional and educational
materials regarding the City, its services, programs and opportunities.
      2.   Preparation and dissemination of promotional and educational
materials regarding the impact of diverse cultural contributions and current
social issues to the richness and well being of the community.
      3.   Developing and executing a plan of action for fostering
communication with and encouraging participation by residents of all segments
of the community. The plan may include, but shall not be limited to, an active
Sister City Program and New Americans' Initiative, as well as joint dialogue
and programming with Woodstock Community Unit School District 200 and other
agencies and organizations in McHenry County and broader community.
      4.   Serving as a resource for institutions and organizations concerned
with social awareness, cultural diversity and equality.
      5.   Establishing and executing ongoing recognition programs to foster
and enhance individual, organizational, public and private efforts to eliminate
prejudice and discrimination and promote diversity and social awareness.
      6.   Establishing and executing ongoing programs designed to celebrate
diversity and its unique and positive impact on the fabric of the community.
      7.   Preparing and submitting an annual report of its activities to the
City Council.
      8.   Fostering communication between the public and City regarding its
ongoing activities.
      9.   Arranging and conducting any form of publicity relative to its
activities for the general purpose of increasing public understanding.
   D.   The commission shall not debate, participate or engage in the provision
of social services as such services distinctly do not fall under the purview of
this municipal government. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.5.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the cultural and
social awareness commission in order to assist the commission with its various
duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager for
appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members
shall give direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of
the commission shall be referred to the city council for consideration and
implementation by the city.
   B.   The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
CHAPTER 6
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. 25-O-28, 5-6-2025)
CHAPTER 7
ELECTRICAL COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.7.1: Commission Established
2.7.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.7.3: Meetings
2.7.4: Powers And Duties
2.7.5: General Provisions
2.7.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To provide for the safety and welfare of residents through safe, quality
electrical installation and conveyance and code enforcement, the electrical
commission is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.7.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Commission Membership: The electrical commission shall consist of three
(3) members plus an appointed chair. The chief electrical inspector shall be
one of the members and at least two (2) of the members shall reside within the
corporate boundaries of the city of Woodstock.
Members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of providing
cross representation from the associated trades. Therefore, consideration
should be given to the inclusion of a professional electrical engineer, an
electrical contractor, a journeyman electrician, an electrical supplier, and a
representative of the Woodstock fire/rescue district.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   C.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The appointed staff liaison shall serve as secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.7.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The electrical commission shall meet from time to time as may be
determined by the chair or a majority of the commission.
   B.   The chief electrical inspector or designee shall attend all meetings of
the commission. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.7.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the
Woodstock city council and shall comply with all applicable provisions of
Illinois state statutes and this code.
   B.   Specific duties of the commission shall be limited to providing for the
safety and welfare of residents through safe, quality electrical installation
and conveyance and code enforcement in the city of Woodstock by:
      1.   Assisting the chief electrical inspector of the city in interpreting
the specific ordinances for which they are responsible.
      2.   Recommending to the city council safe and practical standards and
specifications for the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment
in the city designed to meet the necessities and conditions of the
municipality. Such standards and specifications shall not be effective until
adopted as an ordinance by the city council.
      3.   Recommending reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance
of permits and fees to be paid. Such rules, regulations and fees shall not be
effective until adopted as an ordinance by the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-
4-2008)
      4.   Preparing and disseminating educational materials regarding city
electrical standards and inspection procedures. The commission shall not,
however, have the authority to consider appeals of orders, decisions, or
determinations regarding noncompliance with the city's electrical codes and
standards, the issuance of citations for violations of said electrical codes
and standards, or the adjudication of such violations.
      5.   Fostering communication between the public and city regarding its
ongoing activities.
      6.   Arranging and conducting any form of publicity relative to its
activities for the general purpose of increasing public understanding. (Ord.
08-O-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 09-O-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
2.7.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the electrical
commission in order to assist the commission with its various duties. All
requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager for appropriate
response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members shall give
direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the
commission shall be referred to the city council for consideration and
implementation by the city.
   B.   The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
CHAPTER 8
ENVIRONMENTAL COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.8.1: Commission Established
2.8.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.8.3: Meetings
2.8.4: Powers And Duties
2.8.5: General Provisions
2.8.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
The environmental commission is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-O-68,
11-4-2008)
2.8.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of four (4) members
plus an appointed chair. All members shall be residents of McHenry County. Two
(2) members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council and the remainder shall include one representative
selected by and from each of the following community based constituent groups:
McHenry County Defenders
Land Conservancy Of McHenry County
Of the two (2) members and the chair appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council, none may be members of the governing boards of the
above identified constituent groups. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   C.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the appointing
authority, but only for the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The city clerk or designee shall serve as secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.8.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the
chair or a majority of the commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.8.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the Woodstock city
council and shall comply with all applicable provisions of Illinois state
statutes and this code. Specific duties of the commission shall be limited to:
   A.   Prepare and recommend to the city council an environmental plan,
looking to the present and future development and growth of the city. Such plan
should include and identify, in conformance with the comprehensive plan of the
city of Woodstock, open spaces, including municipal parks and identified
conservation areas, wetlands and water recharge areas, and forests.
   B.   Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such
changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the council or the
environmental commission, but not less often than once every five (5) years.
   C.   Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time,
recommendations for specific improvements, additions or deletions to the plan.
   D.   Provide input and advice to the city council regarding contracts
between the city and conservation management organizations and associated
management plans.
   E.   Provide input and advice to the city council on issues referred to the
commission by specific action of the city council and associated with specific
USEPA or IEPA monitoring or oversight projects.
   F.   Provide input and advice to the city council on issues referred to the
commission by specific action of the city council on topics such as wetland
remediation, groundwater regeneration and quality, the municipal use of
insecticides for control of mosquitoes and other insect pests, tree inventories
and maintenance.
   G.   Foster communication between the public and city regarding ongoing
environmental protection and oversight efforts.
   H.   Arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities
for the general purpose of increasing public understanding. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-
4-2008)
2.8.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the environmental
commission in order to assist the commission with its various duties. All
requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager for appropriate
response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members shall give
direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the
commission shall be referred to the city council for consideration and
implementation by the city.
   B.   The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
CHAPTER 9
HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.9.1: Commission Established
2.9.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.9.3: Meetings
2.9.4: Powers And Duties
2.9.5: Applications Affecting Landmark Or Historic Preservation District Status
2.9.6: Appeal Process
2.9.7: General Provisions
2.9.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To promote the preservation of historically significant buildings and
structures within the municipality and pursue the objectives and procedures
contained in this code, the historic preservation commission is hereby
established in the city. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.9.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of four (4) members
plus an appointed chair. At least three (3) members shall live within the
corporate boundaries of the city of Woodstock.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council.
All members shall be selected on the basis of their demonstrated interest,
competence or knowledge of historic preservation. Other criteria for selection
