may include vocation, employment, community interests, artistic skill, or
special training or knowledge in the development of the city.
Further, members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of
providing cross sector representation from within the community. Therefore,
reasonable consideration should be given to professionals in the disciplines of
history, architectural history, architecture planning, archaeology, historic
preservation or related field; property or business owners within the historic
downtown area; real estate professionals; and representatives from the fields
of engineering and construction. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   C.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The city clerk or designee shall serve as secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.9.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the
chair or a majority of the commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.9.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The historic preservation commission shall have the following powers and
duties:
   A.   Work to establish greater public interest and participation in historic
preservation within the city.
   B.   Formulate standards and regulations for the evaluation of proposed
landmark and historic preservation district designation and rules of procedure
for application and hearings. Such regulations and rules of procedure shall be
submitted to the city council and shall be approved by the city council in
advance of their application to specific projects.
   C.   Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such
changes in standards, regulations and rules as may be deemed necessary by the
city council or the commission.
   D.   Develop and conduct an ongoing survey of the city, to identify
buildings, structures, areas, sites and landscapes that are of historic,
archaeological, architectural, or scenic significance, and, therefore, are
potential landmarks or historic preservation districts.
   E.   Hold public hearings and recommend to the city council the designation
of landmarks and historic preservation districts identified in the survey.
   F.   Compile and retain information concerning landmarks and historic
preservation districts identified and recommended for designation. This shall
include descriptions of the landmarks and historic preservation districts and
the characteristics that meet the standards for designation.
   G.   Keep a register of all designated landmarks and historic preservation
districts and prepare, update and publish a map or maps showing the locations
and exact boundaries of proposed and designated landmarks and historic
preservation districts, and, if the commission so chooses, the locations and/or
boundaries of designated McHenry County, state or national landmarks or
districts.
   H.   Establish an appropriate system of markers and plaques for all
designated landmarks and historic preservation districts, and to confer
recognition upon the owners of landmarks and property within historic
preservation districts by means of certificates, plaques and markers.
   I.   Nominate landmarks and historic preservation districts to any state or
national register of historic places.
   J.   Advise and assist owners of landmarks and property within the historic
preservation districts on physical and financial aspects of preservation,
renovation, rehabilitation and reuse, and on procedures of any state or any
national register of historic places.
   K.   Inform and educate the citizens of the city concerning the historic,
archaeological, architectural and scenic heritage of the city by publishing
appropriate maps, newsletters, brochures and pamphlets, and by holding programs
and seminars.
   L.   Develop specific criteria and guidelines for the proper alteration,
construction, demolition or removal of landmarks, or of property within a
historic preservation district. Such criteria and guidelines shall be submitted
to the city council and shall be approved by the city council in advance of
their application to specific projects.
   M.   Consider certificate of hardship applications that would allow the
performance of work for which a certificate of appropriateness has been denied
pursuant to this code.
   N.   Consider the issuance of certificates of appropriateness for category
2, major projects, and appeals when applications for certificates of
appropriateness for category 1, minor projects, are denied.
   O.   Review proposed amendments to zoning regulations, applications for
special use permits and applications for zoning variations that affect any
landmark or historic preservation district. Notice of such proposed actions
shall be transmitted to the commission for review prior to the hearing date
before the plan commission or the zoning board of appeals. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-
2008)
   P.   Testify before all boards and commissions, including the plan
commission, zoning board of appeals, board of building construction and the
city council, on any matter affecting potential or designated landmarks or
historic preservation districts. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 12-O-21,
3-20-2012)
   Q.   Periodically review the city's comprehensive plan, building codes and
Woodstock zoning ordinance; develop and present recommendations for the
preservation component for inclusion in the comprehensive plan or amendments to
the Woodstock zoning ordinance and/or building codes, if determined to be
appropriate for the protection and continued use of landmarks or property
within historic preservation districts.
   R.   Periodically monitor designated landmarks and historic preservation
districts for demolition by neglect.
   S.   Monitor and notify the state historic preservation officer of any
actual or proposed demolition or actual or proposed major alteration affecting
any property in its jurisdiction listed in the Illinois register of historic
places or the national register of historic places.
   T.   Be represented at not less than one informational or educational
meeting per year, approved by the state preservation officer, pertaining to the
work and functions of the commission or to historic preservation.
   U.   Submit an annual report to the Illinois historic preservation agency as
part of the certified local government program.
   V.   Periodically, at its discretion, audit the community development
department's regulations, standards and rules for approving category 1, minor
project, applications and report to the city council the results of its audit
and make recommendations to the city council with respect to the review.
   W.   Such additional powers and duties provided to municipal governments by
Illinois state statutes for historic preservation, subject to final approval by
the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.9.5: APPLICATIONS AFFECTING LANDMARK OR HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT
STATUS:
All applications for construction, alteration, removal or demolition affecting
landmarks or property within historic preservation districts shall first be
submitted to the city's community and economic development department for
review and determination. Determination shall be made in writing with findings
of fact. In addition, the community and economic development department shall
make recommendations for the change, alteration, or variation of any
application so the applicant is aware of what corrections need to be made to
bring the application into accord with city, state and national regulations.
(Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.9.6: APPEAL PROCESS:
   A.   Any applicant or other person aggrieved with the findings of the
community and economic development department may appeal to the commission by
filing a notice of appeal with the city manager within ten (10) days after
notification of the department's decision. The city manager shall set a date
for hearing before the commission not less than five (5) days nor more than
thirty (30) days from the date of notice of appeal. The city manager shall
notify the chair of the commission; the applicant for a category 1, minor
project, certificate of appropriateness approval; the appellant; and any other
person having an interest in the proceedings.
   B.   Following the hearing, the commission shall approve or disapprove the
application under appeal with findings of fact. A simple majority vote of the
commission shall be required to overturn any decision of the city manager. The
commission shall also make suggestions for any changes, alterations or
variations of a disapproved application so the applicant is advised of what
corrections may be made to bring the application into accord.
   C.   The commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings and shall also
keep records of its examinations and other official actions. Findings of fact
shall be included in the minutes for each case and the commission's reasons for
its recommendation to the city council to grant or deny each application shall
be specified. Every rule, regulation, order, requirement, decision and/or
determination of the commission shall immediately be filed in the office of the
city clerk and shall be a matter of public record.
   D.   Any applicant or other person aggrieved with the findings of the
commission may appeal to the city council by filing a notice of appeal with the
city manager within ten (10) days after notification of the commission's
decision. The city manager shall set a date for hearing the appeal before the
city council not less than five (5) days nor more than thirty (30) days from
the date of the filing of the notice of appeal. The city manager shall notify
the chair of the commission; the applicant; the appellant; and any other person
having an interest in the proceedings. No vote or decision of the commission
shall be overridden except by a simple majority vote of the city council. (Ord.
08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.9.7: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the historic
preservation commission in order to assist the commission with its various
duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager for
appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members
shall give direction to any member of the city staff. Unless otherwise set
forth herein or established by Illinois state statutes, all recommendations of
the board shall be referred to the city council for consideration and
implementation by the city.
   B.   The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
CHAPTER 10
ARTS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.10.1: Commission Established
2.10.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.10.3: Meetings
2.10.4: Powers and Duties
2.10.5: General Provisions
2.10.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To support and promote the City of Woodstock as a premier arts center and
destination, thereby enriching and enhancing both the local economy and the
quality of life, an Arts Commission is hereby established in the City. (Ord.
19-O-85, 11-5-19)
2.10.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFI-CERS: 
   A.   The Commission shall consist of six (6) members plus an appointed
chair. All members shall be residents of McHenry County and at least four (4)
members shall live within the corporate boundaries of the City of Woodstock.
All members and the Chair shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the City Council.
All members shall be selected on the basis of a sincere, motivated belief that
art is important to the life of a community and nourishes human development.
Other criteria for selection may include experience with any of the arts
including, but not limited to, visual art (painting, drawing, photography,
sculpture, pottery, floral); performing art (music, dance, theatre, comedy,
recitation); written (creative writing of fiction, non-fiction, and poetry;
musical composition and lyrics); artisan crafts (knitting, quilting,
woodworking, cooking); film/video (writing and production); experience with
fundraising and charitable giving; and personal effectiveness with team
building and community outreach.
   B.   The term of office for all members, including the Chair, shall be for
three (3) years.
   C.   Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the Mayor with the
advice and consent of the City Council, but only for the unexpired portion of
the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The Chair shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the City Council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
Chair to conduct all meetings of the Commission and to represent the Commission
at City Council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice-Chair: The Commission shall elect a Vice-Chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The City Clerk or designee shall serve as Secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the City Council. (Ord. 19-O-85, 11-5-19; amd. Ord. 21-
O-23, 4-6-2021; Ord. 22-O-28, 5-17-2022)
2.10.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The Commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the
Chair or a majority of the Commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois Open
Meetings Act. (Ord. 19-O-85, 11-5-19)
2.10.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The Commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the
Woodstock City Council and shall comply with all applicable provisions of
Illinois State Statutes and the Woodstock City Code.
   B.   The Commission shall investigate, become informed about and promote art
projects that can help the City of Woodstock become a premier arts destination.
   C.   The Commission shall encourage and facilitate collaboration between the
City and private citizens, businesses, organizations and institutions
interested in or conducting arts-related activities to maximize the allocation
and utilization of art resources in support of the arts.
   D.   The Commission shall advise the City Council in arts-related matters,
including long range planning, resource allocation and coordination with the
comprehensive plan.
   E.   The Commission shall assist with the development of art programs in the
City.
   F.   The Commission shall prepare and recommend to the City Council an arts
development plan. Such plan should identify ways for the City to support the
local arts community, connect residents
   and visitors to the arts, partner with local arts groups and businesses,
coordinate with arts programs in the region, and promote local art programs and
events. It may include:
      1.   Recommendations for a public-art program, including an inventory of
available sites for public art display, a procedure for soliciting and
selecting proposals for artworks and a strategy for promoting the artworks.
      2.   Plans for project-specific public art, such as a downtown mural
program, a roundabout sculpture program, a bike-path sculpture program, or a
town-gateway art program.
      3.   Proposals for arts programming to be developed by City departments
or agencies such as an arts-focused resource center operated by the library or
an expansion of arts programming offered by the recreation department.
      4.   Proposals for artist-in-residence programs, including parameters for
selection of artists working in a variety of disciplines, terms of residency,
and project requirements.
      5.   Ways to support or expand existing arts programs and festivals and
support the growth and development of local arts groups.
   G.   The Commission shall prepare and recommend to the City Council from
time to time, recommendations for specific improvements, additions to or
deletions from the plan.
   H.   The Commission shall have the opportunity to form ad hoc committees and
appoint members to such committees, including at least one member of
theCommission, for the purpose of researching specific topical areas, reporting
research outcomes to the Commission, and coordinating associated special
projects and events in keeping with the mission and objectives of the Arts
Commission
   I.   The Commission may provide input to the art-related uses of the City-
controlled portions of the Old Courthouse complex.
   J.   The Commission may provide recommendations for City funding of, and
investigate and promote fund development and procurement for, Arts Commission
projects.
   K.   Nothing in this section shall be construed to provide or imply a right
or responsibility of the Commission to advise or participate in any review or
approval process under the specific purview of other City boards and
commissions. (Ord. 19-O-85, 11-5-19)
2.10.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The City shall provide all reasonable assistance to the Arts Commission
in order to assist the Commission with its various duties. All requests for
assistance are to be conveyed to the City Manager for appropriate response by
the City. Neither the Commission nor any of its members shall give direction to
any member of the City staff and all recommendations of the Commission shall be
referred to the City Council for consideration and implementation by the City.
   B.   The Commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the City, without the express prior
approval of the Mayor and City Council. (Ord. 19-O-85, 11-5-19)
CHAPTER 11
PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.11.1: Commission Established
2.11.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.11.3: Meetings
2.11.4: Powers And Duties
2.11.5: General Provisions
2.11.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To further the goals of supporting and furthering healthy, active lifestyles;
providing a varied and comprehensive recreational program and park system in
the city of Woodstock; upholding both passive and active recreational uses of
municipal parks and recreational facilities; and promoting and supporting
pedestrian access and connectivity within the city of Woodstock, a parks and
recreation commission is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-
2008)
2.11.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of four (4) members
plus an appointed chair. All members shall be residents of the geographic
boundaries of unit school district 200 and at least three (3) members shall be
residents of the city of Woodstock. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
   B.   Appointment: The members and chair of the commission shall be appointed
by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.
   C.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   D.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   E.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   F.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   G.   Secretary: The city clerk or designee shall serve as secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.11.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the
chair or a majority of the commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act.
   C.   The recreation director or designee shall attend all meetings of the
commission. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.11.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The parks and recreation commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Make recommendations to the city council regarding parks and recreation
activities for the city.
   B.   Provide aid, assistance, and advice to the officials of the city on
subjects relating to parks and recreation activities.
   C.   Assist in the implementation of the city's comprehensive plan as it
pertains to parks and recreation activities.
   D.   Review all new residential development projects and provide a
recommendation for the donation of land for park sites.
   E.   Prepare and recommend to the city council a parks master plan. Such
plan shall include an overview of current park and recreational facility
locations, recommendations for future parks and recreational facilities sites
and amenities, and a supporting system of pedestrian access and connectivity.
   F.   Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such
changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the council or the
commission, but not less often than once every five (5) years.
   G.   Solicit information from the public and user groups for specific park
improvement projects, provide recommendations for improvement projects, and
provide recommendations for park and recreation facility needs, goals and
implementation schedules.
   H.   Solicit information from specific user groups such as established
leagues and school organizations to coordinate use of city facilities.
   I.   Assist staff to identify special user groups and establish or modify
recreation opportunities to increase the availability and selection of park and
recreation activities for all residents.
   J.   Evaluate policies for use of park and recreational facilities and
recommend changes to the established policies to the city council.
   K.   Evaluate current fees for park and recreational facilities and
recommend changes to the established fee structure to the city council.
   L.   Develop and conduct various means to publicize commission activities in
order to solicit public comments on park and recreation issues and to
communicate with the public to increase general public awareness and
understanding. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008)
2.11.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the parks and
recreation commission in order to assist the commission with its various
duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the recreation
director for appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any
of its members shall give direction to any member of the city staff and all
recommendations of the commission shall be referred to the city council for
consideration and implementation by the city.
   B.   The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-0-68, 11-4-2008)
CHAPTER 12
PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.12.1: Commission Established
2.12.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.12.3: Meetings
2.12.4: Powers And Duties
2.12.5: Cooperation With Regional Plan
2.12.6: Land Subdivision Or Resubdivision
2.12.7: Improvements
2.12.8: Project Review Process
2.12.9: Project Review Appeal Process
2.12.10: Expenditures
2.12.11: General Provisions
2.12.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To provide for well planned, managed and serviceable growth of the residential,
commercial and industrial sectors of the municipality, a plan commission is
hereby established in the city. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.12.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Commission Membership: The commission shall consist of six (6) members
plus an appointed chair. Five (5) members shall live within the corporate
boundaries of the city of Woodstock and two (2) may reside within one and one-
half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the city but must not be included
in any other municipality.
   B.   Appointment: The members and chair of the commission shall be appointed
by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.
   C.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   D.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   E.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   F.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   G.   Secretary: The city clerk or designee shall serve as secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012; amd. Ord.
22-O-23, 4-19-2022, eff. 5-1-2022)
2.12.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The commission shall meet no less than monthly. Additional meetings may
be called if deemed necessary by the chair or a majority of the commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.12.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The plan commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Prepare and recommend to the city council a comprehensive plan of
public improvements and land use, looking to the present and future development
and growth of the city. Such plan, after its adoption by the city council,
shall be known as the official plan of the city. Such plan shall include
reasonable requirements with reference to streets, alleys and public grounds
within the corporate limits and in contiguous territory outside of and distant
not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles from such limits, and not included
in any municipality; such requirements to be effective whenever any such lands
shall be subdivided after the adoption of the plan.
   B.   Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such
changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the city council or the
commission, but not less often than once every five (5) years.
   C.   Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time, plans and
recommendations for specific improvements pursuant to such official plan.
   D.   Hear all requests, petitions or appeals for rezoning of real estate or
amendments to the zoning district maps or the text of the zoning ordinance as
follows:
      1.   Any person aggrieved by a ruling of the City Zoning Officer, or by
any officer, department, board or bureau of the City concerning the
interpretation of the Zoning Ordinance, may appeal to the Plan Commission.
      2.   The Commission shall hear appeals and review any order, requirement,
decision or determination made by the Zoning Officer charged with the
enforcement of the City Zoning Ordinance.
      3.   A notice of appeal shall be made upon completion of forms provided
by the Commission for such purpose and the filing of said forms with the City
Clerk and the Commission. Said notice shall specify the grounds of appeal and
shall include such plats and exhibits as are reasonably necessary.
      4.   An appeal shall be taken by the Commission within thirty (30) days
after the filing with the City Clerk and the Commission of a notice of appeal.
The City Clerk shall transmit to the Commission all documents constituting the
record upon which the action being appealed was taken.
      5.   Formulate standards and regulations for the evaluation of appeals
and rules of procedure. Such regulations and rules of procedure shall be
submitted to the City Council and shall be approved by the City Council in
advance of their application to specific appeals.
      6.   Prepare and recommend to the City Council from time to time such
changes in standards, regulations and rules as may be deemed necessary by the
City Council or the Board.
      7.   The Commission may reverse or affirm, wholly or in part, or may
modify or amend the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed, to
the extent and in the manner the Commission may decide to be fitting and proper
for the premises. To that end, the Commission shall have all the powers of the
Zoning Officer of the City whose order, requirement, decision or determination
made was cause for the appeal.
      8.   The concurring vote of four (4) members of the Commission shall be
necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of the
Zoning Officer of the City or to decide in favor of the appellant any matter
upon which it is authorized to render decisions.
   E.   Review and approve the layout of all streets and the subdivision of
real estate and approve preliminary and final plats of subdivision,
resubdivision, or planned development.
   F.   Give aid to the officials of the city charged with the direction of
projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the
making of such improvements, and generally to promote the realization of the
official plan.
   G.   Work to establish greater public interest and participation in
enhancement of the city's appearance, order and quality of design to combat
deterioration of visual character.
   H.   Formulate standards and regulations for the evaluation of proposed
projects and rules of procedure for application and hearings. Such regulations
and rules of procedure shall be submitted to the city council and shall be
approved by the city council in advance of their application to specific
projects.
   I.   Prepare and recommend to the city council from time to time such
changes in standards, regulations and rules as may be deemed necessary by the
city council or the commission.
   J.   Periodically, at its discretion, audit the community development
department's application of the regulations, standards and rules to a completed
project review and report to the city council the results of its audit and make
recommendations to the city council with respect to project reviews.
   K.   Act as counselor and review consultant on matters of appearance to
those desiring to develop or redevelop properties.
   L.   Arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities
for the general purpose of public understanding.
   M.   Exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by law as may
be conferred by the city council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012; amd. Ord. 21-O-23,
4-6-2021; Ord. 22-O-23, 4-19-2022, eff. 5-1-2022)
2.12.5: COOPERATION WITH REGIONAL PLAN:
The plan and activities of the commission shall be developed in cooperation
with and implemented by any regional plan that may be adopted by other units of
government in McHenry County insofar as the same is possible. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-
20-2012)
2.12.6: LAND SUBDIVISION OR RESUBDIVISION:
Following the adoption of an official plan in the manner prescribed in this
chapter, no map or plat of any subdivision or resubdivision presented for
record affecting land within the corporate limits of the city, or in contiguous
territory outside of and distant not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles
from such limits and not included in the city, shall be entitled to record or
shall be valid unless the subdivision thereon shall provide for streets, alleys
and public grounds in conformity with any applicable requirements of the
official plan. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.12.7: IMPROVEMENTS:
The city clerk shall furnish the commission, for its consideration, a copy of
all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any nature.
The commission may report in relation thereto if it deems a report necessary or
advisable, for the consideration of the city council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.12.8: PROJECT REVIEW PROCESS:
   A.   All project plans subject to project review shall be submitted to the
community development department for review and approval.
   B.   The community development department shall review project plans, using
the commission's regulations and standards and submit a written project review
report. Such project review shall be completed by the department within fifteen
(15) business days after a complete submittal has been made.
   C.   The community development department shall make recommendations for the
change, alteration or variation of any project plan in the written project
review report to inform the applicant of necessary corrections to bring the
project plan into accord with this code and the commission's regulations and
standards. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.12.9: PROJECT REVIEW APPEAL PROCESS:
   A.   Any applicant or other person aggrieved with the findings of the
community development department may appeal to the commission by filing a
notice of appeal with the director of the community development department
within ten (10) days after notification of the department's decision.
   B.   The director of the community development department shall set a date
for an appeals hearing before the commission. The hearing on any appeal shall
be set not less than five (5) days nor more than thirty (30) days from the date
of notice of appeal.
   C.   The building and zoning officer of the city shall provide notification
of the appeals hearing to the commissioners, the applicant for project plan
approval, the appellant and any other person having an interest in the
proceedings.
   D.   After the hearing, the commission shall, with findings of fact, approve
or disapprove the project plan under appeal. A simple majority vote of the
commission shall be required to overturn any decision of the community
development department.
   E.   The commission shall also recommend changes, alterations or variations
to a disapproved project plan so the applicant is advised of corrections to
bring the project plan into accord with this code and the commission's
regulations and standards.
   F.   Any applicant or other person aggrieved with the findings of the
commission may appeal to the city council by filing a notice of appeal with the
city manager within ten (10) days after notification of the commission's
decision.
   G.   The city manager shall set a date for hearing the appeal before the
city council. The hearing for any such appeal shall be set not less than five
(5) days nor more than thirty (30) days from the date of the filing of the
notice of appeal.
   H.   The city manager shall notify the commission chair, the applicant for
project approval, the appellant and any other person having an interest in the
proceedings.
   I.   After the hearing, the city council shall approve or disapprove the
project plan under appeal. A simple majority vote of the city council shall be
required to overturn any decision of the commission. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.12.10: EXPENDITURES:
The commission may, at the discretion of the city council, employ necessary
help whose salaries, wages and other necessary expenses shall be provided for
by adequate appropriation made by the city council from the public funds. If
the commission shall deem it advisable to secure technical advice or service,
it may be done upon authority from and the appropriation by the city council
for such purpose. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.12.11: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the plan commission
in order to assist the commission with its various duties. All requests for
assistance are to be conveyed to the city manager for appropriate response by
the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members shall give direction to
any member of the city staff. Unless otherwise set forth herein or established
by Illinois state statutes, all recommendations of the commission shall be
referred to the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
   B.   Except as specifically stated in this chapter, the commission shall not
have the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any purchase or
contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien
against the city, without the express prior approval of the mayor and city
council.
   C.   Any special request for the record to be taken by a court reporter
shall be provided at the expense of the appellant with a copy provided to the
city one week prior to action by the city council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
CHAPTER 13
POLICE PENSION BOARD
SECTION:
2.13.1: Board Established
2.13.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.13.3: Meetings
2.13.4: Powers And Duties
2.13.5: General Provisions
2.13.1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
   A.   For the benefit of city of Woodstock police officers and their
surviving spouses, children, and certain other dependents, and in accordance
with Illinois state statutes, specifically article 3 of the Illinois pension
code, the board of trustees of the police pension fund is hereby established in
the city.
   B.   For purposes of reference and financial accounting within the
municipality, the board of trustees of the police pension fund shall also be
known as, and shall serve as one in the same as, the police pension board.
(Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.13.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Board Membership: The board of trustees of the police pension fund,
a.k.a. police pension board, shall consist of five (5) members, at least two
(2) of whom shall reside within the corporate boundaries of the city of
Woodstock.
   B.   Appointment: Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the
mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. Two (2) members of the
board shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members
thereof. The remaining members shall be elected by and from the beneficiaries
of the police pension fund.
   C.   Election: The election for elected board members provided for in
subsection B of this section shall be held biennially on the third Monday in
April at such time or times and places in the city as shall be prescribed by
the appointed members of the board, and under the Australian ballot system and
other such regulations.
   D.   Voting: All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to
vote only for the police force members of the board. All beneficiaries of legal
voting age shall be entitled to vote only for the member to be chosen from the
beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at any
such election. Members so elected shall be elected for a term of two (2) years
beginning the second Tuesday of the first May following such election.
   E.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members shall be for two (2)
years.
   F.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the initial
appointing authority, but only to the unexpired portion of the vacated term.
   G.   Officers: The officers of the board shall be president, vice president,
secretary and assistant secretary who shall be selected from its members at the
regular July meeting. Officers shall serve for one year and until their
respective successors are elected and qualified.
   H.   President: It shall be the duty of the president to conduct all
meetings of the board and to represent the board at city council meetings as
from time to time may be necessary.
   I.   Vice President: The vice president shall perform the duties of the
president during any vacancy in that office, or during the president's absence
from the municipality, or if he or she is by reason of illness or other causes
unable to perform the duties of the office.
   J.   Secretary: The secretary shall maintain minutes and records of regular
and special meetings and regularly provide such records to the city council.
   K.   Assistant Secretary: The assistant secretary shall act for the
secretary whenever necessary to discharge the functions of such office. (Ord.
12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.13.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The board shall meet no less than quarterly in July, October, January
and April. Additional meetings may be called if deemed necessary by the
president or a majority of the board.
   B.   Notice of a board meeting shall be given in writing to each member of
the board at least twenty four (24) hours prior to the time set for the
meeting. Additionally, notice of the meeting shall be posted in a conspicuous
place in the police department not less than twenty four (24) hours prior to
any board meeting.
   C.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
2.13.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of trustees of the police pension fund, a.k.a. police pension board,
of the city shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To control and manage exclusively the pension fund and all monies
donated, paid or assessed for the relief or pensioning of disabled,
superannuated and retired members of the police department, their widows, minor
children and dependent parents. All such monies shall be placed by the
treasurer of the municipality to the credit of the fund subject to the order of
the board.
   B.   To order and direct the payment of pensions and other benefits provided
by article 3 of the Illinois pension code and to issue certificates signed by
its president and secretary to the persons entitled thereto of the amount
ordered paid to such persons from the fund, which certificate shall state the
purpose of the payment.
   C.   To submit annually to the city council at the close of the
municipality's fiscal year, a list of persons entitled to benefits from the
fund, stating the amount of the payments and their purpose, as ordered by the
board. It shall also include items of income accrued to the fund during the
fiscal year. Such lists shall be signed by the secretary and president of the
board and attested under oath. No resolution or order for the payment of money
shall be valid unless approved by a majority of the members of the board, and
any order for such payment shall be signed by the president and secretary of
the board.
   D.   To draw such pension funds from the treasurer or other officials of the
municipality, and to invest any part thereof in the name of the board in
interest bearing bonds or tax anticipation warrants of the United States Of
America, of the state of Illinois, or of any county, township or municipal
corporation of the state of Illinois; insured withdrawal capital accounts of
the state chartered savings and loan associations; insured withdrawable capital
accounts of federal chartered federal savings and loan associations if the
withdrawable capital accounts are insured by the federal savings and loan
insurance corporation; insured investments in credit unions if the investments
are insured by the national credit union administration; and in savings
accounts or certificates of deposit of a national or state bank. All
certificates or securities shall be deposited with the treasurer of the
municipality and be subject to the order of the board. Interest on such
investments shall be credited to the account of the police pension fund.
   E.   To compel witnesses to attend and testify before it, upon all matters
connected with the administration of this chapter, in the manner provided by
law for the taking of testimony before the circuit court. The president or any
member of the board may administer oaths to such witnesses.
   F.   To accept donations by gift, grant, transfer, or bequest, any money,
real estate, or personal property. Such money and the proceeds from the sale of
or the income from such real estate or personal property shall be paid into the
police pension fund.
   G.   To appoint a clerk and define the duties of a clerk. No person drawing
a pension under this chapter shall be employed by the board.
   H.   To provide for the payment from the fund of all necessary expenses
including clerk hire, printing and witness fees.
   I.   To keep a public record of all its proceedings.
   J.   To make necessary rules and regulations in conformity with the
provisions of this chapter, which shall be published by the board and copies
transmitted from time to time to all pensioners and contributors. (Ord. 12-O-
21, 3-20-2012)
2.13.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the board of
trustees of the police pension fund, a.k.a. police pension board, in order to
assist the board with its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be
conveyed to the director of the finance department for appropriate response by
the city. Neither the board nor any of its members shall give direction to any
member of the city staff. Unless otherwise set forth herein or established by
Illinois state statutes, all recommendations of the board shall be referred to
the city council for consideration and implementation by the city.
   B.   Except as specifically stated in this chapter, the board shall not have
the authority to make any expenditure, or cause to be made any purchase or
contract that directly or indirectly results in a financial liability or lien
against the city, without the express prior approval of the mayor and city
council. (Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
CHAPTER 14
RESERVED
(Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
CHAPTER 15
RESERVED
CHAPTER 16
OLD COURTHOUSE AND SHERIFF'S HOUSE ADVISORY COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.16.1: Commission Established
2.16.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.16.3: Meetings
2.16.4: Powers And Duties
2.16.5: General Provisions
2.16.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To further the goals of: a) preserving, and promoting awareness and
understanding of the historic and architectural character of the Old McHenry
County Courthouse and Sheriff's House on the Square, b) promoting and
soliciting investment in, and ensuring the financial sustainability of, the Old
Courthouse and Sheriff's House, c) utilizing the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's
House as contributing entities to the economic base of the Square and
community, and d) facilitate collaboration among community and regional
partners in such efforts, the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's House advisory
commission is hereby established in the city. (Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015)
2.16.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Membership: The commission shall be comprised of six (6) members plus
an appointed chair. All members shall be residents of McHenry County and at
least five (5) members shall live within the corporate boundaries of the city
of Woodstock.
All members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council.
All members shall be selected on the basis of a sincere, motivated interest in
identifying the highest and best use of the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's House,
recognizing its potential contribution to the aesthetic and vitality of the
Historic Woodstock Square. Other criteria for selection may include an
understanding of real estate and/or economic development strategies; knowledge
of historic preservation techniques and guidelines; experience with fundraising
and charitable giving; personal effectiveness with team building and community
outreach.
Further, members shall be appointed recognizing the municipal interest of
providing cross sector representation from within the community. Therefore,
reasonable consideration should be given to property or business owners within
the historic downtown area; individuals with evidenced expertise in the
disciplines of architectural history, architectural planning, historic
preservation, or related fields; and professionals in law, education,
engineering, economic development, fund development and procurement, financing,
real estate, and the construction trades.
   B.   Terms: The term of office for all members, including the chair, shall
be for three (3) years.
   C.   Vacancies: Any vacancy shall be filled through appointment by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, but only for the unexpired
portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The city clerk or designee shall serve as secretary and
maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and regularly
provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015; amd. Ord.
21-O-23, 4-6-2021)
2.16.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The commission shall meet no less than quarterly. Additional meetings
may be called if deemed necessary by the chair or a majority of the commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act.
   C.   The managing director of the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's House or
designee shall attend all meetings of the commission. (Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015)
2.16.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the city
council and shall comply with all applicable provisions of Illinois state
statutes and this code.
   B.   Specific duties of the commission shall be:
      1.   To work to establish greater public interest and participation in
the historic preservation of the Old McHenry County Courthouse and Sheriff's
House within the city.
      2.   To inform and educate the citizens of the city and county concerning
the historic, architectural and aesthetic significance of the buildings.
      3.   To hold such public meetings appropriate to gain public input on
ownership and the highest and best uses of the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's
House.
      4.   To create and forward a common vision for ownership and use of the
buildings for consideration and approval by the city council.
      5.   To investigate and promote fund development and procurement
supportive of long term sustainability of the buildings.
      6.   To consider potential lease arrangements associated with the Old
Courthouse and Sheriff's House and make recommendations to the city council for
consideration and approval.
      7.   To annually evaluate and prioritize in cooperation with the managing
director of the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's House, short and long term
structural capital expenditures, capital improvements, and other needs based on
the underlying interests and priorities of accessibility, structural and
historic integrity, financial capacity, and sustainability and make
recommendations to the city council for consideration and approval.
      8.   To promote and facilitate interaction among organizations and groups
interested in the preservation of the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's House.
      9.   To prepare a written report to the city council at the end of each
calendar year and in cooperation with the managing director of the Old
Courthouse and Sheriff's House evaluating the status of the buildings in terms
of: a) historic preservation, b) structural improvement and integrity, c)
usage, including tenants and leases, d) financial perspective and economic
viability, and e) the impact of the buildings, status and uses on the downtown
Square area and community.
      10.   To consider, evaluate and make recommendations pertaining to any
Old Courthouse and/or Sheriff's House issue at the request of the city council.
(Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015)
2.16.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the Old Courthouse
and Sheriff's House advisory commission in order to assist the commission with
its various duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the
managing director of the Old Courthouse and Sheriff's House for appropriate
response by the city. Neither the commission nor any of its members shall give
direction to any member of the city staff and all recommendations of the
commission shall be referred to the city council for consideration and
implementation by the city.
   B.   The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015)
CHAPTER 17
OPERA HOUSE ADVISORY COMMISSION
SECTION:
2.17.1: Commission Established
2.17.2: Membership, Terms, Officers
2.17.3: Meetings
2.17.4: Powers And Duties
2.17.5: General Provisions
2.17.1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
To further the goals of providing varied and diverse cultural arts programming
in the city of Woodstock, opportunities for local artists and performers to
grow and advance in their art, and uphold and preserve the historic character
of the Woodstock Opera House, the Woodstock Opera House advisory commission is
hereby established. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015)
2.17.2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS, OFFICERS:
   A.   Commission Membership: The commission shall be comprised of six (6)
members plus an appointed chair. All members shall be residents of McHenry
County. Two (2) at large members and the chair shall be appointed by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council. The remainder of the
commission shall include one representative selected by and from each of the
following community based constituent groups upon consent of the city council:
      Friends Of The Opera House
      Judith Svalander School of Ballet
      Theatre 121
      Woodstock Fine Arts Association
Of the three (3) members and the chair appointed by the mayor with the advice
and consent of the city council, none may be members of the governing boards of
the above constituent groups.
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office for all members, including the
chair, shall be for three (3) years.
   C.   Vacancy: Any vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the initial
appointing authority with the consent of the city council, but only to the
unexpired portion of the vacated term.
   D.   Chair: The chair shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the city council in May of each year. It shall be the duty of the
chair to conduct all meetings of the commission and to represent the commission
at city council meetings as from time to time may be necessary.
   E.   Vice Chair: The commission shall elect a vice chair from among its
membership at the first meeting of each year.
   F.   Secretary: The opera house director or designee shall serve as
secretary and maintain minutes and records of regular and special meetings and
regularly provide such records to the city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008;
amd. Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015; Ord. 16-O-18, 4-5-2016; Ord. 19-O-51, 6-4-2019;
Ord. 21-O-23, 4-6-2021)
2.17.3: MEETINGS:
   A.   The commission shall meet from time to time as may be determined by the
chair or a majority of the commission.
   B.   All meetings shall be held in compliance with the Illinois open
meetings act.
   C.   The opera house director or designee shall attend all meetings of the
commission. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015)
2.17.4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The commission shall serve only in an advisory capacity to the
Woodstock city council and shall comply with all applicable provisions of
Illinois state statutes and this code and shall have the following.
   B.   Specific duties of the commission shall be:
      1.   To evaluate all phases of the performing arts, art exhibits,
lectures and cultural activities in connection with the utilization of the
Woodstock Opera House Community Center and Stage Left Cafe.
      2.   To assist, in an advisory capacity, the opera house director, in the
promotion and use of the Opera House Community Center and Stage Left Cafe for
recreational, artistic and educational purposes.
      3.   To prepare a written report to the city council at the end of each
calendar year and in cooperation with the opera house director evaluating the
programs and policies governing the use of the Woodstock Opera House Community
Center and Stage Left Cafe. This shall be prepared by taking into consideration
how the various programs in the facilities relate to other such commercial and
educational programs in surrounding areas.
      4.   To recommend to the city council at the end of each calendar year
and in cooperation with the opera house director necessary short and long term
capital expenditures, capital improvements and other facility needs of the
Opera House Community Center and Stage Left Cafe.
      5.   To promote and facilitate interaction among organizations and groups
who utilize the facilities of the Opera House Community Center and Stage Left
Cafe.
      6.   To consider, evaluate and make recommendations pertaining to any
Opera House Community Center and Stage Left Cafe issue at the request of the
Woodstock city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 15-O-62, 10-6-2015)
2.17.5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall provide all reasonable assistance to the Woodstock opera
house advisory commission in order to assist the commission with its various
duties. All requests for assistance are to be conveyed to the opera house
director for appropriate response by the city. Neither the commission nor any
of its members shall give direction to any member of the city staff and all
recommendations of the commission shall be referred to the city council for
consideration and implementation by the city.
   B.   The commission shall not have the authority to make any expenditure, or
cause to be made any purchase or contract that directly or indirectly results
in a financial liability or lien against the city, without the express prior
approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 08-O-68, 11-4-2008; amd. Ord. 15-
O-62, 10-6-2015)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
LICENSES AND PERMITS
SECTION:
3.1.1: Applicability of Provisions
3.1.2: Application for Licenses
3.1.3: Contents of Licenses
3.1.4: Investigations
3.1.5: License Fees
3.1.6: Term of Licenses
3.1.7: Conditions of License
3.1.8: Inspections
3.1.9: Revocation of License
3.1.1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
In the absence of specific provisions to the contrary, the provisions of this
Chapter shall apply to the issuance of all licenses and permits by the City.
(1963 Code, §43.01)
3.1.2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSES:
Applications for all licenses and permits required by ordinance shall be made
in writing to the City Manager. Each application shall state the name of the
applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the
time covered and the fee to be paid, and shall contain such additional
information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the City officials in
the issuing of the permit or license applied for. (1963 Code, §43.02; amd. 1986
Code)
3.1.3: CONTENTS OF LICENSES:
   A.   Forms: Forms for all licenses, permits and applications shall be
prepared and kept on file by the City Manager. (1963 Code, §43.03; amd. 1986
Code)
   B.   Signatures: Each license or permit issued shall bear the signatures of
the Mayor and the Clerk. (1963 Code, §43.04)
3.1.4: INVESTIGATIONS:
Upon the receipt of an application for a license or permit where the ordinances
of the City necessitate an inspection or investigation before the issuance of
such permit or license, the City Manager shall refer such application to the
proper officer for making such investigation within forty eight (48) hours of
the time of such receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making the
investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or
otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving the application or a copy
thereof. If the report recommends denial, the reasons shall be stated in the
report. (1963 Code, §43.05; amd. 1986 Code)
3.1.5: LICENSE FEES:
All fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid at the time
application is made to the City Manager. When application for an annual license
is made after the expiration of six (6) months of the current license year, the
license for the remainder of the year shall be issued upon payment of one-half
(1/2) the annual fee. (1963 Code, §43.06; amd. 1986 Code)
3.1.6: TERM OF LICENSES:
   A.   All annual licenses shall terminate on the last day of the current
fiscal year of the City 1 .
   B.   Three (3) weeks prior to the date of expiration, the City Manager shall
mail a statement to all annual licensees of the City stating the time of
expiration. Failure to receive notice shall not excuse the licensee from
failure to renew his license. (1963 Code, §43.07; amd. 1986 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. Section
  1.3.2 of this Code defines "fiscal year" as May 1 to April 30.
3.1.7: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   No license or permit shall be issued for any purpose if the premises or
building to be used for such purpose do not comply with the ordinances or
regulations of the City. (1963 Code, §43.08)
   B.   Transfer: Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, lLicenses issued
may be transferred by the original licensee if written notice is filed with the
Director of Finance within ten (10) days before the transfer is made, but no
more than one transfer of any license shall be made within any license year.
(1963 Code, §43.09; amd. 1986 Code)
   C.   Posting License: Any person conducting a licensed business in the City
shall keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for
such business. (1963 Code, §43.14)
   D.   Nuisances: No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted or
operated as to amount to a nuisance in fact.
(1963 Code, §43.11; amd. Ord. 25-O-27, 4-15-2025)
3.1.8: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the
operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for, the licensee
or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected shall admit for the
purpose of making such inspection at any reasonable time any authorized City
officer or employee.
   B.   Whenever an inspection or analysis of any commodity or material is
reasonably necessary to secure conformance with any ordinance provision or to
detect violations, the licensee shall give to any authorized officer or
employee of the City requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or
commodity for inspection analysis.
   C.   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the Mayor may
revoke the license of any licensee who refuses to permit any authorized officer
or employee to make such inspection, or who interferes with such officer or
employee while making such inspection. No license shall be revoked for such
cause unless written demand has been made upon the licensee or person in charge
of the premises in the name of the City, stating that such inspection is
sought. (1963 Code, §43.12)
3.1.9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license or permit for a limited time may be revoked by the Mayor at any
time during the life of such license or permit for any violation by the
licensee or permittee of the ordinance provisions relating to the license or
permit, the subject matter of the license or permit, or to the premises
occupied. Such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. (1963 Code,
§43.13)
No license shall be revoked without a hearing being conducted by the Mayor
pursuant to notice. (1986 Code)
CHAPTER 2
MUNICIPAL TAXES
SECTION:
3.2.1: Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax
3.2.2: Municipal Service Occupation Tax

3.2.11.2: Collection Of Tax By Retailers
3.2.12: Amusement Tax
3.2.1: MUNICIPAL RETAILER'S OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the City in the
business of selling tangible personal property at retail at the rate of one
percent (1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such
business while this Section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1.
   B.   Every such person engaged in such business in the City shall file, on
or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State
Department of Revenue required by section three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax
Upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to
Purchasers for Use or Consumption" approved June 28, 1933, as amended 1 .
   C.   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State
Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the
receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month.
(Ord. 840, 9-2-69)
   D.   The exclusion contained in section 2(d) of the "Retailers' Occupation
Tax Act" approved June 28, 1933, and as amended by Public Act 80-1292, shall
not apply to property within the City. (Ord. 1479, 12-19-78)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
3.2.2: MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the City in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost
price of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either
in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an
incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-5.
   B.   Every supplier or serviceman required to account for Municipal service
occupation tax for the benefit of the City shall file, on or before the last
day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of Revenue
required by section nine of the "Service Occupation Tax Act", approved July 10,
1961, as amended 1 .
   C.   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State
Department the amount of tax hereby imposed. (Ord. 841, 9-2-69)
   D.   The exclusion contained in section 2(e) of the "Service Occupation Tax
Act" approved July 10, 1961, as amended by Public Act 80-1292, shall not apply
to property within the City. (Ord. 1479, 12-19-78)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.
3.2.3: MUNICIPAL USE TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in the City any
item of tangible personal property, which is purchased outside of the State of
Illinois at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an
agency of the government of the State of Illinois. The tax imposed shall be at
the rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price of such tangible property.
"Selling price" shall have the same meaning as defined in the Use Tax Act,
approved July 14, 1955 1 .
   B.   The use tax hereby imposed shall be collected by the Illinois
Department of Revenue for the benefit of the City, and shall be paid before any
title or certificate of registration for such personal property shall be
issued. (Ord. 1118, 10-24-74)
 
Notes
1 2. S.H.A. 35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.
3.2.4: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES' TAX:
   A.   Tax and License Fee: All corporations, companies and associations not
incorporated under the laws of this State which are engaged in effecting fire
insurance in the City, shall pay to the City Treasurer, for maintenance, use
and benefit of the Fire Department thereof, a sum equal to two percent (2%) of
the gross receipts of the premiums received by their agents for fire insurance
on property situated in the City. (1963 Code, §15.01)
   B.   Report: Every person acting as agent or otherwise for or on behalf of
such corporations, companies and associations shall, on or before July 15 of
each year, render to the City a full, true and just account, verified by his
oath of all premiums for fire insurance received by him or any other person for
him in behalf of any such corporation, company or association for the year
ending July 1; and shall also pay to the City Treasurer at the time of
rendering said report the amount due at the rate fixed by this Section, for
which the companies, corporations or associations represented by them are
severally chargeable by law and under this Section. (1963 Code, §15.02)
   C.   Transaction of Business Prohibited: If any person fails to render such
account on or before July 15, or if such amount so computed remains unpaid
after that date, it shall be unlawful for any person so in default to transact
any business in the City until this Section shall have been fully complied
with. (1963 Code, §15.03)
3.2.5: AUTOMOBILE RENTING USE TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in the City an
automobile which is rented from a renter outside of the State of Illinois and
which is titled or registered with any agency of this State's government in the
City, at the rate of one percent (1%) of the rental price of such automobile
while this Section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-8.
   B.   The tax provided for in this Section shall be collected from the
persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as
being in this City. (Ord. 1709, 1-5-82)
3.2.6: AUTOMOBILE RENTING OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
renting automobiles in this City at the rate of one percent (1%) of the gross
receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this Section
is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-11-7.
   B.   Every such person engaged in such business in the City shall file on or
before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department
of Revenue required by sections two and three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax
Upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to
Purchasers for Use or Consumption", approved June 29, 1933, as amended 1 .
   C.   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State
Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the
renting of automobiles during the preceding month. (Ord. 1710, 1-5-82)
