3.3.2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall sell or offer for sale at retail in the City any alcoholic
liquor without having a retail liquor dealer's license, or in violation of the
terms of such license or any statute, law or this Code. (Ord. 15-O-25, 4-21-
2015)
3.3.3: APPLICATION AND ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Prior to submitting an application, any interested applicant shall
first confirm with the Commissioner whether there is a moratorium on the class
of liquor license in question under Section
3.3.6(B) of this Code and shall provide the Commissioner with information
sufficient for the Commissioner to determine whether or not such moratorium
should be lifted.
   B.   Applications for a liquor license shall be filed with the Commissioner
in such manner as may be directed by the Commissioner.
   C.   No City liquor license shall be issued to any applicant who (i) is not
qualified to receive a license under state law, or (ii) who is specifically
prohibited from receiving a liquor license pursuant to state law at 235 ILCS 5/
6-2, as may be subsequently amended.
   D.   Sole Proprietor applicants are required to reside within the City.
   E.   All applicants must certify that at all times a licensed establishment
is open for business, either (i) an authorized licensee, or (ii) a manager or
agent who possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee, shall be
on the premises.
   F.   All applicants must obtain and submit proof of insurance as required by
this Chapter.
   G.   Applicant must agree in writing to save and hold harmless the City of
Woodstock from any and all claims arising out of consumption of alcoholic
liquor on the premises.
   H.   Outstanding Debts: No licenses shall be issued or renewed to any
applicant who is indebted to the City for any amount that is past due.
   I.   Investigation Of Applicant:
      1.   No license shall be issued hereunder until the applicant shall have
been investigated by the Commissioner and a report filed in the records of the
Commissioner. As a part of this investigation, the Commissioner shall require
fingerprints of all new applicants and shall have the right to require
fingerprints of any applicant for renewal thereof. A copy of fingerprints may
be held on record by the Chief of Police or his or her designee. Applicant
shall be responsible for all costs and fees incurred by the City associated
with this investigation including but not limited to the fees for fingerprints
and any criminal background checks.
      2.   The Commissioner or their authorized agent shall have the right to
examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local license
or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or
suspension has been served, and to examine or cause to be examined, the books
and records of any such applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and take proof
for this information in the performance of the Commissioner’s duties.
   J.   Application Fee: Except for Class K and N Licenses, a nonrefundable
application fee in the amount of established by the City Manager as authorized
by this Chapter shall be payable upon initial application, which shall be
applied to the license upon issuance of the license (less any amount due to the
City to reimburse the City for the costs of any fingerprint or criminal
background check fees paid by the City in the course of consideration of the
applicant’s application for a liquor license).
   K.   Conditions: All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be
subject to any and all changes or amendments to this chapter and to any and all
rules adopted by the Commissioner. All licenses shall be subject to any
restrictions or conditions deemed desirable by the Commissioner to ensure
compliance with this Chapter or to protect the public health, safety, and
welfare.
   L.   The issuance of a liquor license, regardless of class, shall be deemed
to include any representations contained in the application for the respective
class of license as well as a representation by the applicant to comply with
all requirements of Illinois and City liquor laws or ordinances. Any false
statement or misrepresentation in an application or in all other information
submitted with the application shall be deemed grounds for immediate revocation
of the license granted pursuant to that application. Any violation of the terms
and conditions of any liquor license, including representations and information
submitted on or with the application, shall be grounds for the issuance of a
fine or the suspension or revocation of the license as provided in this
chapter.
   M.   All licenses shall be for a term not to exceed one (1) year and shall
expire at the end of April 30 of each year, after the date of issuance,
regardless of the date when issued.
   N.   If the application is approved and a license is issued, all owners, on-
site managers, and employees that serve alcohol and/or check for legal age
shall take and successfully complete a Beverage Alcohol Sellers and Servers
Education and Training (BASSET) Program that has been certified by the State of
Illinois. A copy of the BASSET course completion certificate(s) for each such
person always shall be made available, at the licensed premises for inspection
by the City.
   O.   Unless an extension is approved by the Commissioner, an applicant for a
liquor license shall have sixty (60) calendar days following approval of the
license by the City Council in which to pick up the physical license from the
Commissioner. If the applicant fails to pick up the physical license within the
sixty-day time period, the license shall automatically expire, and, if the
applicant still wishes to obtain a license, the applicant will be required to
submit a new application with fees for City approval through the normal review
process. (23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.4: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Required Insurance for All Applicants/License Holders: Every
application for any class of license, including special event and BYOB
licenses, shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance that evidences
that the applicant and the applicant’s premises have or will have dram shop
(liquor liability) insurance with minimum coverages of at least one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
in the aggregate in full force and effect throughout the time period covered by
the license.
   B.   Additional Requirements for Sales in the City’s Right-of-Way and City-
Owned Property. For any applicant who is permitted to or seeks to sell, serve,
or allow the consumption of alcoholic liquor on any City right-of-way or real
property owned by the City, the applicant must also provide evidence that the
required insurance includes coverage for such right-of-way or City-owned real
property.?
   C.   Policy Must be Acceptable to Commissioner. All required insurance
policies shall be issued by a responsible insurance company, authorized and
licensed to do business in the State of Illinois, and acceptable to the
Commissioner.
   D.   Policy Must Name City as Additional Named Insured. All required
insurance policies shall specifically name the City of Woodstock as an
additional named insured.
   E.   Policy Must be in Effect at All Times as a Condition of License.
      1.   The license holder may not operate at any time without the required
insurance in place.
      2.   All certificates of insurance shall provide that the insurance
coverage may not be cancelled unless written notice is given to the City at
least fifteen (15) days prior to the effective date of such cancellation. In
addition, all license holders must notify the Commissioner of any cancellation
in or change to the required insurance.
      3.   In the event insurance coverage is expected to or does lapse,
regardless of reason, during the time period covered by the license, the
licensee shall promptly provide the city with a new certificate of insurance
evidencing dram shop coverage in the aforesaid amounts.
      4.   If the licensee is unable to obtain such replacement dram shop
insurance coverage, licensee shall promptly notify the City and shall
immediately cease selling, serving, and allowing the consumption of alcoholic
liquor until such time as licensee procures dram shop insurance coverage at the
limits described in this section.
      5.   The failure of the applicant/licensee to have such insurance
coverage in full force and effect at any time during the term of its liquor
license shall be cause for the immediate suspension and for the revocation of
the liquor license. (Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.5: VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS:
   A.   Liquor License with Video Gaming: Video Gaming shall only be permitted
as authorized by this section and in a manner consistent with state law and
regulations. If a liquor license associated with video gaming is available
under the A, C, D, E and I classification, then an applicant may apply for such
a City-issued license provided they meet the following additional criteria:
      1.   The applicant/license holder must maintain their liquor license
eligibility under the City’s Code and any fees due for video gaming licensing
shall be in addition to those required for ordinary liquor licensing without
video gaming.
      2.   The applicant/license holder must comply with all City Code
provisions.
      3.   The applicant/license holder must be licensed by the Illinois Gaming
Board and always comply with the Illinois Video Gaming Act, as may be amended
(230 ILCS 40/1 et. seq.) and with its associated regulations.
   B.   All license applications seeking video gaming authority must be
reviewed by and are subject to the approval of both the Commissioner and the
City Council to determine whether the conditions of this Chapter can be or have
been reasonably met prior to issuance of any liquor license permitting video
gaming.
   C.   Gaming Terminals: No more than six (6) video gaming terminals shall be
permitted in and upon the premises used or occupied as a place holding a valid
City issued liquor license if each of the following conditions is first met:
      1.   The use and placement thereof is in compliance with the provisions
of the Video Gaming Act, as amended; and
      2.   The use and placement thereof is in compliance with the provisions
of all rules promulgated by the Illinois Gaming Board pursuant to the Illinois
Administrative Procedures Act;
      3.   The terminal operator or agent of the operator:
         a.   Pays an annual video gaming permit fee in the amount established
by the City Manager as authorized by this Chapter.
         b.   The annual fee shall be due and payable upon application for
issuance or renewal. Permits shall be for not longer than a one-year period
from May 1 of each year to April 30 of each following year, unless sooner
revoked or suspended. All video gaming permits, regardless of date of issuance,
shall terminate on April 30 of each year following the date of issuance.
         c.   This fee is not in lieu of any fee or payment payable to the
State or the Illinois Gaming Board or of any liquor license fees otherwise due
and payable under this Chapter.
      4.   The licensee or agent of the licensee:
         a.   Files with their application a copy of the licensee’s written use
agreement with the terminal operator for placement of the video gaming
terminals and a copy of the license issued by the Illinois Gaming Board as well
as, to the extent possible, a copy of a diagram approved by the Illinois Gaming
Board that shows the authorized location of the terminals and which are not
visible from outside the licensee’s premises; and
         b.   Pays to the City an annual video gaming license fee plus an
annual video gaming terminal fee for each video gaming terminal upon the
premises all in the amounts established by the City Manager as authorized by
this Chapter; except for liquor license Classification C (club licenses) which
establishments shall pay no annual video gaming license permit fee and shall
pay an annual video gaming terminal fee in the amount of one hundred dollars
($100) for each video gaming terminal upon the premises.
         c.   The annual video gaming license fee and annual gaming terminal
fee shall be due and payable upon application for issuance or renewal. Licenses
shall be for not longer than a one-year period from May 1st of each year to
April 30th of each following year, unless sooner revoked or suspended. All
licenses, regardless of date of issuance, shall terminate on April 30th of each
year following the date of issuance.
         d.   This fee is not in lieu of any fee or payment payable to the
State or the Illinois Gaming Board or of any liquor license fees otherwise due
and payable under this Chapter.
      5.   In the event the total number of video gaming terminals at any
licensee site increase after the payment of any annual fee, the licensee and
Terminal Operator are jointly and severally responsible for notifying the City
of such change and for ensuring that the licensee and the Terminal Operator pay
any additional fees due to the City for such increase.
      6.   All truck stops of any sort approved for video gaming by the
Illinois Gaming Board, are subject to all of the provisions of this section and
responsible for paying all annual fees provided for within this section,
whether or not they hold a City-issued liquor license.
   D.   Hours Of Operation: No video gaming terminal that is permitted under
the provisions of this section may be played except during the legal hours of
operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the licensed
premises.
   E.   Signage: No video gaming signage or advertising of any type or size,
including, but not limited to, posters, paper signage, fliers, neon signage,
banners, video or audio feed, or any other form of advertisement, shall be
allowed on the exterior of the licensed establishment or on the inside of such
establishment if such signage is visible from the outside in any way including,
but not limited to, visibility through any window or door areas facing the
public way. Temporary exterior permitted signage would be exempted for a
business within sixty (60) days of original initiation of video gaming
operations.
   F.   Inspection: The City may inspect or cause the inspection of any place
or building in which any such terminal is operated or set up for operation to
ensure that the facilities are operated in a manner consistent with the public
health, safety and welfare and in a manner consistent with both State law and
regulations and City ordinances.
   G.   Video Gaming Cafes Prohibited.
      1.   A Video Gaming Café shall not be qualified to obtain a City liquor
license and is prohibited from becoming a licensed video gaming location within
the City. Further, no license allowing Video Gaming Cafes shall be created,
maintained or authorized by this Chapter. A Video Gaming Café is an
establishment for which the primary or a major focus of the establishment is
video gaming and the service of alcohol; food is secondary to the operation of
video gaming regardless of the percent of total gross revenue from gaming
operations. The following factors may be considered when determining if the
establishment is a Video Gaming Café:
         a.   The layout and design of the establishment;
         b.   The preparation and variety of food and beverages offered;
         c.   The creation and operation of a commercial kitchen on the premise
where gaming is situated;
         d.   The number of video gaming machines relative to the customer
seating capacity of the establishment;
         e.   The square footage of space devoted to video gaming relative to
the amount of space devoted to other activities;
         f.   The source of proposed or actual revenue derived from the
establishment;
         g.   The number of employees at the establishment and their proposed
function; and
         h.   Any other factors deemed relevant by the Commissioner.
      2.   The restrictions of this section related to Video Gaming Cafés will
not apply to existing license holders who have been issued their liquor license
with video gaming by the City prior to the addition of this section to the
City’s Code by this Ordinance No. 21-O-63 until such time as their liquor
licenses with video gaming lapse, terminate or otherwise end.
      3.   Upon the request of the Commissioner, as a condition of the grant or
renewal of a liquor license for an establishment offering video gaming or at
any time during the term of the license, any such license holder shall provide
financial, tax and operational records to the City sufficient to demonstrate
that they are not a Video Gaming Café. In the event it is determined by the
Commissioner that a license holder is operating as a Video Gaming Café, their
liquor license permitting video gaming shall be revoked in accordance with the
provisions of this Chapter or shall not be renewed; such a licensee may request
a hearing before the Commissioner to determine if they are eligible for a non-
gaming liquor license. For new applicants with no history of operations, they
must provide reasonable assurance to the satisfaction of the Commissioner that
they will not operate in violation of this section in their first year of
operations.
   H.   Banquet Hall/Event License with Video Gaming If the applicant/license
holder is the holder of an A-5 banquet hall/event license, any video gaming
license issued by the City shall only constitute a grant of authority to host
video gaming on their premises during hours when banquets or events are being
held. Video gaming must be ancillary to any banquet or event; gaming may not be
promoted as the primary purpose of any banquet or event; banquets and events
eligible for video gaming shall be those that are of an occasional nature and
shall not include banquets or events that are regularly scheduled or held open
to the public or to private parties for the primary purpose of permitting
alcohol service and gaming in a manner comparable to that of a bar, restaurant
or video gaming parlor.
   I.   Violation And Revocation: If a licensee violates any provision of the
Video Gaming Act or any provision related to video gaming terminals contained
in this section, such violation shall be deemed a violation of the licensee’s
liquor license. In addition, the Commissioner may revoke the City’s video
gaming terminal license for any violation of this section or of any ordinance
pertaining to the conduct of such business and may report any violations to the
Illinois State Gaming Board or other appropriate regulatory agency. (Ord. 15-O-
25, 4-21-2015; amd. Ord. 15-O-59, 10-6-2015, eff. 1-1-2016; Ord. 17-O-22, 3-7-
2017; Ord. 17-O-23, 3-7-2017; Ord. 17-O-36, 4-18-2017; Ord. 18-O-03, 1-16-2018;
Ord. 18-O-34, 5-15-2018; Ord. 19-O-10, 1-15-2019; Ord. 19-O-58, 7-16-2019; Ord.
20-O-37, 5-20-2020; Ord. 21-O-12, 2-16-2021; Ord. 21-O-26, 4-6-2021; Ord. 21-O-
41, 7-20-2021; Ord. 21-O-42, 8-3-2021; Ord. 21-O-44, 8-17-2021; Ord. 21-O-63,
12-7-2021; Ord. 23-O-51, 11-7-2023; Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023; Ord. 24-O-14, 2-
20-2024)
3.3.6: RULES OF GENERAL APPLICABILITY REGARDING LICENSES, NUMBER AND FEES:
   A.   The following rules apply to all liquor licenses and applicants for
liquor licenses within the City:
      1.   License as a Privilege not a Right: It is acknowledged that the
business of selling alcoholic liquors at retail (and of offering video gaming
at such an establishment) is a privilege, not a right. It is also acknowledged
that when not properly done, it is a business fraught with danger to the
community which raises peculiarly local problems pertaining to the public
health, safety and morals of the community. By establishing a maximum number of
liquor licenses in any particular classification (including those with video
gaming permitted), any license not yet created by the City Council shall not be
deemed to exist until such time as the City, by legislative action of the City
Council, has in fact created such a license. Accordingly, the City Council
hereby reserves the right in its sole discretion to create additional licenses
within any classification as it deems appropriate. Moreover, it is hereby
affirmed that the City, in its sole discretion, may determine from time to time
whether a moratorium in the creation of any new licenses shall be imposed to
promote, permit and regulate the orderly growth of liquor establishments (with
and without video gaming )in the City.
      2.   Alcohol Delivery: Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary in
the classifications described in part (B) of this section, retail liquor
license holders shall be permitted to deliver alcoholic liquor to purchasers
for use or consumption to the extent permitted by Illinois law. To the extent
that Illinois law permits delivery within the licensed retailer’s parking lot
and curbside delivery for pickup by a consumer, the City also shall permit such
retailers to offer walk-up window retail sales.
      3.   Special Events: The Liquor Commissioner may grant existing retail
license holders authority to host special events consistent with the
requirements of Classifications K and N or other special event-type licenses
within the discretion of the Commissioner, as provided in part (B) of this
section.
   B.   License Classifications:
      1.   There shall be an indefinite moratorium on the acceptance of all
liquor license applications (including those that include video gaming), except
for Class K, KK, and N licenses. The Commissioner is authorized to waive the
City’s moratorium for accepting new liquor license applications for any license
classification, on a case-by-case basis and at the Commissioner’s discretion.
      If the Commissioner chooses to waive the moratorium, the business may
apply, the City may accept such application and the application is then
processed by the Liquor Commissioner for eventual consideration by the City
Council of licensure. If the Commissioner does not grant a waiver to the
moratorium for an application, then the petitioner may appeal this decision to
the Woodstock City Council.
      2.   Liquor Classifications A, C, D, E and I may also be eligible for
video gaming authorization pursuant to Section 3.3.5 of this City Code. In that
instance, such licenses will be identified with a V immediately following the
liquor license classification. Like other liquor licenses of the City, the
total number of such licenses is fixed by ordinance. However, in the event such
a license holder relinquishes or loses their authority for video gaming for any
reason (but they have not otherwise lost their liquor license), then their
liquor license shall be reclassified within the same classification but without
the “V” designation, and the City Manager (or designee) shall adjust the list
of authorized licenses in Section C below accordingly. By way of example, if a
licensee with an A-1-V license chooses to stop offering video gaming in the
middle of a license year, the City Manager may revise the table in Section C
below to reflect one fewer A-1-V license and one additional A-1 license and may
re-issue their license for the remainder of the year as an A-1 liquor license.
      3.   Liquor licenses (including those with video gaming) shall be divided
into the following classifications.
Classes
      A    (Various Retail Service Licenses)
         Permits the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use on the
licensed premises and the retail sale of beer and wine by package. Class A
licenses shall be divided into the following subdivisions:
         A-1 (Tavern)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use
on licensed premises including a bar, but not incidental to the service of food
and the retail sale of beer and wine by package.
         A-2 (Restaurant)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use
on the premises of a restaurant, as well as the retail sale of beer and wine by
package. For the purposes of this class A-2, a restaurant must derive more than
forty percent (40%) of its gross revenue (on an annual basis) from the sale of
food. The determination of whether the forty percent (40%) gross revenue
standard has been met shall be made at the time of license renewal for the year
just ended. In the event a licensee has not possessed a class A-2 license for a
full year, the determination of whether the forty percent (40%) standard has
been met shall be deferred until the next license renewal period. The records
used to determine whether said forty percent (40%) standard has been met shall
include, but not be limited to, audited financial statements, corporate
financial reports, tax return information, state liquor license reports, or any
other form of information deemed acceptable by the city.
         A-4 (Golf club)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use
on the premises of a golf club and the retail sale of beer and wine by package.
         A-5 (Banquet hall/event venue)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use
on the premises of a banquet hall or event venue for public or private events
held or sponsored by the licensee or his client and the retail sale of beer and
wine by package.
         A-6 (Restaurant/caterer)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use
on the premises of a restaurant as well as the retail sale of beer and wine by
package; and permits the restaurant to also serve alcoholic liquors as an
incidental part of food service that serves prepared meals, either on or off
the licensed restaurant premises. For the purposes of this class A-6, a
restaurant must derive more than forty percent (40%) of its gross revenue (on
an annual basis) from the sale of food. The determination of whether the forty
percent (40%) gross revenue standard has been met shall be made at the time of
license renewal for the year just ended. In the event a licensee has not
possessed a class A-6 license for a full year, the determination of whether the
forty percent (40%) standard has been met shall be deferred until the next
license renewal period. The records used to determine whether said forty
percent (40%) standard has been met shall include, but not be limited to,
audited financial statements, corporate financial reports, tax return
information, state liquor license reports, or any other form of information
deemed acceptable by the city.
         A-7 (Restaurant/caterer/brewpub)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use
on the premises of a restaurant/brewpub, the retail sale of beer and wine by
package, and the service of alcoholic liquors as an incidental part of food
services either on or off the licensed restaurant/brewpub premises. Also
permits the manufacture of beer, only on the premises specified in the license;
the sale of beer manufactured on the premises to importing distributors,
distributors and to nonlicensees for use and consumption; the storage of
manufactured beer upon the premises; and retail sale of the beer manufactured
on the premises of a restaurant/brewpub.
      B   (Permits the retail sale by package).
         B-1a (Liquor Store with no bar)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by package only, but
not for consumption or use on the licensed premises, where more than 30 percent
(30%) of the public sales area is devoted to alcoholic liquor.
         B-1b (Combined Liquor Store with small bar)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by package where more
than thirty percent (30%) of the public sales is devoted to alcoholic liquor.
Also permits the consumption or use on the licensed premises at a small bar
with eight or fewer seats and with no more than three (3) alcoholic drinks
served per customer during a single seating.
         B-2 (Convenience store)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by package only, but
not for consumption or use on the licensed premises, where no more than thirty
percent (30%) of public sales area is devoted to alcoholic liquor.
         B-3 (Major retail/grocery stores, liquor generally)
            Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by package only, but
not for consumption or use on the licensed premises, where no more than ten
percent (10%) of the public sales area is devoted to alcoholic liquor.
         B-3a (Major retail/grocery stores)
            Permits the retail sale, service and consumption of alcoholic
liquor by package or use on the licensed premises, where no more than ten
percent (10%) of the public sales area is devoted to alcoholic liquor.
Alcoholic beverages must be consumed in the seating area, conference room or on
the secured outdoor patio. This also includes the consumption of alcoholic
beverages on the premises during tasting events.
         B-4a (Nonconvenience specialty store with consumption of wine only)
            Permits the retail sale of beer and wine by package, the retail
sale of wine for consumption or use on the premises, and the sampling of beer
and wine, with or without the service of food, on premises maintaining no bar
for the sale of alcoholic liquor.
         B-4b (Nonconvenience specialty store with consumption of beer and wine
only)
            Permits the retail sale of beer and wine by package, the retail
sale of beer and wine for consumption or use on the premises, and the sampling
of beer and wine, with or without the service of food, on premises maintaining
no bar for the sale of alcoholic liquor.
         B-4c (Nonconvenience specialty store with consumption of alcohol).
            Permits the retail sale of beer, wine and alcoholic spirits by
package, the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use on the
premises, and the sampling of beer, wine and alcoholic spirits with or without
the service of food, on premises maintaining no bar for the sale of alcoholic
liquor.
         B-5 (Nonconvenience specialty store)
            Permits the retail sale of beer and wine by package only, but not
for consumption or use on the licensed premises, and the sampling of beer and
wine on premises maintaining no bar or area reserved exclusively for the sale
of alcoholic liquor.
         B-6 (Gas station/convenience store)
            Permits the retail sale of beer and wine by package only in a
convenience store associated with the distribution and sales of gasoline and
where no more than thirty percent (30%) of the public sales area is devoted to
beer and wine.
         B-7 (Major retail/grocery stores - beer and wine only)
            Permits the retail sale of beer and wine by package only, but not
for consumption or use on the licensed premises, where no more than ten percent
(10%) of the public sales area is devoted to alcoholic liquor.
         B-8 (Nonconvenience specialty store with low volume sales)
            Permits the low volume retail sale of beer and wine by package
only, but not for consumption or use on the licensed premises, and the sampling
of beer and wine on premises maintaining no bar or area reserved exclusively
for the sale of alcoholic liquor where no more than twenty five percent (25%)
of the public sales area is devoted to alcoholic liquor and where the annual
sales for alcoholic liquor totals seventy five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) or
less. The determination that the sales restriction has not been exceeded shall
be made at the time of license renewal for the year just ended and records used
to make this determination shall be in any form deemed acceptable by the City.
This license also allows the transfer of a portion of beer and wine inventory
from the licensed premises to the premises of a special event for sales or
sampling but not for consumption.
         B-9 (Brewpub, distillery, vintner, or winery license)
            Permits the retail sale by package of beer or wine or alcoholic
liquor produced at the licensed production facilities of a small business
location of a brewpub, distillery, vintner or winery and the sampling of said
products. This license also permits the transfer of a portion of the produced
beer or wine or alcoholic inventory from the licensed premises to the premises
of a special event or the Woodstock Farmers’ Market for sampling and retail
sale of packaged beer or wine or alcoholic liquor.
      C   (Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by a club licensed for
consumption or use on the licensed premises only).
         C-1 (Larger club)
            Organizations with more than one thousand (1,000) members.
         C-2 (Club)
            Organizations with less than one thousand (1,000) members.
      D   (Restaurant with no bar).
         Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use on
the licensed premises, incidental to the sale of food in premises maintaining
no barroom, tavern, lounge, or other area reserved exclusively for the sale of
alcoholic liquor. For the purposes of this class D, a restaurant must derive
more than forty percent (40%) of its gross revenue (on an annual basis) from
the sale of food. The determination of whether the forty percent (40%) gross
revenue standard has been met shall be made at the time of license renewal for
the year just ended. In the event a licensee has not possessed a class D
license for a full year, the determination of whether the forty percent (40%)
standard has been met shall be deferred until the next license renewal period.
The records used to determine whether said forty percent (40%) standard has
been met shall include, but not be limited to, audited financial statements,
corporate financial reports, tax return information, state liquor license
reports, or any other form of information deemed acceptable by the city.
      E-1   (Restaurant with no bar/beer and wine only)
         Permits the retail sale of beer and wine only for consumption or use
on the licensed premises, incidental to the sale of food, on premises
maintaining no barroom, tavern, lounge or other area reserved exclusively for
the retail sale of beer and wine on said premises. For the purposes of this
class E-1, a restaurant must derive more than forty percent (40%) of its gross
revenue (on an annual basis) from the sale of food. The determination of
whether the forty percent (40%) gross revenue standard has been met shall be
made at the time of license renewal for the year just ended. In the event a
licensee has not possessed a class E-1 license for a full year, the
determination of whether the forty percent (40%) standard has been met shall be
deferred until the next license renewal period. The records used to determine
whether said forty percent (40%) standard has been met shall include, but not
be limited to, audited financial statements, corporate financial reports, tax
return information, state liquor license reports, or any other form of
information deemed acceptable by the city.
      E-2 (Restaurant/caterer with no bar/beer and wine only)
         Permits the licensee to serve beer and wine as an incidental part of
food service that serves prepared meals, either on or off the licensed
premises. For the purposes of this class E-2, a restaurant must derive more
than forty percent (40%) of its gross revenue (on an annual basis) from the
sale of food. The determination of whether the forty percent (40%) gross
revenue standard has been met shall be made at the time of license renewal for
the year just ended. In the event a licensee has not possessed a class E-
2 license for a full year, the determination of whether the forty percent (40%)
standard has been met shall be deferred until the next license renewal period.
The records used to determine whether said forty percent (40%) standard has
been met shall include, but not be limited to, audited financial statements,
corporate financial reports, tax return information, state liquor license
reports, or any other form of information deemed acceptable by the city.
      E-3 (No restaurant, with small portable bar carts, service counters and a
small bar)
         Permits the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use on the
licensed premises with service counters and a small bar with a lounge, or other
areas reserved exclusively for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, and also
permits the sale of alcoholic liquor from small portable bar carts throughout
the premises.
      E-4 (Specialty restaurant with small bar)
         Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, beer and wine, with or
without the service of food, for consumption or use on the licensed premises of
a specialty restaurant maintaining a small bar with eight (8) or fewer seats,
and the retail sale of beer and wine by package. For the purposes of this class
E-4, a restaurant must derive more than forty percent (40%) of its gross
revenue (on an annual basis) from the sale of food. The determination of
whether the forty percent (40%) gross revenue standard has been met shall be
made at the time of license renewal for the year just ended. In the event a
licensee has not possessed a class E-4 license for a full year, the
determination of whether the forty percent (40%) standard has been met shall be
deferred until the next license renewal period. The records used to determine
whether said forty percent (40%) standard has been met shall include, but not
be limited to, audited financial statements, corporate financial reports, tax
return information, state liquor license reports, or any other form of
information deemed acceptable by the city.
      E-5 (Hotel small bar and in-room minibar)
         Permits the retail sale and service of alcoholic liquor for
consumption or use on the licensed premises maintaining a small bar with eight
(8) or fewer seats and/or portable bar cart, and the retail sale of individual
units of alcoholic liquor for consumption or use on the licensed premises from
in-room minibars.
      E-6 (Movie theater)
         Permits the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the
licensed premises where the primary business is that of a movie theater (a
business that regularly shows motion pictures/films), subject to the following
conditions:
         1.   Sales of alcoholic liquor shall be limited to times at which the
business is open either to show regularly scheduled motion pictures or films,
or for special motion picture or film showings scheduled at the business. Under
no circumstances may alcoholic liquor be served more than one-half (1/2) hour
prior to (i) the advertised time of the first motion picture or film showing on
any day, or (ii) a scheduled special showing, and service of alcoholic liquor
must cease one-half (1/2) hour prior to the completion of the last showing.
However, if this conflicts with the City’s Liquor Control Code (section
3.3.10), then the open and/or closing hours identified in section 3.3.10 shall
supersede.
         2.   Food service must be available at all times that alcoholic liquor
is available for purchase on the premises.
         3.   No seats or stools for patrons to sit upon shall be included at
any service point from which sales of alcoholic liquor on the premises are made
except for movie theater seats.
         4.   The licensee shall sell only beer, wine, and mixed cocktails in
single-serving sized containers, although such single-servings of such
alcoholic liquor may be poured into a unique plastic cup option, different in
color, size and design than those in which non-alcoholic drinks are served.
         5.   The licensee shall not serve or deliver more than two (2) of the
single-serving sized servings of alcoholic liquor to a person at a time and no
person shall have in his/her possession at any given time more than two (2)
such servings.
      F   Repealed.
      G   Repealed.
      H   (Wholesaler)
         Wholesale delivery license permits the retail sale of beer and wine
only, but not for consumption or use on the licensed premises and where
delivery to the customer is in the original package container by mail or by
common carrier, upon the following conditions:
         1.   There shall be no bar, lounge, taproom or other sales floor on
the licensed premises;
         2.   There shall be no outdoor advertising of the licensed premises;
and
         3.   There shall be no mandatory closing time.
      I   (Brewery/brewpub)
         Permits the retail sale of beer manufactured on the premises of a
brewery/brewpub specified in the license for consumption or use on or off the
licensed premises including a bar, but not incidental to the service of food
and permits the retail sale of wine by package and for consumption or use on
the premises of a brewery/brewpub; the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for
consumption or use on licensed premises; the retail sale and storage of the
manufactured beer by package on or off the licensed premises; and the sale of
beer manufactured on the licensed premises to distributors, licensed retailers
and non-licensees for sale, use and/or consumption. Further the license permits
a single guest tap for the retail sale of craft beer or alcoholic cider not
manufactured on the licensed premises for consumption on premises.
      J   (Caterer)
         Permits the holder to serve alcoholic liquors as an incidental part of
a food service that serves prepared meals which excludes the serving of snacks
as the primary meal either on or off site whether licensed or unlicensed by a
caterer retailer.
      K   (Special Event/for retail license holders/3 types)
         The Commissioner shall have sole discretion to issue a retailer
special event license that permits a licensed Illinois retailer to transfer a
portion of its inventory from the retail licensed premises to a designated site
for a special event. (Special event license, retailer)
         An applicant for a K special event license must submit with the
application satisfactory proof of the dramshop liability insurance required of
all liquor license applicants and shall meet such other requirements or
conditions as may be imposed by the Commissioner in the interests of the
public’s health, safety and welfare.
         Any request for a K special event license for an event in the City’s
public ways must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Commissioner that,
except for the liquor license, they have obtained all other necessary City
approvals for such an event.
         The Commissioner will provide routine reporting to the City Council.
         There shall be three (3) types of K liquor licenses as follows:
         K-1a:   Events sponsored by or for the benefit of a not-for-profit
organization where transferred alcoholic liquor shall be offered for
consumption or use on the designated site. (Not-for-profit daily special event
license for on-site consumption or use.)
         K-1b.15:   Events sponsored by or for the benefit of a not-for-profit
organization where transferred alcoholic liquor shall be offered for
consumption or use on the designated site. (Not-for-profit annual special event
license for on-site consumption or use, with a maximum permitted amount of
fifteen (15) such daily special events annually.)
         K-1b.30:   Events sponsored by or for the benefit of a not-for-profit
organization where transferred alcoholic liquor shall be offered for
consumption or use on the designated site. (Not-for-profit annual special event
license for on-site consumption or use, with a maximum permitted amount of
thirty (30) such daily special events annually.)
         K-2   Events held to promote a commercial undertaking and/or any for-
profit event where transferred alcoholic liquor shall be offered for
consumption or use on the designated site. (For-profit special event for on-
site consumption or use)
         K-3   Events held by an Illinois licensed retailer where transferred
package beer and wine inventory will be offered for sale by package, but not
for consumption, apart from reasonable sampling, on the designated site.
(Retailer special event beer and wine package sale only/no consumption)
      KK    (Chamber of Commerce)
         Permits the Commissioner may issue a Chamber of Commerce business
mixer permit to the chamber which allows the chamber or a host business to
purchase alcoholic liquors to sell for use or consumption on premises at
business mixers sponsored by the chamber, but not for external resale in any
form. This permit also allows the Chamber of Commerce to engage a licensed
Illinois retailer to transfer a portion of its alcoholic inventory from its
retail licensed premises and to offer for sale such transferred alcoholic
liquor for use or consumption on premises at business mixers, but not for
external resale in any form. A total of up to thirty-six (36) business mixers
may be held in any one calendar year under a Chamber of Commerce business mixer
permit, and only at or by businesses approved by the Woodstock Chamber of
Commerce.
         The Commissioner may also issue up to twelve (12) pre-approved
community event permits per calendar year which allow the Chamber of Commerce
to purchase alcoholic liquors to offer for sale by package or for use or
consumption on premises or in the public way, as determined in the approval
process. This permit also allows the Chamber of Commerce to engage a licensed
Illinois retailer to transfer a portion of its alcoholic inventory from its
retail licensed premises and to offer for sale such transferred alcoholic
liquor for use or consumption on premises or in the public way, as determined
in the approval process.
         Upon issuance of the Chamber of Commerce business mixer permit and
pre- approved community event permits, the Chamber of Commerce assumes
responsibility for providing proper security at each mixer or event to ensure
only those aged twenty-one (21) years and older are served and that no one is
overserved. The Chamber of Commerce shall annually submit to the City
satisfactory proof of the dramshop liability insurance required of all liquor
license applicants.
      L   (Armory)
         Repealed.
      M   Repealed.
      N   (Special event license, non-retailer/not-for-profit)
         The Commissioner shall have sole discretion to issue a non-retailer/
not-for-profit special event license that permits any lodge, veterans’
organization, civic organization or other similar not-for-profit organization,
to sell beer and wine at any picnic, club, or similar function sponsored by
such organization or club.
         An applicant for an N special event license must submit with the
application satisfactory proof of dramshop liability insurance to the maximum
statutory limits and shall meet such other requirements or conditions as may be
imposed by the Commissioner in the interests of the public’s health, safety and
welfare.
         Any request for an N special event license for an event in the City’s
public ways must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Commissioner that,
except for the liquor license, they have obtained all other necessary City
approvals for such an event.
         The Commissioner will provide routine reporting to the City Council.
      V   (Video gaming supplement)
         A supplemental license that permits an existing Class A, C, D and E
liquor license holder to conduct video gaming on the licensed premises in a
manner consistent with State law and section
3.3.5 of this chapter.
      BYOB   (Restaurant license allowing BYOB)
         1.   A BYOB license shall permit alcoholic liquor to be consumed only
in conjunction with the purchase and consumption of a meal (and not merely
appetizers or dessert).
         2.   A BYOB license shall limit consumption of alcoholic liquor to no
more than one (1) seven hundred-fifty-milliliter bottle of wine, or thirty-six
(36) ounces of beer, or two (2) one-and-one-half-ounce servings of spirits per
patron.
         3.   A BYOB license shall limit consumption of alcoholic liquor to the
licensed premises. An opened bottle of alcohol . may not be removed from the
premises but must be disposed of before the customer leaves the premises.
         4.   BYOB licensees may provide glassware and ice to patrons, and may
uncork, pour, serve, or otherwise control the consumption of the alcoholic
liquor, so long as anyone performing the service of alcoholic liquor is over
age 21 and has a valid BASSET certificate as required for all license holders
under this Chapter.
         5.   BYOB licensees may charge a fee for uncorking, pouring, serving,
or otherwise controlling consumption of the alcoholic liquor to patrons who
bring alcoholic liquor on the BYOB licensee’s premises for consumption on said
premises.
         6.   Possession and/or consumption of alcoholic liquor by any person
under age twenty-one (21) is prohibited.
         7.   For the purpose of this section, a “full-service restaurant” is
defined as a food service establishment, with interior seating at tables or
booths for a minimum of twenty-five (25) customers, where food is ordered from
a full menu and orders are taken directly from a customer’s table by restaurant
wait staff and served directly to a customer’s table.
         8.   The applicant must satisfy all the applicable liquor license
application requirements of this Chapter including but not limited to the
insurance requirements (or comparable, sufficient, general liability or other
appropriate insurance coverage), all prohibitions related to alcohol sales to
those under 21, requirements regarding hours of operation, and other
requirements of this Chapter.
         9.   The BYOB permit is not considered by the City to make the holder
a -”licensed establishment” under the Illinois Video Gaming Act.
   C.   License Amounts and Fees.

   2.   Reduction in the Number of Liquor Licenses, If a license of any class
is revoked, expires without renewal, is surrendered by the licensee, or is
otherwise terminated pursuant to this Chapter, the total number of licenses
available in that class automatically shall be reduced by that license without
further action required by the City Council.
   D.   Midyear License Applicants: Any applicant seeking a license under this
chapter between May 1 and August 31 of the same year shall pay the required
license fee in subsection C of this section. Any applicant seeking a license
between September 1 and December 31 of the same year shall pay the equivalent
of two-thirds (2/3) of the applicable license fee in subsection C of this
section. Any applicant seeking a license between January 1 and April 30 of the
same year shall pay the equivalent of one-third (1/3) of the applicant license
fee in subsection C of this section.
   E.   Late Filing Penalty: Liquor license annual renewal application packets
shall be submitted to the Office of the Mayor no later than five (5) business
days prior to the renewal date of each year. Unless waived by the Commissioner
or the Commissioner’s designee, a penalty of twenty-five dollars daily shall be
assessed for each day the completed renewal application packet is late.

3.3.7: PRIVILEGE GRANTED BY LICENSE:
A license issued under this chapter shall be purely a personal privilege good
for not to exceed one year after issuance, unless sooner revoked, as in this
chapter provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to
attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or
transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or
hypothecated. Such license shall not descend by laws of testate or intestate
devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that
executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the
trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in
part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic
liquor under the order of the appropriate court and may exercise the privileges
of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such
decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy, until the expiration of such
license but not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or
insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of that portion of the
license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be prevented from
operating under such license in accordance with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 15-O-25, 4-21-2015; amd. Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.8: TERM OF LICENSES:
   A.   A license is purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one
year from the date of issuance. The one-year period shall be from May 1 of each
year to April 30 of each following year, unless sooner revoked or suspended or
unless installment payments are not received as provided for in subsection C of
this section. Licenses issued after May 1 of any year shall pay the prorated
fee as provided for in subsection 3.3.6E of this chapter.
   B.   All licenses, regardless of the date of issuance, shall terminate on
April 30 of each year following the date of issuance.
   C.   For Licensees for whom the annual license fee is one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) or more, at the discretion of the Commissioner may pay for the
license in two (2) installments. The first installment will be due with the
application for renewal; the second installment will be due no later than
October 31. If any installment is not received by the due date, the license in
question will be suspended as of twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight on that date.
Reinstatement of said license is subject to payment of the installment(s), and
payment of a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) as determined by
and at the sole discretion of the Commissioner. (Ord. 15-O-25, 4-21-2015; amd.
Ord. 22-O-22, 4-19-2022; Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.9: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   Any licensee must complete such renewal application as required by the
Commissioner. Renewal applicants must continue to meet the requirements for an
initial issue of a liquor license, but the City Council reserves the right to
decrease the number of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction and
renewal is not a vested right of any applicant.
   B.   Any licensee seeking a renewal of an A-2, A-6, D, E-1, E-2 or E-
4 liquor license, but that is not qualified for the license because it did not
meet the standard of deriving more than forty percent (40%) of its gross
revenue from food, may apply for a probationary license, for up to 7 months,
the length of which shall be decided at the discretion of the Commissioner, in
order to try to bring its operation into compliance with the forty percent
(40%) standard.
      1.   Any application for such a probationary license must be accompanied
by a written business plan detailing how the licensee plans to bring its
business into compliance with and thereafter continue to meet the forty percent
(40%) standard. Because such a probationary license is intended to give the
licensee the opportunity to come into compliance and thereafter remain in
compliance with the forty percent (40%) standard, such a probationary license
i) may only be extended by the Commissioner two times if the Commissioner finds
that the probationary licensee has been making reasonable efforts and
reasonable progress toward meeting that goal; or ii) may only be granted two
times (not including extensions) by the Commissioner in a ten year period to
any licensee. In any other circumstance, requests for renewed or extended
probationary licenses can only be granted by the City Council. The Commissioner
shall have the authority to require records necessary to document ongoing
progress toward the forty percent (40%) standard, and may revoke any
probationary license if, in the opinion of the Commissioner, reasonable
progress toward this goal is not being made.
      2.   During the term of the probationary license, any violation by the
licensee of any state laws or local ordinance regulating the sale and/or
service of alcohol may be considered by the Commissioner -as grounds for
revocation of the probationary license.
      3.   The granting of a probationary license shall not be construed as a
vested right, but rather is a remedial opportunity to bring the business into
compliance for a liquor license for which the licensee does not currently
qualify.
      4.   Whether or not to issue or deny a probationary license shall be
within the discretion of the Commissioner who may consider any factors relevant
to the initial issuance of a liquor license to ensure the probationary license
is only granted to applicants who would otherwise be eligible for an A-2 or A-
6 license.
      5.   One month before the expiration of the probationary license period,
the licensee shall submit records required in section B.2 of Article 3.3.6 for
the Commissioner to determine whether the licensee has become eligible for
renewal of its liquor license. The records submitted must cover the licensee’s
sales for the four (4) most recent months, although the licensee may pick any
two (2) months within that probationary period to demonstrate to the
satisfaction of the Commissioner that it has and can reasonably be expected to
continue to meet the forty percent (40%) requirement. If the Commissioner
determines that the licensee has otherwise complied with all other license
requirements and has made good faith and material progress toward satisfaction
of the forty percent (40%) requirement without yet reaching that threshold, the
Commissioner may extend the probationary period up to, but not in excess of,
the annual renewal date for all liquor license holders.
      6.   For purposes of the City’s number of A-2, A-6, D, E-1, E-2, and E-
4 liquor licenses issued, a probationary license shall not be considered a new
or different license. Rather, it is the intent of this section that it shall
continue to be the same license previously held by the applicant, but it shall
be a license that has been renewed only subject to these additional
probationary terms. Such license may be revoked at the end of any probationary
period (or extended period) if the license standards have not been met. (Ord.
15-O-25, 4-21-2015; amd. Ord. 22-O-10, 2-16-2022; Ord. 23-O-22, 4-18-2023; Ord.
23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.10: CLOSING HOURS:
   A.   No person shall sell or offer for sale any alcoholic liquor in the city
between the hours of one o’clock (1:00) A.M. and six o’clock (6:00) A.M. on any
day, with the exception of Friday night, Saturday night, and nights prior to
holidays. “Holidays” are New Year’s Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor
Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day in the city of Woodstock, McHenry
County, Illinois, and the closing hours on those nights shall be two o’clock
(2:00) A.M.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to keep open for business, or to admit persons to
any premises licensed under these rules for the retail sale of alcoholic
liquors during the hours within which the sale of alcoholic liquors is
prohibited or to permit or allow persons to remain in or about the licensed
premises either before or after the hours designated within which the sale and
consumption of alcoholic liquor is prohibited on the licensed premises;
provided, however, that restaurants, clubs, drugstores, retail grocery stores
and hotels may keep their place of business open, subject only to the
provisions that no sale at retail of alcoholic liquors or the consumption by
persons of alcoholic liquors shall be permitted or allowed on said licensed
premises during the hours prohibited.
   C.   The hours mentioned herein shall be Central Standard Time except when
daylight saving time is in effect, and then said hours shall be Central
Daylight-Saving Time. (Ord. 15-O-25, 4-21-2015; Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.11: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic
liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school (other than an
institution of higher learning), hospital, home for aged or indigent persons or
for veterans, their spouses or children or any military or naval station;
provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering restaurant
service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food shops or other
places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal business carried
on, or if the church or school has been established since the issuance of the
original license. Notwithstanding any provision of this Section to the
contrary, the Commissioner may grant an exemption to the prohibitions in this
Section.
   B.   No license shall be issued to any person for the sale at retail of any
alcoholic liquor at any store or other place of business where the majority of
customers are minors of school age or where the principal business transacted
consists of schoolbooks, school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for such
minors.
   C.   Licenses issued hereunder apply only to the premises described in the
application and in the license issued thereon, and only one location shall be
so described in each license. After a license has been granted for particular
premises, the Commissioner, upon proper showing, may endorse upon said license
permission to:
      1.   Abandon the premises therein described and remove therefrom to other
premises approved by the Commissioner; or
      2.   Expand the existing licensed premises into additional, adjoining
space, but in order to obtain such approval, the licensee shall file with the
Commissioner a request in writing and a statement under oath which shall show
that the premises to which removal or expansion is to be made comply in all
respects with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 15-O-25, 4-21-2015; amd.
Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023; Ord. 24-O-28, 5-7-2024)
3.3.12: VIEWS INTO BUILDING REQUIRED:
   A.   Unless otherwise approved by the Commissioner:
      1.   In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption
upon the premises is licensed, other than as a restaurant, hotel or club, no
screen, blind, curtain, partition, opaque glass, article or thing (including
any advertising or signage of any type and any video gaming devices) shall be
permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises, nor
inside such premises, which prevents a clear view into the interior of such
licensed premises from the street or sidewalk at all times.
      2.   To the extent that the rules and regulations governing the Video
Gaming Act, provide that video gaming areas must have restricted visibility
from outside the business then these licensed premises should comply with this
subsection to the maximum extent possible in a manner consistent with the video
gaming regulations and the public health, safety and welfare.
   B.   All rooms where liquor is sold for consumption upon the premises shall
be continuously lighted during business hours by natural light or artificial
light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly
visible.
   C.   In case the view into any such licensed premises required by the
foregoing provisions shall be obscured or obstructed or if the Commissioner
believes improved sight-lines into the premises are in the interests of
improved public health, safety and welfare, the Commissioner can order that
obstructions be removed or modified to address those concerns. Failure to
comply with such an order shall subject the license to revocation as provided
in section 3.3.17 of this chapter.
   D.   In order to enforce the provisions of this section, the commissioner
shall have the right to require the filing with him of plans, drawings and
photographs showing the clearance of the view as above required. (Ord. 15-O-25,
4-21-2015; amd. Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.13: SANITARY REQUIREMENTS:
All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage
of such liquor for such sale shall be kept and operated in a clean and sanitary
condition, and shall be kept in full compliance with the laws of Illinois and
the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or
sale of food for human consumption and the service in such an establishment.
(Ord. 15-O-25, 4-21-2015; amd. Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.13.5: PUBLIC SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   In addition to any other requirements contained in this Chapter, no
licensee (including their employees and agents) shall permit or allow any
illegal activity on the licensed premises. It is the duty and responsibility of
each licensee (including their employees and agents) to maintain the licensed
premises in a peaceable and orderly manner so as not to allow any patron,
employee, or member of the public on the licensed premises to commit any
criminal act or any act which is done in an unreasonable manner so as to alarm
or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace.
   B.   It is the affirmative duty of a licensee (including their employees and
agents) to report promptly to the police department all illegal activity
reported to or observed by the licensee on or within sight of the licensed
premises; to answer fully and truthfully all questions of an identified police
officer who inquires or investigates concerning persons or events in or around
the licensed business; to cooperate with the police in any such inquiry or
investigation, including the giving of oral or written statements to the police
at reasonable times and locations in the course of investigations and sharing
any relevant video or other recording made on the premises; to sign a complaint
against any person whom the licensee observes in any illegal conduct or
activity on or within sight of the licensed premises; and to cooperate with the
police in taking recommended steps to reduce the likelihood of any future
unlawful activities.
   C.   Video Recording Requirements: Prior to the commencement of operations,
all A-1 license categories (with the exception of H, J, K, KK, and N), shall be
required to install and use surveillance camera technology that complies, at a
minimum, with the following requirements:
      1.   The Commissioner shall require license holders to file with their
initial application plans, drawings and photographs showing compliance with the
requirements of this section and may require all license holders to file such
material at other times on the Commissioner’s initiative or upon the request of
the Chief of Police.
      2.   The Commissioner, at the recommendation of the Chief of Police, or
their designee, when appropriate in the interests of the public health, safety
and/or welfare, can determine if a license holder in any category previously
identified as being exempt from this specific Section should be subject to the
provisions of this Section as a condition of their license.
      3.   The surveillance system required by this Section shall be subject to
inspection by the Chief of Police (or their designee) who may require recording
of any location on the premises where the Chief of Police (or their designee)
concludes that public safety considerations require the placement of video
surveillance cameras. The Chief of Police (or his or her designee) must approve
the video surveillance system before any liquor license may be approved or
renewed.
      4.   The cameras shall be sufficiently light sensitive and provide
sufficient image resolution (supported by additional lighting, if necessary) to
produce easily discernible images.
      5.   The images recorded by each camera shall be capable of being viewed
and reproduced for or readily accessible for third-party review and copying
using commonly available digital technology. The licensee shall have a person
on staff or otherwise available, without undue delay, capable of operating the
required cameras to produce any requested recorded image(s) and to reproduce
them for third-party review and copying. If the video surveillance system is
web-enabled or has wireless capability, upon request, the Police Department
shall be provided the ability to access the live system upon initiation by the
establishment during incidents requiring a police response or intervention.
      6.   The cameras shall not have any audio capability.
      7.   The cameras shall be maintained in good working condition.
      8.   The cameras shall be operational at all times that the licensee is
open for business to the public. The license holder must report promptly to the
City Clerk, or their designee, any time when any camera or video recording/
surveillance equipment is not properly operating, and the license holder must
ensure that repairs are completed in a reasonable timeframe. Multiple or
extended camera failures or the failure to report inoperable equipment can be
subject to fines as well as suspension(s) and/or license termination at the
discretion of the Commissioner.
      9.   All recordings made by the required cameras shall be indexed by date
and time; shall be preserved by the licensee for at least thirty (30) days in a
manner accessible only to authorized personnel.
      10.   All recordings made by the required cameras, upon request, shall be
made available by the licensee for inspection by (i) the police department
without undue delay and within 24 hours of any request (or sooner in the event
of exigent circumstances where the police identify an immediate safety
concern), (ii) the Commissioner, or (iii) by other authorized government
personnel.
      11.   The licensee shall post signage, in a conspicuous manner and at
appropriate locations, notifying the public that (i) video surveillance cameras
are in operation; and (ii) such surveillance camera footage may be provided to
the police.
      12.   The license holder must obtain written permission from the Chief of
Police in order to change any previously approved video surveillance system.
      13.   The Chief of Police, or their designee, is authorized to require
reasonable modifications to any video surveillance system if, in the opinion of
the Chief of Police, such modification is appropriate in the interests of the
public health, safety and/or welfare.
      14.   The Chief of Police, or their designee, is authorized to conduct
random compliance checks to ensure the requirements of this section are being
met.
      15.   Any decision of the Chief of Police, or their designee, can be
appealed to the City Manager in writing within 10 business days.
      16.   The implementation of this Section will be effective with the May
1st, 2025 liquor license renewal, unless it is otherwise determined by the
Chief of Police that, in the interests of the public health, safety and/or
welfare, an individual licensee (including those otherwise exempt) should be
required to comply earlier, after reasonable notice to the licensee, on a date
to be determined by the Chief of Police.
   D.   Failure of the licensee (including their employees and agents) to
comply with the requirements of this section (and to staff their business and
train their employees and agents in a manner reasonably sufficient to
facilitate such compliance) shall be grounds for a fine, a suspension or the
revocation of the licensee’s license for the premises. (Ord. 23-O-22, 4-18-
2023; amd. Ord. 23-O-62, 12-19-2023)
3.3.14: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Peddling: No person shall peddle alcoholic liquor in the city.
   B.   Sales: No licensee under this chapter shall sell alcoholic liquor to
any person under the age of twenty one (21), or to any intoxicated person, or
to any person known by him or her to be under legal disability or in need of
mental treatment, or harbor or permit any intoxicated persons to loiter on the
premises described in the license or permit any conduct which shall tend to
disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood, or the premises.
   C.   Public Consumption:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any-”alcoholic
liquor”, as defined by this chapter upon or about-any street, sidewalk or
public thoroughfare, except to the extent the Commissioner waives the
enforcement of this section pursuant to a request by a licensee -or unless
specifically authorized by the Commissioner for City permitted special events
and other City authorized events. The Commissioner may limit any such
authorization to beer and/or wine only..
      2.   As a condition of being granted this waiver, the licensee shall
comply with all requirements imposed by the city regarding screening, sound
amplification and location. The licensee shall also comply with all insurance
requirements pursuant to subsection
3.3.3D of this chapter and shall make the city an additional insured party
under the licensee’s liquor liability insurance.
   D.   Adult Business and Bodily Contact Prohibitions:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning or operating
a commercial establishment located within the city, at which alcoholic
beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises, to permit or
allow the following activity to be conducted on the premises of such a
commercial establishment, all of which activity is defined in section
3.13.1 of this title: “adult business”; “adult entertainment center”; adults
only activity, bookstore, motion picture theater, nightclub, sauna; “nudity”;
obscene activity; “rap parlor”; “sadomasochistic activity”; or sexual conduct
activity.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any establishment defined as an adult
business pursuant to the Woodstock zoning ordinance to sell, distribute or
permit beer or alcoholic beverages on the premises.
      3.   Employees shall not have bodily contact with patrons and patrons
shall not be permitted to purchase beverages for employees. For purposes of
this subsection D, the term “employees” shall include independent contractors
performing services on the licensed premises and employees of any independent
contractors performing services on the licensed premises.
   E.   Prohibition Of Disturbance Of The Peace: It shall be unlawful for any
licensee, individually or through his or her agents or employees, to allow
intoxicated persons to loiter on or about that part of the premises described
in the license which part is in use by or in view of the general public, or
permit any conduct which shall tend to disturb the people or quiet of the
neighborhood or the premises.
   F.   Prohibition Of Gambling: It shall be unlawful for any licensee
hereunder to permit or allow any gambling or betting of any money in or about
the licensed premises except in a manner consistent with all federal law, with
the Illinois video gaming act 1  and any rules or regulations enacted
thereunder, and with the provisions of this Chapter, or unless otherwise
permitted pursuant to state law or City Ordinance, such as for raffles
permitted under Title 3, Chapter 5 of the City Code, as may be amended.
   G.   Permit Required for Outdoor Sound Amplification: It shall be unlawful
for any licensee to permit or allow any noise or sound to be amplified outside
the bounds of a structure on the premises without a permit for such use issued
by the City’s Commissioner. Such a permit may contain such conditions as the
City’s Commissioner determines are appropriate for mitigating the impact of
such noise or sound on the City’s residents and businesses. The City’s
Commissioner may determine the length of any such permit and may modify the
conditions of any permit if the City’s Commissioner reasonably determines that
the impact of such sound has not been sufficiently mitigated by the conditions
imposed in the permit.
   H.   Food Trucks: No license holder shall sponsor, advertise, work in
conjunction with, or otherwise promote the presence of Mobile Food Truck
Vendors on or adjacent to their premises or in association with their
operations, without ensuring that such Mobile Food Truck Vendor has obtained
any require licenses and/or permits required by the City Code. (Ord. 15-O-25,
4-21-2015; amd. Ord. 21-O-21, 4-6-2021; Ord. 21-O-63, 12-7-2021; Ord. 23-O-62,
12-19-2023)
 
Notes
1 1. 230 ilcs 40 et seq.
3.3.15: MINORS:
   A.   Selling Or Furnishing Liquor: No person, either directly or indirectly
by himself, bartender, clerk, agent or service or employee, shall at any time
sell, furnish, give or deliver any alcoholic liquor to any person under the age
of twenty-one (21) years. No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years
shall be permitted in any place where beer and wine or other alcoholic liquors
are sold for consumption on the premises, except places in which the principal
business is the sale of services or commodities other than alcoholic liquors.
   B.   Premises Restrictions:
      1.   No holder of an A-1 liquor license or their bartender, agent or
employee shall suffer or permit any person under the age of twenty-one (21), at
any time, to be in that portion of a licensed premises that sells, gives, or
delivers alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises unless such person is
accompanied by his/her parent or guardian; provided, that this shall not apply
to any licensed premises or portion thereof which derives its principal
business from the sale of services or commodities other than alcoholic liquor.
      2.   No holder of a retail liquor dealer’s license or his bartender,
agent or employee shall suffer or permit any person under the age of twenty-one
(21) to be in that portion of a licensed premises that sells, gives, or
delivers alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises, after the hour of
eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M. on any night, provided, that this shall not apply
to any licensed premises or portion thereof which derives its principal
business from the sale of services or commodities other than alcoholic liquor.
      3.   No holder of a retail liquor dealer’s license shall suffer or permit
any person under the age of twenty one (21) to dispense, draw, pour, or mix any
alcoholic liquor, or in any way tend bar as an employee of any licensed
premises for consumption on or off said premises. This shall not prevent people
eighteen (18) years of age and over, as employees of licensed premises, from
delivering alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises.
   C.   All license holders must post all government warning signs and any
other items required by law to be posted by license holders, including but not
limited to those alerting patrons to the dangers of drinking while pregnant.
   D.   Religious Ceremonies: No person, after purchasing or otherwise
obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor
to another person under the age of twenty-one (21) years, except in the
performance of a religious ceremony or service.
   E.   Written Evidence Of Age: Any licensee, or his agent or employee, may
refuse to sell or serve alcoholic beverages to any person who is unable to
produce adequate written evidence of identity and of the fact that he or she is
over the age of twenty-one (21) years. Adequate written evidence of age and
identity of the person is a document issued by a federal, state, county or
municipal government, or subdivision or agency thereof, including, but not
limited to, a motor vehicle operator’s license, a registration certificate
issued under the Federal Selective Service Act, or an identification card
issued to a member of the Armed Forces. Proof that the defendant licensee, or
his employee or agent, demanded, was shown and reasonably relied upon such
written evidence in any transaction forbidden by this section is an affirmative
