7.7.1: PURPOSES AND INTENT:
The purposes and intent of this chapter are as follows:
   A.   To identify, designate, protect, preserve, and encourage the
restoration, rehabilitation, and adaption for continued use of those properties
and structures which represent or reflect the prehistoric, historic,
architectural, cultural, artistic, social, economic, ethnic, or political
heritage of the nation, state, county, or city, or which may be representative
of an architectural or engineering type inherently valuable for the study of
style, period, craftsmanship, method of construction or use of indigenous
materials.
   B.   To safeguard the historic, aesthetic, and cultural heritage of the city
as embodied and reflected in such structures, landscape features, and areas
seen in such examples as houses, commercial buildings, public buildings,
factories, cemeteries, barns, bridges, and fences.
   C.   To stabilize and improve the economic vitality and value of designated
landmarks and historic preservation districts in particular and the city in
general.
   D.   To educate the general public, government officials, and commercial and
industrial interests as to the need to foster historic preservation through the
provisions of the preservation ordinance.
   E.   To work with the city community development department and with other
city commissions in the development and application of a historic preservation
program.
   F.   To foster civic pride in the technological accomplishments, beauty, and
nobility of the past.
   G.   To protect and enhance the attraction of the city to tourists and
visitors, and to support the retention of and stimulus to business and
industry.
   H.   To strengthen the economy and enhance the tax base of the city.
   I.   To promote the use of historic preservation districts, landmarks, and
landscapes for the education, pleasure, and welfare of the citizens of the
city.
   J.   To assist property owners in obtaining the financial benefits and
incentives offered by achieving certified local government status from the
state of Illinois historic preservation agency. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.2: DEFINITIONS:
   ALTERATION: Any act or process which changes one or more of the exterior
architectural features of a structure, including, but not limited to, the
erection, construction, reconstruction of any "improvement" as defined herein.
   ARCHITECTURAL SIGNIFICANCE: The distinctive characteristics of a type,
period, style, or method of construction or use of indigenous construction, or
representing the work of an important builder, designer, architect, or
craftsman who has contributed to the development of the community, McHenry
County, state of Illinois, or the nation.
   CATEGORY 1 MINOR PROJECT: All projects which do not require a building
permit including, but not limited to, awnings, windows and doors (with no
change in the size of the opening), paint, masonry maintenance (cleaning,
sealing or tuckpointing), dumpster enclosures, gutters, landscape, fencing,
sidewalks, parking, reshingling, removing inappropriate and/or nonoriginal
siding, and replication or restoration of original siding, and simple repairs
affecting a nominated or designated landmark or property within a nominated or
designated historic preservation district. Category 1 minor projects include
storefront and facade renovations that involve the replacement of nonoriginal
or nonsignificant storefront facade materials, if this work does not require a
building permit.
   CATEGORY 2 MAJOR PROJECT: All projects which require a building permit such
as the creation of new openings, enlarging window or doors, new construction,
additions, demolition, storefront or facade alterations, and the replacement of
historic elements affecting a nominated or designated landmark or property
within a nominated or designated historic preservation district. Category 2
major projects include all projects which permanently cover, alter, or destroy
original or significant siding materials or architectural features except for
simple repairs, even if a building permit is not otherwise required.
   CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS: A certificate issued by the department
(category 1) or the commission (category 2) indicating its approval of plans
affecting a nominated or designated landmark or property within a nominated or
designated historic preservation district.
   CERTIFICATE OF HARDSHIP: A certificate issued by the commission allowing the
alteration, construction, demolition, or removal affecting a nominated or
designated landmark or property within a nominated or designated historic
preservation district after a certificate of appropriateness has been denied
and after the owner(s) has (have) provided proof that all reasonable use of, or
return from, the property would be lost.
   CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Woodstock, Illinois.
   COMMISSION: The city of Woodstock historic preservation commission.
   CONSTRUCTION: The act of adding an addition to a structure or the erection
of a new principal and/or accessory structure on a lot or property.
   DEMOLITION: Any act or process which destroys, in part or in whole, any
improvement.
   DEMOLITION BY NEGLECT: Neglect in the maintenance of any landmark and/or
building or structure within a historic preservation district resulting in the
deterioration of that building to the extent that it creates a hazardous or
unsafe condition as determined by the building officer of the city of
Woodstock.
   DEPARTMENT: The city's community development department.
   DIRECTOR: The director of the city's community development department.
   EXTERIOR ARCHITECTURAL FEATURES: The architectural character and general
composition of the exterior of a building or structure, including, but not
limited to, the kind and texture of the building exterior, and the type, design
and character of all windows, doors, light fixtures, signs and appurtenant
elements.
   HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT: A place or area so designated by ordinance
of the city council, pursuant to the procedures and requirements prescribed
hereunder.
   HISTORIC STRUCTURE: Any structure or building designated as a landmark or
located in a historic preservation district.
   IMPROVEMENT: Any building, structure, wall, fence, steps, paving, gate,
sign, light fixture, general arrangement of place or area, the kind of texture
or quality of building material, landscaping or landscape architecture, or work
of art which may be erected upon or proposed to be erected upon any specific
real estate.
   LANDMARK: Any improvement designated as a landmark by ordinance of the city
council, pursuant to procedures and requirements prescribed herein.
   LANDMARK SITE: A parcel or part thereof on which is situated a "landmark" as
described herein, and any abutting parcel or part thereof used and constituting
part of the premises on which the landmark is situated.
   ORDINARY MAINTENANCE: That which does not alter the exterior features of a
historic site or historic resource within a historic preservation district.
Exterior features include the architectural style, design, and general
arrangement of the exterior; the nature, and texture of building materials; and
the type and style of all windows, doors, light fixtures, signs, and similar
items found on, or related to, the exterior of a historic site or historic
resource within a historic preservation district. Ordinary maintenance is that
which will have no material effect on the historical, architectural, cultural,
or archaeological value of the historic site or resource within a historic
preservation district.
   OWNER OF RECORD: All of the holders of fee simple title, or an estate of
such duration and enjoyment as to be substantially equivalent to fee simple
title, as indicated by documents recorded in the office of the recorder of
deeds of McHenry County, Illinois.
   PRESERVATION RESTRICTION: A right, whether or not stated in the form of a
restriction, easement, covenant or condition, in any deed, will or other
instrument, executed by or on behalf of the owner(s) of the land or in any
order of taking, appropriate to the preservation of areas, places, building or
structures to forbid or limit acts of demolition, alteration, use or other acts
detrimental to the preservation of the buildings, places or areas designated
pursuant to the provisions hereunder as a landmark or as within a historic
preservation district.
   REPLACEMENT OF MATERIALS: The removal of an existing element on a building
and affixes a replica in its place using materials that are compatible with the
historic structure.
   SIMPLE REPAIR: The repair of existing elements which keep the original
fabric and fix the problem using materials compatible with the existing element
and replaces minor part(s). (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996; amd. Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002;
Ord. 06-0-10, 2-7-2006)
7.7.3: DESIGNATION OF LANDMARKS:
7.7.3.1: NOMINATION OF LANDMARKS:
Any person, group of persons, or association, including the Woodstock historic
preservation commission may submit an application to the commission requesting
that a building, structure, place, or area within the city be designated as a
landmark.
Upon nomination or designation of landmark status, such building, structure,
place, or area shall be afforded the protection of the historic preservation
ordinance. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.2: CRITERIA FOR NOMINATION:
The commission may recommend to the city council the designation of landmark,
upon written proof of owner notification, after a thorough investigation
results in a determination that a property, structure, or alteration retains
the integrity and spirit of the original design, provided that it is:
   A.   Located within the corporate boundaries of the city; and
   B.   Is at least fifty (50) years old; and
It meets one or more of the following criteria:
   C.   It has character, interest, or value which is part of the development,
heritage, or cultural characteristic(s) of the city, the county, the state, or
the nation;
   D.   Its location is a site of a significant local, county, state, or
national event;
   E.   It is identified with a person or persons who significantly contributed
to the development of the city, county, state, or the nation;
   F.   It embodies distinguishing characteristics of an architectural style
valuable for the study of a period, type, method of construction, or use of
indigenous materials;
   G.   It is identified with the work of a master builder, designer,
architect, or landscape architect whose individual work has influenced the
development of the city, county, state, or the nation;
   H.   It embodies elements of design, detailing, materials, or craftsmanship
that render it architecturally significant;
   I.   It embodies design elements that make it structurally or
architecturally innovative;
   J.   It has a unique location or singular physical characteristics that make
it an established or familiar visual feature;
   K.   It has character which is a particularly fine or unique example of a
utilitarian structure, including, but not limited to, commercial buildings,
factories, industrial buildings or structures, including pump houses or
viaducts, with a high level of integrity or architectural significance;
   L.   It establishes a sense of time and place unique to the City;
   M.   It is suitable for preservation or restoration;
   N.   It is included in the National Register of Historic Places and/or the
Illinois Register of Historic Places;
   O.   It has yielded, or may be likely to yield, information important to
pre-history or other areas of archaeological significance;
   P.   It is an exceptional example of a historic or vernacular style or one
of few remaining in the City.
The applicant for landmark designation must demonstrate convincingly the
applicability of one or more of the criteria outlined above, providing ample
documentation to support all statements and assertions. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.3: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Application forms shall be obtained from the Community Development
Department.
   B.   Completed forms shall be submitted to the Community Development
Department which shall forward them to the Commission for their consideration.
Persons wishing guidance or advice prior to completing an application may
contact the staff of the Department. A filing fee may be required.
   C.   The information which must be submitted shall include, but is not
limited to the following:
      1.   The name(s) and mailing addresses of the individuals who last paid
property tax;
      2.   The legal description and common street address of the property
proposed for designation;
      3.   A map drawn to scale delineating the boundaries and location of the
property proposed for designation;
      4.   A written statement describing the property and setting forth
reasons in support of the proposed designation;
      5.   A list and photographs of significant exterior architectural
features;
      6.   A statement indicating whether or not the owner(s) consent(s) to the
landmark designation. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.4: DESIGNATION PROCESS:
   A.   All reasonable efforts shall be made to secure the written consent of
the owner(s) before proceeding with the designation. The owner(s) of record of
any property for which an application is made (unless the request is made by
the owner) shall be informed within seven (7) working days of receipt of such
application. A landmark can be nominated or designated without the consent of
the owners.
   B.   Upon receipt of the completed application, the Commission shall conduct
a public hearing within forty five (45) days. Notice of the public hearing will
be made to the owner(s) of record by certified mail, and to adjacent property
owners and the person(s) filing the application by regular mail. Notice will
also be placed in a newspaper of general circulation of the date, time, place,
and purpose of the public hearing no less than fifteen (15) but not more than
twenty nine (29) days prior to the hearing. A sign shall be placed on a
property within full view of a public right of way, giving notice of the date,
time, place, and purpose of the public hearing for no less than seven (7) days
prior to the hearing.
   C.   At the public hearing, oral or written testimony pertinent to the
proposed designation shall be taken from any person or organization.
   D.   A decision shall be made within sixty (60) days following the date of
the closing of the public hearing. The evaluation and recommendation of the
Commission, and all pertinent information shall be submitted to the City
Council within thirty (30) days of the Commission's decision. Decisions are
made by a simple majority of Commission members in attendance.
   E.   The owner(s) of record shall be notified promptly in a letter of the
decision of the commission and the date of the City Council meeting at which
the application will be addressed.
   F.   To override a recommendation of the Commission, a favorable vote of
four (4) of all the elected members of the City Council is necessary. (Ord.
2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.3.5: NOTICE OF DESIGNATION:
Within five (5) working days after designation by ordinance of the City
Council, and on a yearly basis thereafter, the Commission shall notify the
owner(s) of the landmark site, and tenant(s) if any, that it has been
designated as such, and that an owner must possess a Certificate of
Appropriateness before he or she can procure a building permit, or otherwise
materially affect the exterior appearance of the property. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-
1996)
7.7.4: DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICTS:
7.7.4.1: NOMINATION OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICTS:
Any person, group of persons, or association, including the Woodstock Historic
Preservation Commission, may submit an application to the commission requesting
that a defined geographic area be designated as an historic preservation
district.
Upon nomination or designation of historic preservation district status, each
building, structure, place, or area shall be afforded the protection of the
Historic Preservation Ordinance. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.2: CRITERIA FOR NOMINATION:
The Commission may recommend to the City Council the designation of an historic
preservation district, upon written proof of notification of the owner(s), that
the following requirements shall be met:
   A.   In the case of a new district:
      1.   The geographic area which is the subject of the application has
definable boundaries in the form of natural features or existing physical
improvements; and
      2.   A visual sense of history exists within the proposed boundaries; and
      3.   The buildings, places or areas within the proposed district, by
their inclusion therein, are of sufficient historic significance to be worthy
of rehabilitation, restoration, and preservation because either:
         a.   The proposed district contains within definable geographic
boundaries one or more landmarks along with such other buildings, places or
areas, which, while not of such historic significance to be designated as
landmarks, nevertheless contribute to the overall visual characteristics of the
landmark or landmarks located within the district; or
         b.   The proposed district contains within definable geographic
boundaries such buildings, places or areas which, while not of such individual
significance to be designated as landmarks, nevertheless, as an aggregate,
possess historic significance for the City in:
            (1)   Establishing a sense of time and place unique to the City; or
            (2)   Exemplifying or reflecting the cultural, social, economic,
political, or architectural history of the Nation, the State, or the City; or
            (3)   Representing the distinguishing characteristics of an
architectural type which is inherently valuable for studying a period, style,
method of construction, indigenous materials or unique craftsmanship.
   B.   In the case of addition to existing historic preservation districts:
      1.   The historic preservation district, after inclusion of the property
or properties proposed for addition, constitutes one contiguous area without
"holes" or "gaps", defined by natural or existing improved boundaries.
      2.   The proposed addition does not impair the visual sense of history
within the existing historic preservation district.
      3.   Properties within the proposed addition possess historic
significance or characteristics compatible with that found to exist in the
original district at the time it was designated.
   C.   In the case of deletion from existing historic preservation districts:
      1.   The historic preservation district, after removal of the property or
properties proposed for deletion, constitutes one contiguous area without
"holes" or "gaps", defined by natural or existing improved boundaries.
      2.   The historic preservation district, after removal of the property or
properties proposed for deletion, retains the historic significance or historic
characteristics found to exist at the time the district was originally
designated.
      3.   The property or properties proposed for deletion do not materially
contribute to the historic significance or historic characteristics found to
exist at the time the district was originally designated. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-
1996)
7.7.4.3: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Application forms shall be obtained from the Community Development
Department.
   B.   Completed forms shall be submitted to the Community Development
Department which shall forward them to the Commission for their consideration.
Persons wishing guidance or advice prior to completing an application may
contact the staff of the Department. A filing fee may be required.
   C.   The information which must be submitted shall include, but is not
limited to the following:
      1.   The names and mailing addresses of all the individuals who last paid
property taxes;
      2.   The legal description of the boundary of the proposed district and
the common street address of each of the properties proposed for designation;
      3.   A map delineating the boundary and location of the area proposed for
designation;
      4.   A written statement describing the district and setting forth
reasons in support of the proposed designation;
      5.   A list and photographs of significant exterior architectural
features;
      6.   A statement of which owners consent to the historic preservation
district designation and which do not. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.4: DESIGNATION PROCESS:
   A.   All reasonable efforts shall be made to secure the written consent of
the owner(s) before proceeding with the designation. The owner(s) of record of
any property for which an application is made shall be informed within ten (10)
working days of receipt of such application. A property may be included in a
historic preservation district without the owner(s) consent.
   B.   Upon receipt of the completed application, the Commission shall conduct
a public hearing within forty five (45) days. Notice of the public hearing will
be made to the owner(s) of record by certified mail, and to adjacent property
owners and the person(s) filing the application by regular mail. Notice will
also be placed in a newspaper of general circulation of the date, time, place,
and purpose of the public hearing no less than fifteen (15) but not more than
twenty nine (29) days prior to the hearing. A sign shall be placed on a
property within the proposed district, within full view of a public right of
way, giving notice of the date, time, place, and purpose of the public hearing
for no less than seven (7) days prior to the hearing.
   C.   At the public hearing, oral or written testimony pertinent to the
proposed designation shall be taken from any person or organization.
   D.   A decision shall be made within sixty (60) days following the date of
the closing of the public hearing. The evaluation and recommendation of the
commission, and all pertinent information shall be submitted to the city
council within thirty (30) days of the decision of the commission. Decisions
are made by a simple majority of commission members in attendance.
   E.   The owner(s) of record shall be notified promptly in a letter of the
decision of the commission and the date of the city council meeting at which
the application will be addressed.
   F.   To override a recommendation of the commission, a favorable vote of
three-fourths (3/4) of all the elected members of the city council is
necessary. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.5: NOTICE OF DESIGNATION:
Within thirty (30) days after designation, and on a yearly basis thereafter,
the commission shall notify the owner(s), and tenants if any, of the properties
in the historic preservation district that it has been designated as such, and
that a certificate of appropriateness or a certificate of hardship must be
issued by the commission before an owner or tenant can materially affect the
exterior appearance of a property or obtain a building permit for alterations.
(Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.4.6: RECOGNITION OF EXISTING HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT:
The following area, which includes the Woodstock square historic district as
listed on the National Register of Historic Places in December 1982, is
designated as the historic downtown business preservation district and is
legally described as:
Part of the Southwest Quarter of Section 5, Township 44 North, Range 7 East of
the 3rd Principal Meridian, beginning at the intersection of the centerline of
South Street with the intersection with the centerline of Seminary Avenue;
thence northerly along the centerline of Seminary Avenue to the intersection
with the centerline of Hutchins Street; thence westerly along the centerline of
Hutchins Street to the intersection with the centerline of Madison Street;
thence northerly along the centerline of Madison Street to the intersection
with the centerline of Newell Street; thence westerly along the centerline of
Newell Street to the intersection with the centerline of Clay Street; thence
northerly along the centerline of Clay Street to the centerline of First
Street; thence westerly along the centerline of First Street to the centerline
of the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad right-of- way; thence southeasterly
along said right-of-way to the centerline of Wheeler Street; thence southerly
and southwesterly along the centerline of Wheeler Street to the intersection
with the centerline of Washington Street (Illinois Route 120); thence
northwesterly along the centerline of Washington Street 390 feet to a point;
thence southwesterly perpendicular to the centerline of Washington Street from
the last described point 285 feet to a point; thence westerly 386 feet to a
point, said point being on the west line of said Section 5; thence southerly
from the last described point to the centerline of Lincoln Avenue; thence
easterly along the centerline of Lincoln Avenue to the centerline of Tryon
Street; thence southerly along the centerline of Tryon Street to the
intersection of the centerline with Judd Street; thence westerly along the
centerline of Judd Street to the intersection with the centerline of Hayward
Street; thence southerly along the centerline of Hayward Street to the
intersection with the centerline of South Street; thence easterly along the
centerline of South Street to the place of beginning all within the City of
Woodstock, McHenry County, Illinois.
(Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.5: CATEGORY 2 MAJOR PROJECT:
7.7.5.1: CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS:
   A.   No alteration, new construction, improvement or demolition designated
as a category 2 major project shall be allowed within an existing or proposed
historic preservation district or upon an existing or proposed landmark unless
a certificate of appropriateness has been issued by the commission.
   B.   The building and zoning officer shall not issue a building permit or
demolition permit for any landmark or any historic structure unless a
certificate of appropriateness has been issued by the commission.
   C.   Any category 2 major project that affects the exterior architectural
features visible from any public way shall require a certificate of
appropriateness. (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
   D.   A certificate of appropriateness approval card shall be issued by the
department and shall be prominently displayed on the property until all
exterior work is completed. (Ord. 06-0-11, 2-7-2006)
7.7.5.2: CRITERIA FOR GRANTING A CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS:
   A.   The commission and the community development department shall consider
the following criteria, based on the secretary of the interior's standard for
rehabilitation, and any historic preservation guidelines approved by the city
council when reviewing an application for a certificate of appropriateness:
(Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
      1.   A property shall be used for its historic purpose or to be placed in
a new use that requires minimal change to the defining characteristics of the
building and its site and environment.
      2.   The historic character of a property shall be retained and
preserved. The removal of historic materials or alteration of features and
spaces that characterize a property shall be avoided.
      3.   Each property shall be recognized as a physical record of its time,
place, and use. Changes that create a false sense of historical development,
such as adding conjectural features or architectural elements from other
buildings, shall not be undertaken.
      4.   Most properties change over time; those changes that have acquired
historic significance in their own right shall be retained and preserved.
      5.   Distinctive features, finishes, and construction techniques or
examples of craftsmanship that characterize a property shall be preserved.
      6.   Deteriorated historic features shall be repaired rather than
replaced. Where the severity of deterioration requires replacement of a
distinctive feature, the new feature shall match the old in design, color,
texture, and other visual qualities and, where possible, materials. Replacement
of missing features shall be substantiated by documentary, physical, or
pictorial evidence.
      7.   Chemical or physical treatments, such as sandblasting, that cause
damage to historic materials shall not be used. The surface cleaning of
structures, if appropriate, shall be undertaken using the gentlest means
possible.
      8.   Significant archeological resources affected by a project shall be
protected and preserved. If such resources must be disturbed, mitigation
measures shall be undertaken.
      9.   New additions, exterior alterations, or related new construction
shall not destroy historic materials that characterize the property. The new
work shall be differentiated from the old and shall be compatible with the
massing, size, scale, and architectural features to protect the historic
integrity of the property and its environment.
      10.   New additions and adjacent or related new construction shall be
undertaken in such a manner that if removed in the future, the essential form
and integrity of the historic property and its environment would be unimpaired.
(Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
   B.   The commission shall consider the following architectural design
elements when reviewing plans for a category 2 major project: (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-
5-2002)
      1.   Height And Roof: The height of proposed buildings and structures
shall be visually compatible with the style and character of the surrounding
structures. The roof shape shall be compatible with the architectural style of
the landmark and the surrounding structures to which it is visually related.
      2.   Proportion Of Front Facade: The relationship of the width to the
height of the front elevation shall be visually compatible with buildings,
public ways, and places to which it is visually related.
      3.   Proportion Of Openings: The proportion of window and doors shall be
compatible with the architectural style and character of the adjacent building
or buildings within the historic preservation district.
      4.   Relationship Of Spacing And Buildings: The relationship of a
building or structure to the open space between it and adjoining buildings
shall be visually compatible with the buildings, public ways, and places to
which it is visually related.
      5.   Scale: The size and mass of buildings and structures in relation to
open spaces, windows, door openings, porches and other projections shall be
visually compatible with the buildings, public ways and places to which they
are visually related.
      6.   Materials, Textures, Colors, And Architectural Detail: The
relationship of the materials, textures, colors, and architectural details
should be compatible with the predominant materials used in the existing
building or in the surrounding buildings and structures to which it is related.
      7.   Directional Expression: A building shall be visually compatible with
the buildings, public ways, and places to which it is visually related in its
directional character whether this be vertical, horizontal, or nondirectional
character.
      8.   Landscape: Landscape and appurtenances including signs, fences,
accessory structures and pavings shall be visually compatible with the
buildings, public ways and places to which they are visually related. Landscape
is not considered for one- and two-family dwelling units. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-
1996)
7.7.5.3: ORDINARY MAINTENANCE:
Cosmetic or ordinary maintenance items are not subject to a certificate of
appropriateness except significant changes in exterior schemes for
nonresidential uses. Exterior siding, porch improvements, railings, fences,
storm windows, storm doors, screens, exterior lighting, and similar items shall
be subject to this chapter. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.5.4: DEMOLITION:
Before granting a request for a certificate to demolish a structure which has
been designated a landmark or a structure within a historic preservation
district, the commission must find that at least one of the following
conditions exist:
   A.   The demolition request is for an inappropriate addition, or a
nonsignificant accessory structure, provided that the demolition will not
adversely affect those parts of a building or buildings which are significant
as determined by the commission; or
   B.   The demolition request is for a noncontributing building and the
demolition will not adversely affect the character of the historic preservation
district; or
   C.   The building and zoning officer for the city certifies that demolition
is required for the public safety because of an unsafe or dangerous condition;
or
   D.   The property owner shows that failure to allow demolition would involve
a substantial hardship, economic or otherwise, pursuant to the provisions of
section
7.7.5.6 of this chapter. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.5.5: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Category 2 major project application forms, which are available from
the department, shall be completed and submitted to the department. The
department will forward the completed application to the commission for its
review. Department staff will be available to assist applicants in completing
their applications. A filing fee may be required.
   B.   In addition to the documents required for the issuance of a building
permit, the application shall include, but is not limited to, the following:
      1.   Structure Plan: A drawing including the color and type of surface
materials showing the front and rear elevations, and side elevations where
there are no adjoining buildings.
      2.   Landscape Plan: A drawing showing the location, dimensions and
arrangements of all open spaces and yards, including type and size of planting
materials, color and type of surface materials, methods to be employed for
screening and proposed grades. A landscape plan is not required for single-
family dwellings.
      3.   Plan Details: All plans submitted shall contain or show the
following: height and roof; proportion of front facade; proportion of openings;
relationship of spacing and buildings; scale; materials, textures, colors, and
architectural detail; and directional expression.
      4.   Written Statement: A written statement describing the proposed
construction, alteration, addition or demolition and setting forth the reasons
in support of the proposed action.
      5.   Demolition Applications: Demolition applications shall include
photographs of all exterior elevations and significant interior details.
   C.   The commission shall review the completed application at a regularly
scheduled meeting and shall approve, approve with modifications, or deny the
application within sixty (60) days of the meeting; in the event the application
is continued to another meeting(s), the sixty (60) day deadline shall be after
the last meeting. Written notice of the commission's decision shall be sent to
the applicant within seven (7) days of the decision.
   D.   A denial, or approval with modifications, shall be accompanied by a
statement containing the reasons for the decision. The commission may make
recommendations to the applicant that would cause the commission to reconsider
the application.
   E.   A denial, or approval with modifications, may be appealed pursuant to
the appeal process in section
2.9.6 of this code. (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
7.7.5.6: HARDSHIP:
   A.   A certificate of hardship shall be issued by the commission upon a
finding by it that all reasonable use of, or return from, a designated landmark
or property within a historic preservation district would be denied a property
owner as a result of the disapproval of a certificate of appropriateness.
   B.   The commission may solicit expert testimony, or the applicant may
submit evidence, concerning any of the following items at the time of the
public hearing on the certificate of appropriateness:
      1.   Any substantial decrease in the fair market value of the property as
a result of the denial of the certificate of appropriateness;
      2.   Any substantial decrease in the pretax or after tax return to owner
(s) of record or other investors in the property as a result of the denial of
the certificate of appropriateness;
      3.   Any additional cost of work necessary to comply with the standards
and criteria for the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness;
      4.   In the case of a proposed demolition, the economic feasibility of
rehabilitation or reuse of the existing structure on the property.
   C.   The commission may adopt procedural rules concerning the types of
information, evidence or expert testimony that it considers necessary to make a
determination on an application for a certificate of hardship.
   D.   Upon a finding by the commission that without approval of the proposed
work all reasonable use of, or return from, a designated landmark or property
within a historic preservation district will be denied a property owner, then
the application shall be delayed for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days.
During this period of delay, the commission shall investigate plans and make
recommendations to the city council to allow for a reasonable use of, or return
from, the property, or to otherwise preserve the subject property. Such plans
and recommendations may include, but are not limited to: a relaxation of the
provisions of this chapter, a reduction in real property taxes, financial
assistance, building code modifications, and/or changes in zoning regulations.
   E.   If by the end of this sixty (60) day period, the commission has found
that without approval of the proposed work, the property cannot be put to a
reasonable use or the owner cannot obtain a reasonable economic return
therefrom, then the commission shall issue a certificate of hardship approving
the proposed work. If the commission finds otherwise, it shall deny the
application for a certificate of hardship, and notify the applicant by mail of
the final denial.
   F.   In granting a certificate of hardship in such circumstances, the
commission may prescribe any conditions or limitations that may be necessary to
minimize the adverse impact of the requested alteration or demolition.
   G.   Appeal from the denial of a certificate of hardship may be made to the
city council in the same manner as an appeal from the issuance or denial of a
certificate of appropriateness. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.5.7: ISSUANCE OF PERMITS:
No building permit shall be issued for the alteration, construction,
improvement, or demolition of any building or structure within an existing or
proposed historic preservation district or upon an existing or proposed
landmark, until all requirements of this chapter, as well as applicable
construction codes of the city, have been met. A certificate of appropriateness
or a certificate of hardship shall be required prior to the issuance of such a
permit and shall be valid for a period of one year. (Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.5.8: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to
the fines and penalties set forth in section 1.4.1 of this code. If any person,
firm, organization or corporation receiving a citation for violating any
provision of this chapter fails to pay, settle or adjust the fine specified
herein, then adjudication procedures may be initiated in accordance with title
1, chapter 7, article L of this code or with a court of competent jurisdiction,
and such processes as necessary shall commence. (Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff.
5-1-2009)
   B.   Any person, firm or corporation who alters, repairs, relocates or
demolishes by neglect any landmark or any building or structure within a
historic preservation district without complying with the provisions of this
chapter shall be required to restore the building or structure and its site to
its appearance prior to the violation. This civil remedy shall be in addition
to and not in lieu of any criminal prosecution and penalty contained in this
section.
   C.   In the case of an unauthorized demolition of a landmark or any building
or structure within a historic preservation district, the city council may
prohibit the issuance of a building permit for the subject property for a
period of up to five (5) years after the date of the demolition. (Ord. 2604, 1-
16-1996; amd. Ord. 09-0-24, 4-21-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
7.7.5.9: PREVENTION OF DEMOLITION BY NEGLECT:
The commission, on its own initiative, may file a petition with the building
and zoning officer requesting that the department proceed under public safety
and housing codes to require correction of defects or repairs to eligible or
designated historic landmarks or to buildings or structures in historic
preservation districts so that such landmarks, buildings, and structures shall
be preserved and protected in accordance with the purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 2604, 1-16-1996)
7.7.6: CATEGORY 1 MINOR PROJECTS:
Category 1 minor projects shall not be undertaken without the issuance of a
certificate of appropriateness by the director. The criteria for a category 1
minor project certificate of appropriateness shall be as follows:
   A.   Forms; Fee: Category 1 minor project application forms, which are
available from the department, shall be completed and submitted to the
department. Department staff will be available to assist applicants in
completing their applications. A filing fee may be required.
   B.   Written Statement: A written statement describing the proposed category
1 minor project which includes the reasons in support of the proposed action
shall accompany the application.
   C.   Approval Or Denial; Notice: The director shall approve, approve with
modifications, or deny the application within sixty (60) days after it has been
submitted. Written notice of the director's decision shall be sent to the
applicant within seven (7) days of the decision.
   D.   Reconsideration: A denial, or approval with modifications, shall be
accompanied by a statement containing the reasons for the decision. The
director may make recommendations to the applicant that would cause the
director to reconsider the application.
   E.   Appeal Of Decision: In the event the application is denied the
applicant may appeal the decision to the commission pursuant to section
2.9.6 of this code. (Ord. 02-0-12, 2-5-2002)
CHAPTER 8
PROJECT REVIEW
SECTION:
7.8.1: Project Review Required
7.8.2: Scope And Jurisdiction Of Review
7.8.3: Project Plan Review Procedure
7.8.4: Compliance Requirements
7.8.5: Penalty
7.8.1: PROJECT REVIEW REQUIRED:
To promote the harmonious development of real estate within the city, and to
ensure that such properties are developed in accordance with the preamble of
ordinance 1470, project plans and project reviews are required, in addition to
the requirements of all other regulations of the municipal code of the city
prior to the issuance of building permits for construction of any of the
following types of improvements: (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978; amd. Ord. 01-O-41, 11-
6-2001)
   A.   Required land improvements of a subdivision within the city's planning
and subdivision jurisdiction limits, but limited to entrance features, common
areas and/or open spaces prior to the construction of any subdivision
improvement.
   B.   Multiple-family dwellings for more than two (2) families.
   C.   Public, religious and institutional buildings.
   D.   Hospitals, clinics and nursing homes.
   E.   Hotels, motels and motor courts.
   F.   Commercial and industrial buildings. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978)
   G.   Appurtenant structures to above types of projects including, but not
limited to, parking areas, loading docks, driveways, guardhouses, porches,
canopies, courtyards and service yards. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978; amd. Ord. 2613,
3-6-1996)
   H.   Planned development as required by the zoning ordinance. (Ord. 1470,
11-7-1978)
7.8.2: SCOPE AND JURISDICTION OF REVIEW:
All development of structure sites and improvements identified within section
7.8.1 of this chapter within the city limits, except those sites under the
jurisdiction of review by the historic preservation commission, as determined
by this code, will be examined with respect to each of the following aspects:
(Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001)
   A.   Compatibility of building and landscape design with surrounding
development, existing and future.
   B.   Traffic and traffic patterns, vehicular and pedestrian, both internally
on the site and externally, especially in relation to major thoroughfares.
   C.   Preservation of existing trees, shrubs and/or historic amenities.
   D.   Site grading and topography.
   E.   Provision for open space.
   F.   Screening between incompatible uses.
   G.   Effectiveness of exterior lighting and impact upon surrounding
properties and uses.
   H.   Water retention and runoff, in relation to adjoining properties and on
site amenities.
   I.   Relationship of structures and improvements to public utilities,
existing and proposed. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978)
   J.   Screening of refuse containers and accessory equipment. (Ord. 1470, 11-
7-1978; amd. Ord. 2613, 3-6-1996)
7.8.3: PROJECT PLAN REVIEW PROCEDURE:
   A.   Before an applicant files a building permit application to construct a
building, structure or improvement as defined in section
7.8.1 of this chapter, the applicant shall first file an application for
project review with the community development department ("department" for
purposes of this chapter). (Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001)
   B.   Project review applications shall include those materials required by
the plan commission ("commission" for purposes of this chapter) and the
department. (Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001; amd. Ord. 12-O-21, 3-20-2012)
   C.   Upon receipt of the required filings, the department shall review the
application and plans for compliance with the commission's standards and other
city ordinances. The department shall provide the applicant with a written
report of its review no more than ten (10) business days after a completed
application has been filed. The written report shall include any problems or
deficiencies. The applicant may revise the application and resubmit it to the
department or file for an appeal pursuant to section
2.12.9 of this code.
   D.   Project review approval for an individual building site shall be
revoked in the event the applicant has not applied for a building permit for
the construction of the proposed structure within one year from the date of the
approval of the project.
   E.   Project review approval for a planned development shall be valid as
long as the preliminary and final plats of planned development are valid.
   F.   Prior to approval of the project review application, the applicant may
submit a building permit application to the building and zoning officer.
However, the building and zoning officer shall not issue a building permit
until written project plan approval has been received from the department and
the applicant has established an escrow or letter of credit with the city
pursuant to section
7.8.4 of this chapter. (Ord. 01-O-41, 11-6-2001)
7.8.4: COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Prior to the issuance of any building permit, and subsequent to either
project review or city council action, the applicant for a building permit
shall deposit with the building inspector an itemized estimate of the cost of
the installation of all site improvements, including, but not limited to,
landscaping, plantings, lighting, driveways, off street parking and loading
facilities, sidewalks, parkways and interior streets. In addition to the
estimate of the costs of improvement, the applicant shall also deposit an
escrow deposit or letter of credit in a sum equal to one hundred ten percent
(110%) of the total improvement costs. Escrow accounts shall be created in an
institution designated by the city manager and shall be governed by the terms
and provisions in accordance with escrow agreements, forms of which are
available in the city offices and subject to the approval of the city manager
and the city attorney. (Ord. 1470, 11-7-1978; amd. Ord. 01-0-41, 11-6-2001)
   B.   No certificate of occupancy shall be issued until all site improvements
have been completed; provided, however, that delays due to circumstances beyond
the control of the builder, developer or applicant may be recognized as a
condition for the issuance of a temporary certificate of occupancy, provided
the buildings are otherwise complete. A temporary certificate of occupancy
shall not exceed six (6) months and is not renewable. A temporary certificate
of occupancy may be issued in such circumstances when an escrow deposit or
letter of credit has been deposited equaling one hundred ten percent (110%) of
the cost of any unfinished improvements as determined by the city's development
engineer.
   C.   All escrow deposits and letters of credit shall be conditioned upon the
faithful performance of the applicant and/or builder to complete all the
improvements specified in the project plan. If, in the judgment of the
development engineer the completion of the improvement is being or has been
unreasonably delayed, the development engineer shall serve notice upon the
builder or applicant at his last known address. If, within thirty (30) days
after the date of service of notice, the builder or applicant has not completed
the improvements, the development engineer shall cause the completion of the
improvements specified in the project plan, paying for such improvements out of
the balance of the escrow deposit or letter of credit.
   D.   Prior to the issuance of a final certificate of occupancy for any
improvement, the building owner or applicant shall file with his application
for a final certificate of occupancy, a surety bond in an amount equal to five
percent (5%) of the total cost of the improvements as originally provided in
the cost estimate. The surety bond shall be conditioned upon the workmanlike
installation of the project plan improvements, and shall guarantee the work of
the builder for a period of one year. Evidence of the use of faulty material,
negligence in construction or unworkmanlike performance, if determined by the
development engineer, shall cause forfeiture of the bond. The development
engineer shall then cause the repair and/or replacement of any faulty
construction using the proceeds of such bond to defray the cost of such repair
or replacement. The remainder of any bond forfeited for the repair or
replacement of the improvements shall be returned to the builder. Upon issuance
of the final certificate of occupancy and the filing of the required surety
bond with the city, all previous escrow accounts shall terminate and any
balance returned to the applicant or builder.
   E.   Any decision, ruling or regulation of the development engineer may be
appealed to the city council. The city council may sustain or overrule the
development engineer's decision, ruling or regulation. (Ord. 01-0-41, 11-6-
2001)
7.8.5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense, plus reasonable attorney fees incurred by
the city. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which such violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 01-0-41, 11-6-2001)
CHAPTER 9
FLOODPLAIN REGULATIONS
(Rep. by Ord. 06-0-93, 12-5-2006)
CHAPTER 10
CAPITAL EXPANSION FEE
(Rep. per letter dated 6-22-1998)
CHAPTER 11
DEVELOPMENT FEES
SECTION:
7.11.1: Zoning Fees
7.11.2: Subdivision Fees
7.11.3: Joint Fees
7.11.4: Development Review Deposits
7.11.5: Annexation Fees
7.11.6: CPI Adjustment
7.11.1: ZONING FEES:
The following fees are hereby established for the following services:
   A.   Zoning Amendment (Text Only): $500.00;
   B.   Zoning Amendment (Map/Rezoning): Base fee of $500.00 plus $50.00 for
each acre;
   C.   Zoning Special Use:
      1.   Planned developments: Base fee of $500.00 plus $50.00 for each acre;
      2.   All other special uses: Base fee of $500.00 plus $50.00 for each
acre;
   D.   Temporary Use Permit: $50.00, payable at the time of permit issuance;
and
   E.   Zoning, Variation And/Or Appeal: $125.00.
All fees specified herein shall be paid at the time of filing the first
document or petition. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.2: SUBDIVISION FEES:
At the time of filing the first draft of a plat of subdivision a base fee of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus fifty dollars ($50.00) for each acre shall
be paid to the city. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.3: JOINT FEES:
For any application involving more than one of the items listed in sections
7.11.1 and
7.11.2 of this chapter, the fee shall be calculated on the basis of the highest
fee plus five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each additional item. (Ord. 04-0-
12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.4: DEVELOPMENT REVIEW DEPOSITS:
   A.   Petitions for rezoning and/or annexation, the subdivision or
resubdivision of land for special uses or planned developments shall be
accompanied with a deposit as provided herein as security for the reimbursement
of review expenses incurred by the city. The amount of the deposit is
determined on the basis of total land area and shall consist of a base fee of
two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) plus the following sums:
1 to 20 acres   $100.00 per acre
21 to 50 acres   90.00 per acre
51 to 100 acres   80.00 per acre
Over 100 acres   A base fee of $8,000.00
   plus $70.00 per acre.
   B.   Development review deposits are held by the city to cover the expense
of reviewing both residential and nonresidential development activities,
including, but not limited to, subdivisions, planned developments, special
uses, rezonings and similar activities. The deposit shall be held by the city
until reimbursement of all costs for said activities has been received, at
which time the balance on the deposit will be refunded. In the event said costs
are not reimbursed by the petitioner, the city may use the deposit for
reimbursement.
   C.   Where unusual problems or conditions are encountered which require
additional review, the community development director may require the deposit
of additional funds to cover the cost of such additional review. (Ord. 04-0-12,
1-6-2004)
7.11.5: ANNEXATION FEES:
The following fees are hereby established for the annexation of land into the
city:
   A.   Land having an area of two (2) or more acres: One thousand dollars
($1,000.00) per acre, which shall be paid at the time of annexation, and one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per lot or unit, whichever is greater, which shall
be paid at the time the building permit is issued.
   B.   Annexation fees shall not be required for annexations which are
initiated by the city. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
7.11.6: CPI ADJUSTMENT:
The fees required in this chapter shall be subject to a "CPI adjustment" which
shall be calculated on January 1, 2005, and on January 1 in each year
thereafter. Annually, the fees and cash contributions shall be adjusted by the
December–December percent change as published by the United States department
of labor's bureau of labor statistics, all items consumer price index ("CPI")
for urban consumers (1982-1984 = 100) for the Chicago consolidated metropolitan
statistical area, Illinois. If any index is calculated from a base different
from the base period 1982-1984 = 100, such index shall be converted to a base
period of 1982-1984 = 100 by use of a conversion factor supplied by said bureau
of labor statistics. If the CPI is discontinued or replaced, such other
governmental cost of living index or computation which replaces the CPI shall
be used in order to obtain substantially the same result as would be obtained
if the CPI had not been discontinued or replaced. (Ord. 04-0-12, 1-6-2004)
